title: Familiar Faces Returning Soon
description: It did not take long for the pair who portrayed Frank Bartles and Ed Jaymes in wine-cooler commercials to end their stint on advertising's unemployment line.

title: The Trial Is Not Over For Female Gymnasts
description: In the aftermath of competition, the top six men and the top six women here at the United States Olympic gymnastics trials could not have reflected better a difference in team selection.

title: Any Championship Counts in Cleveland
description: The great bubblegum chew-off ended in a draw.

title: Chronicle
description: He did his homework, he passed the test, so tomorrow HUGH DOWNS will step out of his telvision persona to receive a special certificate in geriatric education from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

title: Lottery Should Increase Its Runner-Up Prizes
description: To the Editor:

title: Value Merchants reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
Roberta Rettner, Elliott Nacmias
description: Roberta Diane Rettner, the daughter of Marcelle Mandelbaum of Tamarac, Fla., and the late Morris B. Rettner, was married yesterday to Joseph Nacmias, a son of Elliott Nacmias of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Francine Schouchana Nacmias. Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum performed the ceremony aboard the World Yacht Duchess in New York Harbor.

title: Housing Data May Give Signals on the Economy
description: Struggling to make sense out of economic statistics that are mixed at best, credit market participants are questioning whether the sluggish recovery that seems to be developing could falter.

title: Ann Harrisburg, Jeffrey Oppenheim
description: Ann Leslie Harrisburg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Harrisburg of Portland, Me., was married yesterday to Dr. Jeffrey Sable Oppenheim, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin S. Oppenheim of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. Rabbi Marc D. Angel performed the ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel in New York.

title: Bonds Is Hurt, and Pirates Get Scared
description: When Barry Bonds crumpled in front of home plate after straining a muscle in his side, it meant more to the Pittsburgh Pirates than just losing their star player for at least two games.

title: Will 3 Be a Charm For Teresa Edwards?
description: The Olympic Games in Barcelona, Spain, this summer will be the third for TERESA EDWARDS of the United States women's basketball team that was named recently.

title: Gucci's Current Campaign: Recovering Its Elite Image
description: HOW do you get Palm Beach patricians and Hollywood tycoons back into Gucci loafers after their secretaries start carrying Gucci handbags? That was the challenge facing Dawn Mello, the former president of Bergdorf Goodman who was given the mandate to revamp the Gucci image in 1990.

title: Europe's Television Borders Start to Fall
description: The French and the Germans have long been the driving forces behind European unification. Recently, the two countries announced plans for a joint military unit. Now they have started Arte, a French-German cultural television network.

title: Mays (J.W.) Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 42,334 in the quarter and $ 56,366 in the 9 months, and after extraordinary credits of $ 94,000, or 4 cents a share, and $ 289,000, or 13 cents a share, in quarter and 9 months, respectively, from tax-loss carryforwards.c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 65,789 in the quarter and $ 268,077 in the 9 months.Year-ago periods were restated to comply with provisions of FASB No. 13, Accounting for Leases.Year-ago periods included a gain of $ 3,012 on the sale of fixed assets.

title: Review/Television; Letting Fundamentalists Tell Their Own Stories
description: Everyone knows that religious fundamentalism is on the upsurge around the globe, but exactly what the term signifies is less clear. It is applied to movements that are distinguished as much by their differences as by their similarities. So welcome to "The Glory and the Power: Fundamentalisms Observed," an enlightening three-part PBS series on aspects of fundamentalism in the United States, Israel and Egypt.

title: Programming & Systems Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
Consilium Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company said year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in accounting.

title: Sparta Surgical Corp. reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company said that the loss for the latest year resulted from lower gross profit margins due to lower sales volume and fixed manufacturing costs. Also, due to a capital shortage throughout the year, the company absorbed $ 482,148 in debt issuance costs including a non-cash expense of about $ 300,000 associated with issuing common stock and common stock purchase warrants to various unaffiliated lenders.

title: Affinity Biotech reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company completed its initial public offering of stock in April. It attributed the increased loss to higher research and development expenses.

title: BASKETBALL: Sports of The Times; The Bulls and Jordan Blaze a Tough Trail in Playoff Finals
description: THE GAME was over, and nobody, but nobody, went home. Not only did the 18,676 fans who filled Chicago Stadium last night not avail themselves of the exits and staircases, as is a generally held custom, but they stood and screamed at the top of their substantial lungs: "We want the Bulls! We want the Bulls!"

title: Admar Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: In Prosperous Bridgehampton, a Racetrack Tries to Stay Alive
description: To auto racing fans, the historic Bridgehampton Racetrack has some of the best gear-wrenching curves and flat-open straightaways in the racing circuit. To real-estate developers, the wooded 518-acre property overlooking Little Peconic Bay is one of the largest and most desirable undeveloped tracts in the Hamptons.

title: Del Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 9 months are adjusted for a 6-percent stock dividend paid in December 1991.

description: New York City Ballet New York State Theater

title: Polly Peck Plan To Sell a Unit
description: Coopers & Lybrand, the bankruptcy administrator for Polly Peck International P.L.C., said today that it planned to sell Polly Peck's Del Monte fresh fruit business.

title: Rax Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
Yeltsin, Due in U.S. Today, Is Still Complex and Elusive
description: It is a year now since Boris N. Yeltsin became the first elected President of Russia, and the reviews are as diverse as the extraordinary chain of events that transformed him from the maverick leader of a Soviet republic to the master of the Kremlin.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Media Business

title: Elizabeth Barkin, Nathan D. Leight
description: Elizabeth Barkin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Barkin of New York, was married there yesterday to Nathan David Leight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Leight of Bay Harbor Islands, Fla. Rabbi Bradley Shavit Artson performed the ceremony at Harmony Club.

title: Rebecca Kaplan, A. I. Greenspan
description: Rebecca Kaplan, a daughter of Megan V. Kaplan of Bethesda, Md., and the late Sheldon Z. Kaplan, was married yesterday to Andrew Ira Greenspan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney N. Greenspan of Chevy Chase, Md. Rabbi Norman Weinberg performed the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Bridgford Foods Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
New York Police, in Compromise, Are to Get More Semiautomatics
description: The State Legislature and the New York City Police Department have struck a deal to kill legislation that would have forced the department to arm all its officers with semiautomatic weapons, agreeing instead to give the guns to 1,000 additional police officers in a major expansion of a current pilot program.

title: A Cold Final Quarter For Fratello and Albert
description: The Chicago Bulls had just laid waste to the Portland Trail Blazers on Sunday to win the National Basketball Association championship, outscoring the Fizzlers, 33-14, in the fourth quarter for a 97-93 victory. And what did Mike Fratello, the motor-driven czar of the TeleStrator say about Portland?

title: HOTELIER IS NAMED TRUSTEE OF CASCADE INTERNATIONAL
description: A Miami-area mortgage broker and hotel manager, Kenneth A. Welt, yesterday was appointed trustee of the troubled Cascade International Inc., the women's clothing retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection in January after its chief executive disappeared. Mr. Welt replaces Cascade's chairman, Aaron Karp, and president, John T. Sirmans Jr., and will assume the powers of the board. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Robert. A. Mark had ordered the ouster of Mr. Karp and Mr. Sirmans in May, ruling that they were "tainted" by fraud committed by the previous chief executive, Victor G. Incendy.

title: Laser Recording Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: North American National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
N.B.A. Winners On Nestle Crunch
description: Television commercials for Nestle Crunch featuring Magic Johnson, which were filmed before the basketball star announced he has the virus that causes AIDS, remain shelved. But a new advertising campaign for the candy bar features the Los Angeles Lakers teams on which Mr. Johnson played.

title: Bioplasty Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net incomeThe company attributed the losses to non-recurring charges associated with inventory write-downs totaling $ 1.4 million, and various lawsuit costs and settlements totaling another $ 4.4 million.

title: Randolph Accentuates the Positive
description: Willie Randolph's locker is in such a far corner of the Mets' clubhouse, it is almost as if he wishes he were in the next room.

title: Russians Say I.M.F. Demands May Nullify Benefits of Loans
description: Officials negotiating Russia's aid package with the International Monetary Fund asserted today that the fund was seeking to impose demands so burdensome that they could weaken the nation's teetering economy and nullify many of the benefits of a $24 billion aid package for Russia.

title: Reporter's Notebook; When Shells Stop Raining Down, Sarajevans Dress Up and Step Out
description: When the guns on the hillside paused for a few hours on Sunday, Zekria Cecko polished his black shoes, pulled out a freshly starched white shirt and a striped club tie, and tucked a lacy handkerchief in his breast pocket. Then he set out to join the crowd strolling down Marshal Tito Street, the very picture of a gentleman.

title: Executive Changes
description: DIME SAVINGS BANK OF NEW YORK named John F. Kennedy senior vice president and deputy controller and Paul F. Leone senior vice president and deputy auditor. GE CAPITAL FLEET SERVICES, Minneapolis, appointed S. Tracy Coster senior vice president and general manager of GE Capital Public Finance, a business unit that provides tax-exempt financing of public services for state and local governments. She had been manager of business development and planning for GE Transportation Systems in Erie, Pa. H. J. HEINZ CO., Pittsburgh, appointed David R. Williams and Luigi Ribolla senior vice presidents. Mr. Williams will remain chief financial officer in Pittsburgh. Mr. Ribolla, who had been managing director of Heinz-Italia, will head European operations and will remain based in Milan, Italy. PERSEPTIVE BIOSYSTEMS INC., Cambridge, Mass., named Noubar B. Afeyan president and chief executive, replacing James E. Coutre, who remains a director. PREMARK INTERNATIONAL INC., Deerfield, Ill., named Joseph W. Deering president of its food equipment group based in Troy, Ohio. He succeeds James M. Ringler, who was appointed to the newly created post of president and chief operating officer. RIDDELL SPORTS, INC., New York, named Stephen D. Tannen president and chief operating officer. SEARS P.L.C., London, a retailer, appointed John Lovering to the new post of managing director for corporate development and international operations. He had been group finance director. That post will be filled by Stephen Park.

title: British Are Planning to Remove A-Arms From Ships and Aircraft
description: The British Government said today that it would remove tactical nuclear weapons from all Royal Navy surface ships and attack aircraft as part of a program to dismantle all but "an absolute minimum" of Britain's nuclear stockpile.

title: 'Romper Room' Host On Her Abortion Case
description: When she talks about that summer of 1962 when headlines worldwide were howling about her, Sherri Chessen refers to herself as "Miss Sherri." That was the way she was known to the thousands of children who recited their Do Bees and Don't Bees as they watched her on the Scottsdale, Ariz., edition of Romper Room, the nationally syndicated television show.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Stonewall Chorale Fashion Institute of Technology Manhattan

title: Yeltsin Arrives on a New Playing Field
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia arrived here today for his two-day meeting with President Bush as negotiators for the two nations worked hurriedly into the night in an effort to conclude an agreement that would sharply reduce their nuclear arsenals.

title: Volt Information reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: b-Net incomec-After extraordinary credits of $ 538,000, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 801,000, or 16 cents a share, in the 6 months, both reflected gains on the repurchase of debt, net of income taxes. The periods also included gains of $ 6.2 million, or $ 1.29 a share, in the quarter and $ 5.6 million, or $ 1.14 a share, in the 6 months, on the settlement of litigation.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; Quayle Attacks New York as Home of Liberal Failure
description: A month before the Democratic Party arrives in New York for its national convention, Vice President Dan Quayle returned here yesterday to lambaste the party's liberal leaders, warning, "We must not let them do to the rest of America what they have done to the people of New York City."

title: Cheese Duty On Hungary To Continue
description: The Bush Administration, which has criticized Western Europe for not allowing more food imports from Eastern Europe, announced this afternoon that it would not eliminate existing duties on Goya cheese imported from Hungary.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; On TV, Clinton Finds an Audience That Listens
description: Listen to Bill Clinton on the morning talk shows. No saxophone. No sunglasses. He is serious, concise and eager to repeat his claim of outsider status in an election year suddenly gone screwy.

title: Eddie Lopat, 73, Yankee Pitcher On 5 Series Championship Teams
description: Eddie Lopat, one of the three pitching mainstays for the New York Yankees during their reign of five straight World Series championships from 1949 to 1953, died in his sleep early yesterday at the home of his son, John, in Darien, Conn. He was 73 years old.

title: Alkermes Inc. reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a one-time non-cash charge of $ 2,199,978 for acquired research and development in fiscal 1991.

description: b-Included $ 228,000 charge related to start-up costs of MediTek Health Corp. and increased expenditures for aerospace research and development programs.c-Included charge of $ 555,000 related to start-up costs of MediTek and increased expenditures for development programs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Their names are not usually associated with battles at clinic doors to preserve legalized abortion. But this afternoon, LAURA POMERANTZ, a senior vice president of the Leslie Fay Companies; LINDA J.WACHNER, the president, chairman and chief executive of Warnaco Inc., and CHARLOTTE MOSS, the owner of an interior design concern that bears her name, are giving a power tea at the "21" Club for the National Abortion Rights Action League. Among the 60 women, mainly from the fashion industry and related fields, who are expected to attend are: Pauline Trigere, Nancy Novograd, Allison Stern, Ellin Saltzman, Adrienne Vittadini, Lee Traub, Colombe Nichols and Dana Buchman.

title: New York's Senior Representative to Retire
description: In the third blow in a week to New York State's influence in Congress, Representative Frank Horton, the dean of the state's Congressional delegation who faced a tough re-election battle because of redistricting, announced today that he was retiring.

title: Trak Auto reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: b-Net loss

title: Mayor Forms A Task Force On Hotel Fires
description: A fire broke out in an exercise room at a midtown Manhattan hotel last night, only hours after Mayor David N. Dinkins formed a task force to investigate a string of 10 other suspicious but small fires set in other hotels in the midtown area.

title: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: Russia's New Role; As Moscow Feels Its Way Abroad, It Draws Conservative Fire at Home
description: For many years, the lugubrious former Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, was known as Mr. Nyet because of the Soviet Union's rejection of almost anything the United States proposed.

title: Topics of The Times; The G.O.P. and Democracy
description: Do Republicans care about increasing voter participation? For the answer, pay close attention to the House's roll call vote today on landmark legislation to make voting a lot easier.

title: Road Show on Biotech and Bugs
description: J. D. Brooks is barreling south through Virginia's Dismal Swamp region, a cellular telephone and a recently drained plastic coffee cup at his side, cheerfully explaining how his company's bacteria destroy the stomachs of Colorado potato beetles. He falls silent for a moment and nods toward the soggy, heavily wooded flatlands crowding the two-lane highway.

title: Martin McKneally, Legion Commander And Attorney, 77
description: Martin B. McKneally, a former New York state and national commander of the American Legion who served one term as a Republican Congressman and later pleaded guilty to income-tax evasion, died on Sunday at the Castle Point Veteran's Administration Hospital near Beacon, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Newburgh, N.Y.

title: Patterns
description: The Well-Dressed Antihero

title: Commtron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
For Holmes, the Fight Against Tough Odds Goes Back a Long Way
description: It takes a maverick to resist conventional wisdom and believe that at 42 years of age he can win the heavyweight title.

title: Black Clergy Urges Boycott in 'Day of Absence'
description: A group of black clergymen called on blacks and other New Yorkers "of good will" yesterday to boycott schools, shops and workplaces on Friday to protest the Rodney G. King verdict, police brutality and racism in general.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Third Rail Brass St. John's in the Village Greenwich Village

title: Old, Deadly Business With Russia
description: When George Bush, elected President of the United States, sits down today with Boris Yeltsin, elected President of Russia, they'll have historic new business to do -- like nurturing democracy in Russia and getting International Monetary Fund backing for its economic reforms.

title: Toxic Agents Found to Be Killing Off Whales
description: THE beluga whales that roam the St. Lawrence River in Canada seem to be magnets for pollution, attracting so many toxic chemicals that some of their carcasses could be considered hazardous waste. Yet for several years scientists and Government officials have debated whether the chemicals found in the whales were the primary reason the population has failed to thrive.

title: Meddlers on the School Board
description: It has never been clearer: New York City needs a new method for choosing its Board of Education. Mayor David Dinkins is moved to say so anew, and his recent criticism of the board rings with merit. With reading and math scores going down, with school buildings in disrepair, with public trust in the schools waning, what does the board choose to argue endlessly about? The details of an AIDS education program.

title: National Media Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 2,169,000, or 20 cents a share, on a gain from sale of the company's National Syndications subsidiary.c-Net loss and after a loss of $ 1,189,000 from discontinued operations.d-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,436,000.

title: PLASTICS RECYCLING UNIT'S SALE TO ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS
description: Illinois Tool Works Inc. said yesterday that it was buying the assets of Du Pont's plastics recycling alliance subsidiary. No terms were disclosed. Du Pont set up the unit in 1989 as a venture with Waste Management Inc., based in Oak Brook, Ill. Du Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., assumed full ownership of the operation, which recycles plastic bottles, in October 1991.

title: Further Adventures Of Carmen Sandiego
description: THAT gallivanting and elusive criminal Carmen Sandiego is back and better than ever. Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego?, a product of Broderbund Software of Novato, Calif., has been put on a CD-ROM disk.

title: Arch Petroleum Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: After Court Ruling, Mexico Tells U.S. Drug Agents to Halt Activity
description: In a sharp, angry response to the Supreme Court decision supporting the abduction from Mexico of a doctor sought in the United States, Mexico announced tonight that it was suspending the activities of American drug enforcement agents in Mexico.

title: 2 Directors Resign From Arts Agency
description: Two of the 14 program directors of the National Endowment for the Arts resigned last week, bringing resignations to three since Anne-Imelda Radice became acting chairwoman of the Federal agency on May 1.

title: Japan's Parliament Votes to End Ban on Sending Troops Abroad
description: Ending nearly two years of bitter debate, the Japanese Parliament approved a bill today permitting the dispatch of military personnel abroad, for the first time since World War II, to play a limited role in international peacekeeping operations.

title: U.S. Agents Seize Cocaine Processing Lab in Brooklyn
description: Federal agents in Brooklyn yesterday shut down a laboratory for refining cocaine, a type of operation that is rarely found in this country because processing can be done more cheaply and with less likelihood of detection in South America.

title: Some Major Feuds Stand in the Way Of Problem Solving
description: Lost in the shadows of the power play that failed last week in major league baseball was an alarm sounded that the game has some serious problems. So serious that management might do well to address them rather than wasting energy and time bickering and fighting.

title: Louis Biancolli, 85, A Writer and Critic
description: Louis Biancolli, an author and a music critic, died on Saturday at the New Milford Hospital in New Milford, Conn. He was 85 years old and lived in New Milford.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday, about efforts to fend off the effects of aging and to improve thought processes through the use of the nutritional supplements, vitamins and prescription drugs collectively called smart drugs, misidentified a direct-marketing company that sells nutritional products. It is Omnitrition International.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Coals to Newcastle Dept.; High-Tech Windmills Are Sold to the Dutch
description: All right, so foreign car manufacturers have grabbed a third of the United States market, America does not make videocassette recorders and even table grapes are imported these days. But a California company is fighting back.

title: Chess
description: At the end of the Schweizerische Kreditanstalt-Mephisto Tournament in Munich in late May, the one man to come through to victory was Mikhail Gurevich. At the start of the last round, the 33-year-old former Russian grandmaster, who now lives in Belgium, trailed the leaders, Robert Hubner of Germany and Boris Gelfand of Ukraine, by half a point. But Gurevich defeated the American entrant, Larry Christiansen of Queens, and achieved the winning 7-4 score while both his chief rivals lost and shared second place.

title: Too Much Tension, Too Few Runs
description: Even Mark Gardener, the Expos' starting pitcher, could sense the tightness around the Mets.

title: Missouri Bonds Are Priced
description: An $82.6 million tax-exempt bond offering by the Missouri Health and Higher Education Facilities Authority was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by A. G. Edwards & Sons. The maximum yield was 6.384 percent for an issue due in 2012.

title: Israel Welcomes Gorbachev as a Hero
description: The last three years have seen 360,000 people come to Israel from the former Soviet Union, so one more Russian arrival should probably not cause heads to turn.

title: Topics of The Times; Brooklyn: The Royal Borough
description: Last Sunday the young star of "The Secret Garden," Daisy Egan, announced to the annual Welcome Back to Brooklyn Day that she loved Brooklyn because it didn't smell. She seemed to know what she was talking about, even if her audience didn't. She's a native.

title: By Design; Buckle Up for the Year of the Belt
description: If this will be, as some fashion experts proclaim, the Year of the Belt, now is not too soon to start cinching in.

title: CHRONICLE
description: His face may be a new one at Lincoln Center, but it is familiar at dozens of other academic and cultural institutions. Dr. ERNEST L. BOYER, the president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching and a Commissioner of Education in the Carter Administration, has been named the chairman of the Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education, it was announced yesterday. Dr. Boyer will also sit on the Lincoln Center board and executive committee.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks in Appearance on a CBS Program
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Gov. Bill Clinton on the CBS News program "This Morning" in a question-and-answer session with an audience.

title: Thor Energy Resources reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Macy Appoints 2 Executives As It Begins Filling Vacancies
description: R. H. Macy & Company announced two key executive appointments yesterday as it began plugging the holes left in its top ranks by the departure of managers in the wake of the retailer's bankruptcy.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media; Bush Considers Following His Rivals on TV Talk Programs
description: President Bush said today that he was considering joining the parade of Presidential contenders to the television talk-show circuit, a move that his advisers were urging him to make as a means of countering the unexpected appeal of the independent Ross Perot.

title: Bridge
description: A women's team match played in Corpus Christi, Tex., a week ago in the Pan-American Championships had a meaning on two levels, one of which escaped the attention of the officials, the press and the players most concerned.

title: American Resource reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Senior Classes Seeking Jobs, Not Themselves
description: At 18, Eva Pitera has her future all figured out.

title: Suicide Myths Cloud Efforts To Save Children
description: WITH suicide now the third leading cause of death among children and the second among older teen-agers, researchers are overturning long-held beliefs about the reasons young people kill themselves.

description: b-Net loss

title: Autotote Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a one-time net gain of $ 2,600,000 related to an insurance claim.c-Net loss

title: Living Poolside, and Wanting More; Insider-Trading Charges and the Southampton Summer Set
description: They gathered by the sea during the hazy summer, and at first life couldn't have been sweeter. The poolside parties at Ed Downe's place in this moneyed resort were a treasured habit. In the morning, the tennis players would compete on the clay court. Once the sun was high, the very adequate buffet lunch would be set out by the pool, and everyone ate and fraternized at the umbrella tables.

title: Still Arguing the Value of Warhol's Estate
description: Nobody knew as well as Andy Warhol how much his art was worth. And nobody hyped it better. But five years after his death, Warhol's estate -- more the magnitude of an investment banker's than an artist's -- is enmeshed in a series of battles that seriously question both the value of his art and the uses to which the income from selling it should be put.

title: ARCO CHEMICAL TO TAKE A $56 MILLION CHARGE
description: The ARCO Chemical Company said yesterday that it expected to take a $56 million charge in the second quarter for selling its 50 percent stake in its money-losing Korean venture. ARCO said it would make an equity payment, which it did not detail, to its venture partner, Yukong Ltd., South Korea's largest oil refiner, and will be released from all obligations. The venture operates a plant at Ulsan, South Korea, that produces propylene, used in seat cushions and bedding, and styrene, used in packaging and drinking cups.

title: Yanks Are Footnotes For Reardon
description: The winning formula the Yankees discovered for two days in Cleveland disappeared quickly against the Red Sox tonight.

title: Circuit City Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Liberal Party Ponders Perot Endorsement
description: The leader of New York's Liberal Party said yesterday that he would not rule out endorsing Ross Perot for President, which would guarantee the potential independent candidate a place on the November ballot.

title: Nurture, Not Nature, Gets Women Lost
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Taking On F.D.A. Is Costly to Barr
description: BARR LABORATORIES INC., a generic drug maker that was one of the first companies to blow the whistle on corrupt Federal drug officials three years ago, is still standing up to the Food and Drug Administration. And it seems to be paying heavily for its feisty attitude, even though a number of F.D.A. officials were later found guilty of taking bribes and manipulating the drug approval process.

title: For Fall, Think Vests, Ties And, Yes, Longer Skirts
description: Sportswear, the jewel in the crown of American fashion, is leading the march into fall. Orders from retailers are up as much as 50 percent over last year, manufacturers report, and little resistance is expected from consumers to visible style changes like longer skirts.

title: Keep Quiet On Shooting, Mayor Told
description: The New Jersey Attorney General admonished Mayor Sharpe James today to stop talking about the investigation into a shooting and possible cover-up by members of the Newark Police Department.

title: Less Expensive Lines From Compaq
description: FULFILLING a vow made in its darkest hours, the Compaq Computer Corporation yesterday introduced two new families of desktop computers that are hundreds, and in some cases thousands, of dollars less expensive than the company's premium Deskpro/M machines.

title: Thrift Is Under Siege in Japan As Use of Credit Cards Soars
description: For years the Japanese have been unwavering in their devotion to thrift, regarding personal savings as a measure of national strength. Then they met credit cards.

title: Perot's Ticket to the White House
description: Mr. Edward RollinsDallas, Tex.Dear Ed,

title: Crime Boss Is Convicted in Rackets Trial
description: Vittorio Amuso, portrayed by prosecutors as the brutal boss of the Lucchese crime family, was convicted yesterday of all 54 charges in his racketeering trial, including nine murders.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Racetracks in Florida Are Jockeying for Dates
description: Florida, the winter home of Eastern horse racing, is flying down the homestretch of another political season that will determine the fate of its thoroughbred business, and it looks like a photo finish.

title: Phillies Stop Pirates And Halt Streak at 5
description: Phillies 4, Pirates 1

title: The Archeology of a Crisis
description: A third of America's population was not born or not yet in kindergarten when, 20 years ago tomorrow, burglars working for the Committee to Re-elect the President were arrested breaking into Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate hotel complex in Washington.

title: Utilities Say '81 New York Law Is Proving Costly
description: New York State consumers will pay $4.5 billion or more in extra costs in the 1990's, according to the state's utilities, because of a law passed in Albany at the tail end of the last energy crisis.

title: Coming to Pizza Huts: All-You-Can-Eat Buffet
description: In an attempt to lift sales, Pizza Hut, the nation's largest pizza chain, plans to install all-you-can-eat buffets in 2,000 restaurants by the end of the year.

title: Sports of The Times; The Boss Explains (Sort of)
description: We do not really know if Hiroshi Yamauchi, the new $75 million absentee owner of the Seattle Mariners, speaks English. We are just guessing that George Steinbrenner, the absentee owner of the New York Yankees, does not speak Japanese. But let us assume that if they ever spoke on the telephone, it would sound something like this:

title: HIGH COURT BACKS SEIZING FOREIGNER FOR TRIAL IN U.S.
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the United States can kidnap a criminal suspect from a foreign country, over that country's objection and without following the procedures set out in an extradition treaty, to put the suspect on trial in a Federal court.

title: German Prices Flat
description: Wholesale prices in the former West Germany were unchanged in May from April and up 1.7 percent from May 1991, the Government's federal statistical office said. That compares with a monthly rise of three-tenths of 1 percent and an annual increase of 2.3 percent in April, the agency said.

title: Some New Turns for Motel 6
description: Motel 6, the nationwide motel chain, is taking its advertising into new arenas -- television and the market among Hispanic people.

title: LOTUS CARS PLANS TO STOP MAKING $40,000 ELAN ROADSTER
description: The Lotus Cars Ltd. division of the General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would stop producing its $40,000 Elan roadster, ending an effort by the British sports car maker to revive its fortunes by selling a lower-priced model. "The Elan was introduced into the weakest high-end sports car market in recent history," Lotus said in a letter to its dealers, adding that it could not make the Elan "at a price that makes it a profitable element of our business."

title: GULAG HELD M.I.A.'S, YELTSIN SUGGESTS
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia said today that some Americans captured during the Vietnam War were apparently transferred from Hanoi to labor camps in the Soviet Union. He added that some of them may still be alive, possibly in psychiatric hospitals.

title: Ion Laser Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: University Patents reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 72,202, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 117,328, or 2 cents a share, in the 9 months, from note payments being made by Unilens Corp. in connection with the 1989 sale of the assets of the optical products subsidiary.c-Net incomed-Included gain of $ 960,400 from reversal of an acquired rent liability which was eliminated with the termination of a lease.

title: Scrabble's Word Nerds Live for the Perfect Mix
description: THIS is a column about Scrabble and the raczy pleope who play it.

title: Reactions to Quayle Split on Party Lines
description: The response from elected officials in New York to Vice President Dan Quayle's remarks yesterday divided sharply along party lines. Republicans accepted Mr. Quayle's criticism that the party in power in the city -- the Democrats -- had been responsible for its mounting woes.

title: McDonnell Postpones Jumbo Jet
description: Lacking a single order so far for its planned new jumbo jet, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had bowed to the inevitable and postponed the start of the program until next year.

title: For Holmes, the Fight Against Tough Odds Goes Back a Long Way
description: It takes a maverick to resist conventional wisdom and believe that at 42 years of age he can win the heavyweight title.

title: Drivers Tell Of Gunfire And Blood On School Bus
description: It began with "popping" sounds, continued with bullets ricocheting around the school bus and ended a block away with 6-year-old Cesar Sandoval surrounded by emergency workers, wounded by a bullet that pierced his skull.

title: Observer; Save That Arch For Fu
description: Having recently betrayed irritation with the homilies of Parson Quayle, I am suffering the consequences. A New Jersey man suggests I belong to "a cabal of ultra-leftists," and a fellow in Illinois, who really knows how to hurt a guy, calls me an "arch liberal."

title: 2d Police Inquiry Begins Into Drug-Dealing Charge
description: Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown appointed his second in command yesterday to investigate allegations that senior officials of the New York City Police Department had failed to adequately support an internal affairs investigation of an officer who was later arrested by Suffolk County officials on drug-trafficking charges.

title: Mutant Foods Create Risks We Can't Yet Guess
description: To the Editor:

title: Proler International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Classical Music in Review
description: Steinway Foundation John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts Washington

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court's Decision on the Kidnapping of Foreigners
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's 6-to-3 ruling today in United States v. Alvarez Machain, holding that an extradition treaty with another country, in this case Mexico, does not bar the United States from kidnapping a citizen of that country and putting him on trial in Federal court. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the decision for the majority, joined by Justices Byron R. White, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy, David H. Souter and Clarence Thomas. Justice John Paul Stevens wrote a dissenting opinion that Justices Harry A. Blackmun and Sandra Day O'Connor joined. FROM THE DECISION By Chief Justice Rehnquist

title: Robert William Haack, 75, Dies; Led Stock Exchange During Crises
description: Robert William Haack, who led the New York Stock Exchange during a period of crisis and change and later became the chairman of the Lockheed Corporation, died on Sunday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 75 years old.

title: Tokyo Company Sues Bush's Brother for Millions
description: A Japanese company with reputed mob connections accused President Bush's older brother in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday of refusing to honor a $2.5 million guarantee he had given the company as part of a 1989 stock transaction.

title: Adirondacks in Peril
description: A hundred years ago, with extraordinary foresight, New York State's Legislature created one of America's priceless treasures: the Adirondack State Park -- a six-million-acre patchwork of state forests, timber tracts and privately owned land. Now, in its centennial year, it faces twin threats: from developers pushing at the wilderness, and from inattentive legislators.

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a $ 67.8 million charge from the cumulative effect of accounting change and $ 10.5 million restructuring charge. Before the accounting change, there was an operating loss of $ 22.4 million.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Missing Endorsements Leave Clinton Fragile
description: The primaries are over, the convention opens four weeks from today, but three of the Democrats whom Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas defeated on his way to locking up the party's nomination have still not endorsed him and have not decided whether they should do so.

title: Police Bring No Security to South Africa Slum
description: Alfred Mabulana came home from peddling sweaters in this black township and discovered the door of his one-room wooden shack ominously ajar.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Apple Finds a New Arena For Its Fight With Microsoft
description: After four years of battling the Microsoft Corporation and its Windows software in the courts, Apple Computer Inc. took the fight to a new arena last week with an advertising campaign that questions its rival's contention that the software is easy to use.

title: A Summer of Decisions for New York City's Newspapers
description: The summer of 1992 promises to be a watershed for New York City's major daily newspapers, with changes possible that could resolve major uncertainties about the futures of The Daily News and The New York Times and thereby affect the futures The New York Post and New York Newsday as well.

title: Nichols (S.E.) Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Festival's Violent End Prompts Tales of Fear From Belmar Residents
description: Plywood sheets covered the few broken windows in shops along Ocean Avenue today, and crews busily cleaned up the usual post-concert debris as bicyclists, strollers and vacationers returned to the beach front following a two-day music and sports festival that turned violent on Sunday.

title: No Shift at Time Warner Despite Ross Absence
description: Although Steven J. Ross, its chairman and co-chief executive, is out on indefinite leave for further treatment of prostate cancer, Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that no shifts in management or strategy were planned.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Nassau County Limits Sale of Crime Trading Cards
description: David Berkowitz, the "Son of Sam" killer, can no longer show his face here. Al Capone beware. Charles Manson go home.

title: On My Mind; Congress, Yeltsin and Prisoners
description: Boris Yeltsin and the American Congress have an opportunity, immediate and glorious, to turn his visit to the United States into a richness far beyond ceremony and speeches.

title: Italians Are Captains of Their Own Ship
description: Wearing a sleeveless crew T-shirt and matching black gym shorts over a torn, threadbare blue sweatsuit, 33-year-old Giuseppe Abbagnale leans against the doorway of the Circolo Nautico di Stabia boathouse as the dawn light breathes a nascent green into the Bay of Naples.

title: Bankruptcies Rise in Japan
description: Japanese bankruptcies increased in May for the 20th consecutive month, led by defaults in the real estate industry, a private research agency reported today. .

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS A Breeze for Navratilova

title: ROSS COSMETICS PLEDGES COOPERATION WITH INQUIRY
description: Ross Cosmetics Distribution Centers Inc., which distributes imitations of designer-label perfumes, said yesterday that it "intends to cooperate fully" with a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its ownership disclosure and its accounting practices. On Friday, the company said the commission was investigating its failure to disclose that parties related to its primary supplier, S & J Perfume, had direct and indirect ownership of up to 60 percent of its stock.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Washington at Work; When He Works for Perot, and She Backs Bush
description: Only days ago, Edward J. and Sherrie Rollins were the ultimate Republican power couple: He was a well-known strategist and former campaign official. She was a high-ranking White House official.

title: Vincent Indefinitely Delays Steinbrenner Decision
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent deferred indefinitely yesterday his decision on George Steinbrenner's request to return to active duty with the Yankees. By the time his office made that announcement, his representatives had already initiated an investigation into allegations that the owner had communicated with club officials when he was prohibited from talking with them.

title: American Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included gains of $ 650,000 from an incentive contract and $ 24,000 from extinguishment of debt.c-Net loss

title: Business Scene; Figuring Profits The Russian Way
description: CALL on a store or a factory in Russia today and no matter how rundown it looks or how desperate its circumstances, the manager will probably declare that the enterprise is very profitable. By all the rules of Russian accounting, that is the truth. But that is largely because those rules encourage managers to spend their profits on housing, food, day care, holiday retreats and numerous other amenities for workers.

title: Alfin Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Music; American Opera Finds a Home at the Nightclub
description: "Casino Paradise" at the Ballroom on Sunday night took American opera off the stage and put it in the nightclub, where it belongs. Set in the middle of eating and drinking customers, without props and sets, using three performers at three microphones, a piano and a synthesizer, words and music achieved a symbiosis that the usual copies of European tradition never quite do.

title: Knowledge House reports earnings for Year to Feb 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Books of The Times; Soap Operas and Fragments From Daily Life Around London
description: The Real Thing Stories and Sketches By Doris Lessing 214 pages. HarperCollins. $20.

title: Big Debt Agency Seeks Better Odds of a Payoff
description: With credit cards accounting for nearly a quarter of the business at collection agencies, one of the nation's largest collectors of bad debts is evaluating the odds of recovery from deadbeats by using the same techniques that banks use to select and retain credit card customers.

description: b-Net income

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "When you celebrate something in America, you break a window and grab something. When people have an excuse to loot, they loot, when they have an excuse to shoot, they shoot." -- MAYOR RICHARD M. DALEY of Chicago. [ A16:4. ]

title: 33 Win MacArthur Awards, Including 17 Women
description: On the same day that Janet Benshoof opened a center to defend the right of women to obtain safe and legal abortions, she was named a recipient of a fellowship from the MacArthur Foundation of Chicago.

title: Return of an Issue: Protectionism
description: After several months in the background of national debate, trade policy is returning as an issue, as Congress takes up new legislation and as Ross Perot sounds protectionist notes in his semiofficial Presidential candidacy.

description: b-Included tax benefits of $ 36,600, or 1 cent share, in the latest period and $ 955,800, or 32 cents a share, in year-ago period.c-Included a tax benefit of $ 271,000, or 9 cents a share.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said the decrease in earnings was due to a reduction of about $ 300,000 in the royalties and franchise entry fees generated by the cafe-bistro and bar-cafe network.

title: To Our Readers
description: Beginning today, the Nasdaq National List table, on page D16, and the Nasdaq Supplemental table, on page D25, list the actual closing prices of the stocks, rather than the last bid and asked prices. Closing prices were not previously made available by the National Association of Securities Dealers. As a result, the price change column in the tables is blank today, since no information is available on Friday's closing prices.

title: New Testimony Raises Questions at Au Pair Trial
description: A police sergeant's conflicting testimony about a broken window has become a central issue in the trial of a Swiss au pair charged with the arson murder of the baby in her care.

title: Hong Kong Journal; The Walled City, Home to Huddled Masses, Falls
description: The Walled City is a colony within this colony, a dark little enclave of narrow, twisting streets and rickety walk-ups that has defied British law and order for almost 100 years.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New Amsterdam Symphony Symphony Space Manhattan

title: Versus Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Albanian Leader Tells Bush of His Fear of Serbia
description: President Sali Berisha of Albania met with President Bush today and said his country was doing what it could to keep the conflict in neighboring Yugoslavia from spreading.

title: Robert Collins Christopher, 68, An Editor and Pulitzer Secretary
description: Robert Collins Christopher, an author and journalist who administered the day-to-day operations of the Pulitzer Prize Board for the last 11 years, died on Sunday at Lawrence and Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn. He was 68 years old and lived in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: Pond-Making Plants Nurture Riot of Life In Forest Treetops
description: A VISITOR who glances upward into the canopy of a New World tropical rain forest will be struck by the sight of spiny, succulent plants that festoon the tree branches and trunks, making a constellation of star-shaped silhouettes against the sky.

title: New Panel in Chicago to Study Sexual Abuse of Children by Priests
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago said yesterday that he would establish an independent board made up mostly of lay members to investigate accusations of sexual abuse of children by priests in his archdiodese.

description: Year-ago periods' share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in February 1992.

description: b-Included a $ 2,220,000 tax credit.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Devils Trade for Veteran
description: The Hartford Whalers made two trades yesterday. They sent veteran defenseman BRAD SHAW to the Devils in exchange for future considerations, and also traded right wing MARK HUNTER to Washington for left wing NICK KYPREOS.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Bosnia and Herzegovina misidentified Brig. Gen. Lewis MacKenzie. He is a senior officer in the United Nations contingent there, not its chief.

title: Court Backs Old Standard On State Tax
description: In an important corporate tax case, the Supreme Court today reaffirmed its longstanding approach to state taxation of the income of companies that are based outside a state but that conduct some business within the state's borders.

title: Running on Experience: On Welfare, Then Off It
description: If elected to the House of Representatives in November, Lynn Woolsey promises to be Exhibit A for a nation struggling to contain welfare costs, hold absent fathers accountable for the support of their children and ease the passage of single mothers from public assistance to sustaining work.

title: U.S. Reports a Stronger Saddam Hussein
description: Despite stringent economic sanctions and diplomatic isolation, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is stronger now than he was a year ago, according to a classified intelligence report that will be presented to President Bush and his chief aides.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 JAPAN PASSES TROOPS BILL

title: Excalibur Technologies Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

description: b-Net incomeResults are in U.S. dollars and all U.S. dollar figures represented translations using an exchange rate of 2.404 new Israeli shekels to U.S. $ 1.00.

title: Corrections
description: The calendar of events in the Connecticut Weekly on Sunday misstated the opening date of an exhibit on sharks at the Maritime Center in Norwalk. It is June 27, not this Saturday.

title: North Korean Denies Plan for A-Bomb Fuel
description: The North Korean delegate to the United Nations today denied the presence of any plutonium-reprocessing sites in his country and declared that the Government in Pyongyan was committed to a nuclear-free Korean penisula.

title: Basketball Title Brings Chicago Night of Looting
description: When the sun rose over the city's West Side today, Frank Ingram tiptoed through the shards of glass on the floor of his looted pawn shop, his dreams shattered during a night of celebration turned ugly.

title: The Talk of Hollywood; An Ending That's Not Happily Ever After
description: A real-life drama involving high-stakes players and allegations of plagiarism against a television writer was all set to end happily and, above all, quietly the other day, just the way Hollywood prefers when it deals with potential embarrassments.

title: Shirmax Fashions reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEVE ALLEN comes to the city today to hit the talk-show circuit in connection with his new book, "Hi-Ho Steverino! My Adventures in the Wonderful Wacky World of TV," published by Barricade Books.

title: President of Yugoslavia Named; Protest Continues
description: As 15,000 university students added their voices today to mounting protests calling for a change of government, legislators from Serbia and Montenegro, the only remaining republics in the Yugoslav federation, elected a 71-year-old author of best-selling Serbian sagas as President.

title: Homer by Milligan Keeps Orioles Close
description: Orioles 6, Indians 5

title: Courier and Seles No. 1 at Wimbledon
description: The All-England Club kept to the world rankings today, installing Jim Courier and Monica Seles as the top-seeded players for the Wimbledon tennis championships, which begin next Monday.

title: Luby's Cafeterias Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Bulls May Still Be Best In N.B.A. Next Season
description: With the taste of champagne still fresh, Michael Jordan was already being asked the dreaded question on Sunday night.

title: U.N. Agencies Would Find a Welcome Just Across East River
description: To the Editor:

title: Brokerage Firm Fined
description: Paine Webber Inc. and four of its brokers yesterday were fined for violating rules of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

title: Quiet, Calm, Faceless, Simpson Still a Threat
description: With the United States Golf Association's flag flapping above the first tee, the eye unavoidably follows an impossibly narrow ribbon of emerald fairway squeezed between the duller, darker green of dense rough. It's definitely United States Open week at Pebble Beach, which practically guarantees one player in particular will be at his best.

title: HBO SIGNS DISTRIBUTION AGREEMENT WITH SAVOY PICTURES
description: Home Box Office Inc., a unit of Time Warner Inc. signed a four-year agreement yesterday, giving it the American and Canadian home video, pay television and pay-per-view rights to films distributed by Savoy Pictures Entertainment Inc. Savoy is a distribution company formed by the former chief executives of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., Victor A. Kaufman and Lewis J. Korman.

title: Shaker Loses Position at CBS
description: TED SHAKER, the executive producer of CBS Sports since 1986, was removed from his post yesterday and replaced by RICK GENTILE, who will serve in the new position of senior vice president of production. In a division reorganization, the position of executive producer was eliminated.

title: Star Gazers Bewildered By Odd Galaxies
description: LIKE pupils at a show-and-tell class, astronomers brought their latest studies of galaxies to a meeting of the American Astronomical Society here last week, displaying reams of pictures, graphs, equations and speculations. But while the fare was often startling and sometimes spectacular, many galactic enigmas seemed even more impenetrable than before.

title: Critic's Notebook; On Talk-Show Circuit, It's Clinton vs. Perot
description: In the last week, the political talk show has gone upscale, and Bill Clinton and Ross Perot have gone more or less mano a mano, which translates roughly to mouth against mouth. Yesterday, Mr. Clinton answered questions from studio audiences around the country for about an hour of the two hours of "CBS This Morning." (The rest was given to news, weather and advertising.) Last week, he took an hour's worth of telephone calls on NBC's "Today Show," and Mr. Perot took two hours's worth, minus breaks for commercials of course.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: A GRADUATING CLASS MULLS ITS FUTURE

title: Pro-Dolphin Accord Made
description: The United States, Mexico, Venezuela and Vanuatu have agreed to ban the setting of nets around schools of tuna that include dolphins, a compromise that could resolve a festering trade dispute that has led the United States to ban tuna imports from several dozen countries, an Administration official said today.

title: Cuomo Warns of Election Delay
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo urged the State Legislature today to begin revising its legislative redistricting plan immediately, saying this year's elections could be threatened if time is wasted in appealing a recent court decision against the plan.

title: Diet May Play a Role In Menopause Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Let States Set Rules on AIDS-Infected Health Workers
description: AFTER a year of acrimonious debate, the Federal Centers for Disease Control has decided to let state or local health departments decide, on a person-by-person basis, the care that can be provided by health workers infected by the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Two Workers Injured in Building Collapse
description: Two constuction workers were seriously injured yesterday when the rear of a vacant building at 2317 First Avenue, near East 118th Street, collapsed yesterday. One of the workers was trapped under rubble for more than two hours before firefighters could free him.

title: INSIDE
description: Sarajevo's Main Street

title: Mutant Foods Create Risks We Can't Yet Guess; No Evidence of Danger
description: To the Editor:

title: Ephim Fogel, 71, Poet And English Professor
description: Ephim Fogel, a professor of English emeritus at Cornell University and a poet, died on Friday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 71 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Snails as Clocks
description: A scientist has found a fast-ticking chemical clock in the shells of snails that promises to allow researchers to date deposits that are 350 years old and younger, sediments typically too recent for radiocarbon dating.

title: Hallwood Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 451,000, or 8 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt.Year-ago results are restated for a change in accounting principle by Hallwood affiliate, ShowBiz Pizza Time Inc. Originally, for the third quarter ended April 30, 1991, the company posted a loss of $ 73,000, on revenues of $ 23,082,000. For the 9 months in 1991, the company had reported a loss of $ 1,223,000, on revenues of $ 65,520,000.

title: France Rebukes U.S. for Tariff Threat
description: The French Government denounced the United States today in an unusually strong statement, saying Washington had brought trans-Atlantic trade relations close to commercial war.
