description: Braves 4, Dodgers 3

title: YELTSIN CHEERED AT CAPITOL AS HE PLEDGES ERA OF TRUST AND ASKS FOR ACTION ON AID
description: On a day that the United States gave Russia a set of trade incentives to boost its struggling economy, President Boris N. Yeltsin swept through official Washington like a conquering hero today and announced that he was deactivating the most potent nuclear missiles aimed at America.

description: The Cost of Hits

title: Theater in Review
description: The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant 85 East Fourth Street East Village Manhattan By Rainer Werner Fassbinder; translated by Denis Calandra; directed by Brian Jucha; set design, Sarah Edkins; lighting design, Roma Flowers; music direction, Roberto Pace; costumes, Kasia Walicka-Maimone; Presented by Via Theater, Anne Bogart and Mr. Jucha, co-artistic directors. WITH: Sheryl Dold, David Kellett, Tamar Kotoske, Anne McKenna, Tina Shepard, Karla Silverman, Megan Spooner, Reet Roos Varnik and Lisa Welti.

title: Review/Jazz; Aching To Break The Walls Of a Tune
description: About half-way through Billy Harper's first set at Fat Tuesday's on Tuesday night, the tension between Mr. Harper's compositions and the band's improvisation started to build. Mr. Harper, a tenor saxophonist who has been sadly overlooked for the last decade, writes complicated tunes that usually build on some sort of musical motif. Most of them have rhythmic patterns, or a series of musical ideas that are kept constant through the piece. When improvisers get going, and the band is itching to follow them, the pressure to break down the walls of a composition creates real drama.

title: Review/Opera; An Emperor's Concubine in Her Cups
description: At irregular intervals over the last dozen years, New Yorkers stimulated by a visit of the Beijing Opera to the Metropolitan Opera House have had access to further examples of Chinese opera. But they have not been able to explore this colorful genre in any systematic way.

title: HEI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Growing
description: THE winners of the All-America Rose Selections were announced last week at an elegant luncheon at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, but the old roses in the restored Cranford Rose Garden (which has 5,000 bushes blooming or getting ready to bloom) stole the show.

title: CSP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Clinton Promises to Trim 100,000 Jobs
description: Gov. Bill Clinton pledged today to eliminate at least 100,000 Federal employees by attrition in eight years if he is elected President. He said the move would streamline government and make it more responsive.

title: Roberts Named in Civil Suit
description: A Miami man filed a civil suit yesterday against William Roberts of the Giants, seeking damages for a beating he said he received after he was accused by Roberts of stealing the lineman's two Super Bowl rings.

title: Plan for Ice Rink and TV Studio on Chelsea Piers
description: New York State selected a development group yesterday to build ice-skating rinks, film and television studios and a marina on the Chelsea Piers as part of a plan to revitalize Manhattan's decaying Hudson River waterfront.

title: Paul J. Hartman, 81, An Expert on Tax Law
description: Paul J. Hartman, professor emeritus at the Vanderbilt School of Law, died on Monday at the Helen Pate-Bain Health Care Center in Nashville. A resident of Nashville, he was 81 years old.

title: Topics of The Times; Pistol-Whipped
description: The State Legislature's battle over how to arm New York City police officers has ended in a compromise that actually constitutes a partial victory for union bullying.

title: Pathe Computer Control reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Caspen Oil Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net incomeYear-ago 9 months' revenues included a $ 1,716,007 gain on sale of oil and gas properties.

title: Club Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Club Med said that it incurred about $ 6 million in additional costs during the latest 6 months from a new marketing campaign in North America. Prior-year earnings from two equity affiliates, which were recorded this year due to the recent confirmation of ownership rights and other factors, and the adjustment of certain prior-period cost estimates, reduced most of the impact of these additional costs.

title: Galaxy Foods Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains of about $ 2.2 million from replacement value insurance proceeds for building and equipment lost in a plant fire for both the quarter and year.c-Net lossGalaxy Foods said that the $ 2.2 million of gains in the latest fourth quarter and year had been carried on the company's financial statements at their historical cost values.The company also said the lastest year's net income excluded $ 1,335,714 of deferred income which arises as a result of the company's settlement of the business interruption portion of its coverage. The $ 1.34 million of deferred income will be recognized by the company over the next two fiscal quarters.

title: Events: The Inside Story of City Hall
description: Seat of Power The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West at 77th Street; (212) 873-3400.

title: U.S. Army Gets Flexibility on Europe Troop Levels
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has approved a policy change that would give the military the latitude for the first time to plan to reduce its forces in Europe below the 150,000 ceiling set by President Bush, Pentagon officials said today.

title: When Your Beadwork Needs Work
description: PEOPLE have used beads to decorate objects, clothing and themselves for thousands of years. "Beads are compelling," said Lois Sher Dubin, author of "The History of Beads From 30,000 B.C. to the Present" (Abrams, 1987). "They feel good to touch, and your eyes are attracted because light bounces off them."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19 YELTSIN CONQUERS WASHINGTON

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Monday, about advertising for Gucci products, misstated Gucci's ownership. Maurizio Gucci and Investcorp own 50 percent each.

description: Little Joe y la Familia S.O.B.'s 204 Varick Street, at Houston SoHo

title:
Huntsville Journal;
Of Magnolias, Passion and a Murder
description: If it were not for the magnolias in bloom on Whitesburg Drive, a visitor to this northern Alabama city might suspect that he had left the South entirely.

title: Krabbe Is Caugh In a Race to Nowhere
description: You are leafing through a magazine when suddenly your eyes are drawn to a flashy advertisement extolling the virtues of Olympic coins. There in silver-plated, long-legged bas-relief under the inscription, Barcelona, is Katrin Krabbe.

title: Officer Charged With Beating Teen-Agers
description: A New York City police officer was arrested yesterday on charges that he pistol-whipped one teen-ager and punched another because he believed that they threw rocks at his car, forcing him to drive into a fence on the Lower East Side.

title: If Aardvarks Ruin the Plants, Don't Get Tabasco on the Elves
description: FOR a couple of years now, I've been a subscriber to three on-line computer services that link me through a modem to electronic bulletin boards on several topics, including gardening. I occasionally participate, asking or answering a question, but mostly I just eavesdrop on conversations among people who represent a cross section of the gardening world. The level of discourse is often knowing, even sophisticated, and by private electronic mail I've made friends with gardeners across the country.

title: School Board Appointed Six Illegally, Report Says
description: Leaders of a Bronx school district forged documents and "engaged in deliberate misconduct" to push the appointment of six favored principals before newly elected board members took their seats, according to a report released yesterday by school investigators.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Seles Shuns Yugoslav Affiliation
description: MONICA SELES will not play under the Yugoslav flag when she bids for her first Wimbledon title at the championships starting Monday. A Women's Tennis Association spokeswoman, GEORGINA CLARK, said that Seles, the No.1-ranked women's player, who will be top-seeded, would play as Monica Seles of Sarasota, Fla.

title: Philips Sued On Prospects For Earnings
description: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics concern, was named in a class-action lawsuit yesterday, just hours after the company said its 1992 operating profit was unlikely to match the $566 million earned in 1991.

title: Blount Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 6,014,000, or 50 cents a share, which reflected accounting changes.

title: Advanced Micro in Setback
description: In a blow to Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a Federal district court jury ruled today that the company does not have rights to the microcode in the Intel Corporation's 80287 chip. Microcode is software embedded in a processor that controls the execution of basic functions.

title: Worldwide Collections Fund reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,457,662 from an accounting adjustment in the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomeWorldwide Collections said that it changed its accounting policies beginning with the latest quarter. The fund's finance income before the latest quarter was comprised of interest income and discounts on finance receivable purchased at less than face value.Worldwide said the new accounting policy will record earnings on all currently owned consumer finance receivables on the collection basis only.

title: U.S. Oil Output At 30-Year Low
description: United States crude oil production in May hit the lowest level in more than 30 years, the American Petroleum Institute said today.

title: Sprinter Not Swayed By Schedule Change
description: Two days before the start of the United States Olympic track and field trials here, one American 400-meter runner, Michael Johnson, was told the Olympic time schedule had been changed to help him, and another, Butch Reynolds, was told he must wait until Friday.

title: Drought Unites South Africa and Neighbors
description: Past withered cornfields and sun-cracked river beds, freight trains packed with grain have been rolling across the parched farmland of the Transvaal, carrying relief to South Africa's once hostile northern neighbors.

title: Medicaid Warning Ignites New Trenton Fiscal Crisis
description: Less than a day before the Republican legislative majority was to unveil a budget $1 billion smaller than the one suggested by the Governor, the fiscal planning process was thrown into yet another crisis today by a letter from the State Treasurer warning the Republicans not to count on $450 million in Federal Medicaid reimbursements.

title: Adobe Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Mishap Over Bond Payment
description: A day's delay in repaying a debt can be irritating, but when the debt involves hundreds of millions of dollars, it becomes a matter of grave concern that can upset investors' plans to buy other securities and even result in financial loss.

title: NMR of America reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 349,000, or 8 cents a share, in the latest period and $ 489,000, or 13 cents a share, in year-ago period, both from tax-loss carryforwards.

description: * Red Lobster, Minneapolis, to Saatchi & Saatchi, New York for network and syndication television buying. The account, estimated at $55 million, was previously handled by Grey Advertising, New York.

description: b-Net loss

title: Knicks Go Shopping for Veteran Guard
description: David Checketts and Ernie Grunfeld have a list of four shooting guards they would like to acquire for the Knicks. Consider it an early Christmas list, but remember that there is no major gift-giving holiday during the summer.

title: Miscellany
description: * Greenstone Roberts Advertising, Melville, L.I., reported that net income for its second fiscal quarter rose 45.6 percent, to $331,048, from $227,326 in the comparable 1991 period. Revenues for the period, which ended on April 30, totaled $3.2 million, up 33 percent from $2.4 million.

title: 2 Wrights Equal an Ellington
description: WHILE most people think they need more money, Richard Haas, an artist known for his illusionistic murals, thinks they need more currency. He has designed four new bills, including $25 and $200 denominations. They will "fill in important monetary gaps owing to inflation," Mr. Haas said. All four feature prominent American cultural figures instead of statesmen. The fronts are in various colors, but green is still the dominant shade on the backs. Mr. Haas's banknotes were commissioned by Martin Filler, editor of Design Quarterly, the journal of Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, for the summer issue.

title: Outlook Graphics Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Howe? They're Still Talking
description: Discussions between union and management officials trying to resolve a dispute over the suspension of Yankees pitcher Steve Howe are expected to resume today. "We spoke to the union today, but there's nothing new to report at this point," Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner, said late yesterday afternoon.

title: New Jersey Budget Cuts Imperil Latino Centers
description: To the Editor:

title: Agreement on Casting of 'Will Rogers'
description: The Actors' Equity Association signed an agreement yesterday with the producers of "The Will Rogers Follies" in a dispute over minority casting in the production, which was last season's Tony Award-winning musical.

title: Books of The Times; After TV, What? An Eden of Art and Individualism?
description: Life After Television By George Gilder 126 pages. W. W. Norton. $14.95.

title: Dewey Balfa, Folk Fiddler, Is Dead at 65
description: Dewey Balfa, a fiddler and singer who helped create the Cajun music revival and became one of America's leading traditional musicians, died on Wednesday at Moosa Memorial Hospital in Eunice, La. He was 65 years old and lived in Basile, La.

title: Raphael Totah; Executive, 81
description: Raphael Totah, a retired international rice trader and former executive of the Continental Grain Company in New York, died on Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan and Southampton, L.I.

title: After New Testing, Parents Worry About Levels of Lead at School
description: With a private laboratory test having shown dangerous levels of lead at a century-old elementary school in Greenwich Village, parents at the school are anxiously awaiting the results of tests ordered by the Schools Chancellor to determine if their children have been exposed to poisonous levels.

title: Mexicans Mollified Over Drug Ruling
description: Mexico and the United States backed away from a diplomatic confrontation today when Mexican officials said they had received assurances from Washington that there would be no more kidnappings of criminal suspects from their territory.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Reason begins to triumph over madness. We have left behind the period when America and Russia looked at each other through gunsights, ready to pull the trigger at any time." -- PRESIDENT BORIS N. YELTSIN. [ A18:4. ]

title: YELTSIN DESCRIBES A LIST OF MISSING
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin today bolstered his assertion that American prisoners of war were transferred to the Soviet Union from Vietnam, saying Russia had a list of names under investigation that included United States servicemen captured in Indochina.

title: 2 Charged With Making Up Traffic Tickets
description: A New York City traffic-enforcement agent and a man who resigned as an agent last year were arrested yesterday and charged with fabricating traffic tickets, in a ruse to cover up times when they should have been working but were not, officials said.

title: Shaping a New Agenda
description: Although the biggest news out of this week's summit meeting was the agreement to sharply reduce American and Russian nuclear arsenals, the centerpiece turned out to be economic relations between the two former rivals.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 3.7 million, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of real estate investments.

title: Review/Opera; 'Boheme' Greets Summer in the Park With Clear Skies and 70,000 Fans
description: With 25 seasons down and a new one just begun, the Metropolitan Opera's series of free park concerts must surely qualify as an entrenched summertime tradition. And if the opening of the 26th season on Tuesday evening jumped the gun on summer by five days, who could complain? After several years in which the company's offerings have been rained upon regularly, this year's opening had the benefit of a cool, dry, cloudless night.

title: 'What? Me Marry?' Widows Say No
description: AS a growing number of people opt for customized family arrangements and life styles, single motherhood being the most publicized of late, another nontraditional pattern is being observed. An increasing number of middle-aged and older widows are choosing not to remarry.

title: Irish Voters Ask, Are We to Be Truly European?
description: For the first time since Ireland became independent 70 years ago, there is a sense, on the eve of a referendum on the Treaty on European Union, that this country is about to make a decision affecting not only its own destiny but also Europe's.

title: James H. Traynor, 55; Owned Car Dealership
description: James H. Traynor, an automotive consultant and former owner of the Traynor Motors car dealership in Fairfield, Conn., died on Monday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 55 years old.

title: Bridge
description: Very few players can claim to have attended a regional championship, played in three events and won them all. Albert Rahmey of Brooklyn joined this select club in April by winning two regional pair titles and one regional Swiss team title at the Southeastern Championships in Miami Beach.

title: Graduating From a High School To Go On to Be an Arts Center
description: "We went through five chancellors, three cultural commissioners and two Mayors to make this dream come true," Linda LeRoy Janklow said yesterday about her group's nine-year effort to turn the once crumbling, fire-gutted former High School of the Performing Arts at 120 West 46th Street into a school-and arts-center for public-school pupils. The legendary 99-year-old building near Times Square, the inspiration for "Fame," both the movie and the television series about the High School of Performing Arts, was vacated by the school in 1984 and abandoned entirely by the Board of Education after a 1988 fire.

title: Transnational Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 415,000, or 16 cents a share, on the settlement of the company's judgment with the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corp., and an extraordinary credit of $ 228,000, or 8 cents a share, from tax-loss carryforward.c-Net loss and included a loss of $ 262,000 from discontinued operations.Share earnings are after payment of preferred dividends.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Can it be that PAUL McCARTNEY is turning 50? The composer and former Beatle celebrates his half-century birthday today.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Labor; Union Leaders Seek to Keep Auto Workers From the Arms of Perot
description: Already buffeted by weaknesses in the auto industry, layoffs at aerospace plants and setbacks in Washington, the United Automobile Workers Union now has a political headache: an independent Presidential candidate enticing its members to break ranks with the union's endorsed candidate.

title: Yeltsin Speaks, and Congressional Wall Tumbles
description: With oratory that thrilled even Congressional critics of aid, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia appeared today to have virtually eliminated an important obstacle to passage of an aid program for the former Soviet republics.

title: 2 German Hostages Are Freed in Beirut and Fly Home
description: The last two Westerners known to have been held hostage by Lebanese militant groups, two German aid workers, were flown home today by their Government, which said their freedom was "a victory of justice over injustice" and not the result of any deal.

title: Frederick E. Exley, 63, Author Who Told of His Own Troubles
description: Frederick E. Exley, whose trilogy of books about his troubled life won critical praise, died yesterday at the Edward John Noble Hospital in Alexandria Bay, N.Y. He was 63 years old and lived in Alexandria Bay, in the Thousand Islands region.

title: Biodynamics International reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included tax-loss carryforwards of $ 80,373 and $ 118,665 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Included tax-loss carryforwards of $ 32,570 for the quarter and $ 53,846 for the 6 months.

title: Sea Gull? There's No Such Bird as That; Takeoff Incident in '75
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF: Sports of The Times; Will Anybody See Couples at the Open?
description: EVER since Fred Couples was last seen wearing his Masters green jacket, it's as if he were a golf ball lost in the trees.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Shady Challenge

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture on Saturday about the Olympic gymnastic trials referred incorrectly in some editions to the gymnast shown. She was Shannon Miller, not Kim Zmeskal.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; QUAYLE MAKES JOB EASIER FOR COMEDIANS
description: It didn't take long for jokes about Vice President Dan Quayle and his misspelling of "potato" at a spelling bee in Trenton to make late-night television.

title: Steinbrenner Wasn't Set Up
description: THE word of the week is "squirm," as in Commissioner Fay Vincent is making George Steinbrenner squirm. It's all over television and radio, and it's in the newspapers: Fay Vincent is making George Steinbrenner squirm.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY MARKING GRADUATION AND SURVIVAL

title: Saatchi Sells Yankelovich
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., the London-based communications giant, has sold its American public opinion and market research firm, Yankelovich Skelly White/Clancy Shulman Inc., to a group of investors led by Wand Partners Inc.

title: Cooper Development Co. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Cooper Development said that, subsequent to the close of the second quarter, it acquired Cooper Cosmetics SA, a Swiss company, in exchange for the cancellation of a promissory note in the principal amount of $ 500,000 and the assumption of certain other liabilities relating to the business. The company said Cooper Cosmetics will be consolidated with its Cabot skin care subsidiary.

title: Eilabun Journal; Israel Is Listening as the Arab Voter Is Serenaded
description: A heavy downpour, rare during the parched Israeli summer, lashed the hillside homes of this Galilee village as Defense Minister Moshe Arens arrived to drum up Arab support for the governing Likud Party in national elections next week.

title: Tokyo Stock Market Falls to Its Lowest Level Since 1986
description: Japanese stock prices fell sharply again today, following a steep selloff on Wednesday that pushed the Tokyo stock market down to its lowest levels since late 1986.

title: Trial With Link to D'Amato Begins in San Juan
description: Testimony began today in the trial of a Puerto Rican advertising executive charged with arranging illegal campaign contributions to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in an effort to win Federal housing grants for projects in San Juan.

title: Lamonts Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Thermwood Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Penwest Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Reflected accounting changes which resulted in an after-tax charge of about $ 6 million. The charge is partially offset by a $ 1.6 million credit for adopting another accounting change.The latest third quarter's share earnings included a 2 cents a share charge for two accounting changes.

title: City's Survivors, With a Diploma to Prove It
description: Falasha Spruiell and Charisse Lenoir wearily circled the graffiti-covered high school track, sweating and breathing heavily. The track season was winding down, like high school itself. Only the championships remained -- and graduation.

title: Sea of Suspicion Laps Closer to Brazil's Leader
description: With the glamour of the Earth Summit fading rapidly, President Fernando Collor de Mello now faces a corruption scandal viewed as the most serious political crisis of his two-year-old Government.

title: Vertex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 18,704, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 56,475, or 3 cents a share, in the 9 months, both from tax-loss carryforwards.c-Net loss

title: Russia Is Given Most-Favored Status
description: President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin flung open the door today to increased trade and investment, signing a package of commercial agreements that brush aside barricades put up during the cold war to block commerce between the United States and Russia.

title: Mickelson Springs Surprises
description: Phil Mickelson, who earlier this month captured a third National Collegiate Athletic Association title, is a professional at last.

title: I Came. I Saw. I Bathed.
description: IN the second century A.D., Romans were very clean. As Fikret Yegul, an architectural historian, writes in a new book, "Baths and Bathing in Classical Antiquity" (Architectural History Foundation and M.I.T. Press, $65), the Romans used 300 gallons of water per person a day in that era; New York City's daily per-capita consumption in 1990 was a spartan 192 gallons.

title: Kidnap? Sure, Says the Court
description: The Supreme Court's astonishing Mexican extradition decision upholds national power at the expense of national honor. The United States, says the Court, may kidnap foreigners in their own countries and, over their countries' protest, drag them here for a criminal trial.

title: THAI COMMANDERS BACK CRACKDOWN
description: Thailand's two most senior military commanders have insisted that the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last month, in which scores of civilians were gunned down by Thai soldiers, was the only appropriate response to the public uprising.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: She's Still Going Strong

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's not the kind of material that legislators are likely to use in re-election campaigns, but a number of Congressmen have acquired new titles, thanks to Washingtonian magazine's "Best and Worst" issue, which will be on newstands on Monday.

title: Woman and 2 Girls Are Found Slain; 2 Suspects Charged
description: A mother, her 12-year-old daughter and a 12-year-old neighbor were found stabbed to death in their apartment in Brooklyn yesterday morning, the police said. Late last night, the woman's 18 year-old son and his 17-year-old friend were arrested and charged in the killing, which the police said was sparked by a family dispute.

title: Dell's Stock Slides 25%
description: Despite optimistic forecasts from Michael H. Dell, chief executive of the Dell Computer Corporation, investors pounded the company's stock today. The stock plummeted 25 percent, to $15.75, after analysts cut estimates for the mail-order personal computer concern. It was the second pounding in a week taken by a Texas player in the global PC market. Monday, despite the hoopla surrounding the official start of its Prolinea and Contura line of inexpensive PC's in New York, the Compaq Computer Corporation's stock was hurt, too.

title: Alarm Goes Off as Mets Plunge Toward Cellar
description: The Mets' season is ominously close to becoming as empty as Shea Stadium has been of late. The team is bankrupt of offense, depleted of pitching and devoid of energy or imagination.

title: Chrysler Retirements
description: The Chrysler Corporation said two vice presidents who joined the company in 1984 would take early retirement on Dec. 31. Richard Acosta, 60 years old, will step down as head of car- and truck-assembly operations, while Erick Reickert, 56, will leave as head of engine, transmission and chassis plants, the auto maker said.

title: A Dispute Where Art Pays the Rent; As Loft Law Nears Expiration, Landlords and Tenants Battle
description: Bragging about real-estate deals is to most New Yorkers what brandishing a fistful of wild animal pelts once was to the pioneers. It shows an ability to triumph over adversity and can humble the most bitter of rivals.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Supercollider Contractors Criticize Vote to Halt Work
description: Halting work on the supercollider in Texas would have little near-term economic impact on the leading suppliers of components to the project, but the country could pay dearly in the long run, industry executives say.

title: Litton Wins Court Round In Itek Case
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan reinstated a suit by Litton Industries against Shearson Lehman Hutton yesterday based on the insider-trading scandals of the 1980's.

title: M'DONALD'S TO EXPAND TESTING OF INDOOR PLAYGROUNDS
description: The McDonald's Corporation will expand testing of its Leaps and Bounds indoor playgrounds by opening 15 more in the next year. The company plans to open its second Leaps and Bounds in Westmont, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, next month. McDonald's opened the first one last year in Naperville, Ill. The play centers, which feature tunnels, slides and mazes, charge $4.95 a child. Food is sold at Leaps and Bounds, but it is not McDonald's fare.

title: Holyfield-Holmes: Match of 2 Bumps on a Log?
description: Just days before tonight's Evander Holyfield-Larry Holmes heavyweight championship fight on TVKO, pay-per-view orders were not storming cable TV systems as if they were coaxial Bastilles.

title: Bucking Traditions in Trenton: G.O.P. Budget
description: No government document is more political than a budget, and the one unveiled by the omnipotent new Republican legislative majority in Trenton today represents a stark repudiation of nearly two decades of moderate to liberal government under both Democratic and Republican administrations.

title: After the Cold War: Views From Vietnam; Vietnam, Now Master of Its Own House, Tries to Mend Neighborhood Fences
description: For the first time since French gunboats laid waste to the port of Da Nang in 1858 and began the colonization of what became French Indochina, Vietnam is free of domination by distant powers. But the post-cold-war task of emerging from the umbrella of the old Soviet Union and finding a new place in the rapidly developing region of Southeast Asia is daunting.

title: Review/Architecture; A Master of Masses, Last in a Long Line
description: LOUIS I. KAHN believed that architecture "shouldn't just exist for itself; it should throw out sparks to others." Wear something flameproof to the Museum of Modern Art this summer. Better yet, just let the mind catch fire. The museum's new Kahn retrospective sends out more sparks than any architecture show in recent years.

title: Caspar Weinberger's Handwriting
description: Responsibility for the reverberating Iran-contra scandal still needs sorting out five years later. Now comes the indictment of Caspar Weinberger, the former Secretary of Defense, who was one of the saner figures in the controversy. He was also, according to the independent counsel, Lawrence Walsh, part of a criminal cover-up.

title: The Airline That Roared: Cayman Battles American
description: Cayman Airways, the flag carrier of the Cayman Islands, started a war of words yesterday against American Airlines, whose 97,000 employees are almost four times the total population of the tiny British colony in the Caribbean. At issue is American's recent addition of a second daily flight between Miami and the islands.

title: St.-Tropez Journal; On the Riviera, Naughty Town Feels a Firm Hand
description: Tired of hibernating under North European skies, the tourists are back in town to celebrate the summer, squeezing their yachts into port, camping among the vineyards, and, come nightfall, swirling their bronzed torsos on motorbikes through the scent of pizza and french fries.

title: Juror Is Dismissed From N.F.L. Antitrust Suit
description: One of the nine jurors in the the National Football League antitrust trial here was dismissed today after it was reported that she had told the judge and the two attorneys in the case on Wednesday that she was concerned about being able to render a fair verdict.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 595 money market mutual funds increased by $730.2 million, to $497.11 billion, in the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 219 institutional funds increased by $1.96 billion, to $184.33 billion. The assets of the 283 general-purpose funds fell by $1.23 billion, to $172.74 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds increased by $2.7 million, to $140.05 billion, the institute said.

title: Valvano Is Ill With Cancer
description: Jim Valvano, the former basketball coach at North Carolina State and Iona who is now a television commentator, is ill with cancer, according to ESPN and his agent.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALLEGHANY CORPORATION, New York, appointed John J. Burns Jr. chief executive, succeeding F. M. Kirby, who remains chairman. AMERICAN EXPRESS COMPANY, New York, named Bernard Hamilton senior vice president and general auditor, succeeding William Warrick who resigned.

title: Victim's Aunt Seeks Ouster Of 6 Officers
description: The aunt of a Newark teen-ager who was wounded after emerging from a stolen car here June 9 appealed today for the dismissal of six police officers who were suspended after the incident, arguing that they tried to cover up their involvement. At the same time, leaders of the local police union called for the reinstatement of the six, contending that they had committed no crimes.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BORDEN INC., New York, sold its Crecspan snacks business in Spain to Unichips Finanziaria S.p.A., Barcelona, for undisclosed terms. BSD BANCORP INC., San Diego, said it would incur a significant loss during the second quarter because of restructuring costs associated with the merger of its El Cajon-based American Valley Bank and Long Beach-based Coast Bank into The Bank of San Diego.

title: Inkling of Future: Astros Sign Nevin
description: PHIL NEVIN, the No. 1 pick in baseball's amateur draft, took a lucrative break from working out with the United States Olympic team yesterday to sign a contract with the Houston Astros.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Velocity Girl's Love-Hate

title: Jerry Della Femina Likely To Leave His Ad Agency
description: Ending more than a year of feuding, Jerry Della Femina has apparently reached an agreement to have his contract bought out by Euro RSCG, the French parent of Della Femina McNamee Inc. At a news conference scheduled for today in New York, Mr. Della Femina is expected to announce that he is leaving the advertising agency.

title: From the Annals of Long-Lasting Bulbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Allen, Concert Entertainer And Songwriter, Is Dead at 48
description: Peter Allen, the popular concert entertainer and Grammy- and Academy Award-winning songwriter, died yesterday at a hospital in San Diego. He was 48 years old, and lived in Manhattan and had homes near San Diego and in Australia.

title: Art in Review
description: Lisa Beck and Peter Dudek Stephanie Theodore Gallery 580 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Ol' Khrushchev Trail Leads Yeltsin to Kansas
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia was beaming today when he met Dmitri Antoniadi, a fellow Russian and a student at a university in this city on the Kansas plains.

title: Dropping Heavy Weights
description: THE POLLS close tonight on the race for the toughest job in the world. And none too soon. It has been a noisy, lumpy, mud-slinging campaign. The incumbent has been struggling for respect against charges that he isn't really a heavyweight. The challenger, knocked as a rich guy who shouldn't even be here, has tried to circumvent the media and go straight to the people.

title: Fed Will Push Inflation Fight
description: The Federal Reserve Board intends to continue squeezing inflation down, a Fed governor said today.

title: A Supermarket Of Sounds
description: THIS weekend Manhattan turns into a music supermarket. Its streets and avenues, clubs and stages will overflow with bands of every size, shape, model and flavor: garage bands, rap bands, folk bands and country bands. There are industrial beats, avant-garde structures, noisy guitars and quiet voices; bands made up of 20-year-olds, 70-year-olds, natives and visitors. They come from New York, Los Angeles, Memphis, Jamaica, Japan, Finland, New Zealand and hundreds of other places on the map. The musical consumer can have a field day shopping for sounds this weekend. The full range of sonic possibilities is encased under Manhattan's roof.

title: No Leads on G.I.'s
description: Russians are puzzling over assertions by President Yeltsin that some American prisoners were moved from Vietnam to the Soviet Union. Archivists say the only Vietnam War-era servicemen who passed through Soviet territory were defectors, and they were released.

title: Howe Case Nears Solution
description: Steve Howe could learn just what definite sanctions baseball has in store for him as early as next week, after management and union officials yesterday agreed upon an interim solution to a grievance that was pending on behalf of the suspended Yankee pitcher.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once again, world politics intrudes into athletics. MONICA SELES, the top-ranked women's tennis player, will be listed as hailing from Sarasota, Fla., rather than her native Yugoslavia, when she competes in the Wimbledon championships in England, a tennis official announced in London yesterday.

title: SOCIALIST CHOSEN FOR HELM IN ITALY
description: After 10 weeks of political wrangling and spreading financial scandal, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro asked the deputy leader of the Socialist Party today to try to form a majority coalition in Parliament.

title: Freed in Lebanon, Without Dishonor
description: With the release this week of two German captives, all the surviving Western hostages in Lebanon are now free. A sordid game seems to have ended without dishonor to the West. But Americans and Europeans now have to show that their concern extends to other victims of persecution in Lebanon and Iran.

title: A.T.& T. TO REDUCE SOME DISCOUNTS AND OPERATOR FEES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it would reduce fees for some operator services and eliminate some calling-card discount plans, effective June 30. A.T.& T. said the rate changes, filed with the Federal Communications Commission, would lower operator-service charges by an average of 4 percent and reduce the company's revenue by about $60 million annually.

title: Ashland Oil Expecting Drop in 3d-Quarter Net
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said today that it expects fiscal third-quarter earnings would drop from the period a year earlier because of weak profit margins in refinery operations and rising costs related to environmental matters.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; CLINTON DISAVOWS IDEA OF MIDDLE-CLASS TAX CUT
description: Remember the middle-class tax cut? An early and central feature of Gov. Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign, the idea seems on its way to dying an inconspicuous death.

title:
Derelict-Hotel Project;
Group Restoring River Town's Eyesore
description: For a decade, residents of this bustling riverfront town have fretted over a 90-room former hotel that has stood vacant and derelict on Fair Street in the midst of the main business district. Kingston, with a population of 23,000, is the seat of Ulster County.

title: Mycogen Names Head Of Anti-Parasite Unit
description: The Mycogen Corporation has named Charles J. Dumbrell, a 52-year-old former executive at the American Cyanamid Corporation, to head a new subsidiary that will use genetically engineered bacteria to try to attack parasites in livestock.

title: Foreign Affairs; Israel's Military Superiority
description: Israel is more secure today than ever in its brief and turbulent history.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Americans Advance Mary Joe Fernandez led an all-American advance yesterday into the semifinals of the Eastbourne grass-court tournament in England. Fernandez, seeded second, beat No. 7 Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-3, 6-4, and will face Lori McNeil in the semifinals. It was Fernandez's second victory over Sukova in the last two weeks. McNeil, seeded 11th, survived a match of 21 service breaks to edge No. 6 Nathalie Tauziat of France, 7-6 (7-2), 6-7 (4-7), 7-5. Linda Harvey-Wild, who upset Martina Navratilova in the second round, will play a South African-born Californian, Rosalyn Fairbank-Nideffer, in the other semifinal. Harvey-Wild, a 21-year-old from Hawthorn Woods, Ill., defeated Rennae Stubbs of Australia, 6-1, 6-1, in just 65 minutes. Fairbank-Nideffer upset No. 4 Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, 6-1, 6-3. (AP)

title: 39 IN SOUTH AFRICA DIE IN A MASSACRE
description: Mobs of armed attackers shot and hacked their way through this black township and an adjoining squatter camp on Wednesday night, leaving at least 39 people dead and delivering a jolt to negotiations on South Africa's political future.

title: DOW CORNING TO TAKE $45 MILLION PRETAX CHARGE
description: The Dow Corning Corporation will take a pretax charge of $45 million against second-quarter income for costs related to its decision in January to stop making silicone-gel breast implants. The charges reflect costs anticipated for continuing research on the implants, relations with patients and the medical community and retrieval of implant inventories, the company said in a statement. The charge also includes the projected cost of Dow Corning's legal expenses associated with the controversial devices.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TOMORROW

title: Child Sex Abuse Cases Can Be Witch Hunts
description: To the Editor:

title: Magic's Scott Undergoes Arthroscopy
description: Orlando Magic forward DENNIS SCOTT underwent an arthroscopic procedure on his right knee yesterday after injuring the joint during rehabilitation of a tendon in the leg.

title: Waiting For Lefty? Wait No Longer
description: When Phil Mickelson's 30-foot birdie putt clunked into the cup on the 12th green at Pebble Beach today in the opening round of the United States Open, a voice in the gallery yelled, "Go, Lefty."

title: Michael Secures A New Attorney
description: One day after his meeting with the commissioner was called off because of a flap over lawyers, General Manager Gene Michael of the Yankees secured the New York-based William Robinson as his new lawyer today and will now meet with Commissioner Fay Vincent on Monday in New York City.

title: Article 961092 -- No Title
description: It's a verifiable equation: when a Government falls anywhere in the world, restaurants rise in the United States. Let's face it, political change rarely cures poverty or resolves antipathies, but it almost always benefits American diners.

title: NORTHWEST AIR TO ADD 26 DEPARTURES FROM TWIN CITIES
description: Northwest Airlines will add 26 departure flights from its Minneapolis-St. Paul hub this fall. The airline is adding Buffalo to the cities it serves from Minneapolis-St. Paul and will add one flight a day to its service to 23 other cities. Service to Sioux Falls, S.D., will increase by two flights to six a day. The expansion follows a systemwide review of routes, which was completed this spring and resulted in plans to increase daily departures from the airline's home port to 297, compared with 253 daily flights last fall.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Financing; Lagging in the Polls, Clinton Also Faces a Cash Shortage
description: As Ross Perot has catapulted to the top of the polls and Gov. Bill Clinton has fallen into third place, the Arkansas Governor's fund raising has also lagged, drawing his campaign so deep into debt that he has been unable to pay hundreds of campaign employees on time.

title: The Art Market
description: George Segal Sculpture

title: Fraud Charges Considered By U.S. Against Grumman
description: The United States Attorney's Office in Brooklyn is weighing criminal action against the Grumman Corporation, one of the nation's biggest military contractors, and its former chairman, John O'Brien, charging that the company defrauded the Navy in a series of 1980's contracts, lawyers involved in the inquiry said.

title: Broadway Should Put Some of the Profits Into Its Restrooms
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Camp Badly in Debt
description: Hurt by Ross Perot's popularity, the Clinton campaign is so financially weakened that hundreds of workers have not been paid on time. Page A24.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Justices Affirm Law in California Restricting Property Tax Increases
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of California's Proposition 13, a property tax system based on the date of purchase that has pitted new neighbor against old and created startling differences in tax bills for nearly identical houses.

title: White House Is Refusing to Allow Testimony by Aides on Iraq Policy
description: Confronting Congress over its investigation of Administration policy toward Iraq before the Persian Gulf war, the White House has rejected a request to allow two Presidential aides to testify before the House Judiciary Committee.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate; Perot Makes Plea for Racial Harmony
description: At an outdoor rally before an overwhelmingly white crowd in conservative Orange County, Ross Perot today made his most explicit plea for racial harmony since he first began flirting with the idea of running for President.

title: Schmidt's Degree
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Gambling on Athletes Is Not Allowed Here
description: THE horse does not understand why the people are shouting. The jockey, on the other hand, knows exactly why the people are yelling such unceremonious things in many different languages and dialects. The jockey has been judged responsible by these people for the money they lose, and they are not amused.

title: Review/Art; Humble Jars and Bowls Valued More Than Gold
description: Korean ceramic work was described by an astonished 12th-century Chinese visitor as having "the radiance of jade and the clarity of water," and from early times Chinese and Japanese collectors are said to have valued it above gold.

title: Appointment At Times Co.
description: Elise J. Ross was appointed a corporate vice president by The New York Times Company yesterday.

title: Blueprint for Justice in Massachusetts
description: Three hundred years after Massachusetts Bay colonists created the first appellate system in the Western Hemisphere here, a court-appointed commission has issued a blueprint for making the state's judicial system more accommodating to an increasingly diverse population.

title: CONGRESS PASSES BILL TO AID CITIES
description: The House and Senate today passed a compromise $1.3 billion urban aid bill amid indications that White House and Congressional negotiators were narrowing differences on other measures to increase private investment and law-enforcement in inner cities.

title: Pop/Jazz; JVC Inspires Competition But Not With Its Classics
description: Every year when the JVC Jazz Festival rolls into Manhattan, many music aficionados complain and imagine that they could do better. There has been a tradition of what have been called rump festivals, alternative shows, ever since 1960, when Charles Mingus, Max Roach and Allen Eager pulled away at Newport and started their own jazz festival. This year's JVC Festival has brought forth two other festivals, and combined with the JVC behemoth opening today, they offer an extraordinary bounty. And that's not counting the exceptional jazz-and-dance film festival beginning today at Film Forum. One could easily go broke and deaf, and not sleep for the next week or so.

title: INSIDE
description: Maxwell's Sons and Adviser Arrested on Theft Charges

title: Critic's Choice/Music; Medieval to Modern: A Church Choir With a Difference
description: Corpus Christi Church, a Roman Catholic church at 529 West 121st Street in Morningside Heights, Manhattan, has long had an ambitious music program, both within the context of its services and as a presenter of ensembles. The centerpiece is its first-rate choir, which can be heard 52 weeks a year at Mass and occasionally in the church's Sunday afternoon concerts. The eight-voice choir's specialties are 16th- and 17th-century music and Gregorian chant.

title: Review/Opera; Tania, Cinque and the Super Bowl
description: How can an opera possibly make the 1974 kidnapping of Patricia Hearst believable? An heiress to a great fortune is abducted by a group calling itself the Symbionese Liberation Army; the ransom demands include the release of terrorist prisoners along with the donation of food to the needy. Then Patty Hearst is seen on videotape, robbing a bank, dressed to kill. She has adopted a new name -- Tania -- and a new role: revolutionary.

title: The Rev. Daniel J. O'Hanlon, 73; Jesuit Theologian and Ecumenist
description: The Rev. Daniel J. O'Hanlon, a Jesuit priest who was a nationally known theologian and ecumenical leader, died on Wednesday at Highland Hospital in Oakland, Calif. He was 73 years old and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Jackson Sees a 'Character Flaw' In Clinton's Remarks on Racism
description: Escalating his conflict with Gov. Bill Clinton, the Rev. Jesse Jackson charged today that in a clumsy bid for the backing of alienated white voters the presumptive Democratic nominee had "again exposed a character flaw."

title: The Spoken Word
description: SYMPOSIUM, Kenkeleba Gallery, 214 East Second Street, Manhattan. "Bannister's World: 19th-Century African-American Art and Culture," a symposium that is to cover photography, art and the work of Edward Mitchell Bannister, a 19th-century black painter. Sunday, from 2 to 6 P.M. Admission: $7 in advance, $10 at the door. Information: (212) 674-3939.

title: New Definition of AIDS Postponed Again
description: Federal health officials said yesterday that they would not meet a July 1 deadline for changing the definition of AIDS, which they said had been indefinitely delayed.

title: Tyson Is Out of an Isolation Cell
description: MIKE TYSON was released from an isolation cell yesterday, hours before the broadcast of a television interview in which he criticized guards and fellow inmates at the Indiana Youth Center in Plainfield, Ind.

title: Bush Plans to Lower Fees Charged To Foreigners for Military Goods
description: In a move to support military contractors at a time of shrinking budgets in the post-cold war era, the Bush Administration has decided to lower fees the Pentagon charges foreigners for some products.

title: Yet Another Bid Emerges For U.P.I.
description: A British media company controlled by Saudi Arabian investors offered a no-strings-attached cash bid of $3.5 million today for United Press International, the failing news agency.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Widened to $6.97 Billion in April
description: The long-predicted plunge in American exports to the slowing economies of Japan and Western Europe finally took place in April, and the trade deficit widened to $6.97 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A Sincere Bat, a Sexy Cat and a Bad Bird
description: "BATMAN" was an exceptionally hard act to follow, and that's no compliment. It says less about the first film's dark ingenuity than about its sour, cynical spirit and its taste for smirking sadism, qualities that dimmed the urgency for a return visit to Gotham City and its trouble-plagued citizenry. Yet the status of "Batman" as one of Hollywood's biggest commercial triumphs only compounded the sequel problem, creating pressure to re-activate this money machine at any cost. The prospect of a new "Batman" installment  "Batman Returns" opens today at more than 2,600 theaters nationwide  has thus been more inevitable than welcome.

title: Searching for America's 'Big Money'
description: The casino buses arrive every two hours from 9 A.M. until 11 P.M. at the Confucius Statue on the Bowery in Chinatown. Men and women in tattered coats and worn sneakers scurry out of bakeries and snack shops, jostling to get on the bus. After a week of hard work, they are off to risk their week's pay at the blackjack and baccarat tables of Atlantic City.

title: Seeking the Perfect Father's Day
description: THIS is that one weekend of the year when so many fathers get all foot-shuffling uncomfortable, their children, prompted by so many mothers, fussing over them. The youngsters deliver cold drinks the dads didn't know they needed, hand them newspapers they've already read and hold up crayoned portraits labeled My Dad just as the big play happens in the game on television. Thank you, instant replay.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Be it at the hands of the state or the defense, if a court allows jurors to be excluded because of group bias, it is a willing participant in a scheme that could only undermine the very foundation of our system of justice -- our citizens' confidence in it." -- JUSTICE HARRY A. BLACKMUN. [ A1:5. ]

title: U.N. Chief Asks for Armed Force To Serve as a Permanent Deterrent
description: The United Nations Secretary General tonight asked member countries to provide the Security Council with a permanent armed force to deter aggression and enforce peace.

title: Padres Pound Giants In a Literal Slugfest
description: Padres 9, Giants 4

title: Albert Bader Jr., 59, Partner in Law Firm
description: Albert X. Bader Jr., a partner in the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, died on Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 59 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Last Stand for the Adirondacks?
description: The 100th birthday celebration of the Adirondack Park may yet be turned into a wake.

title: Market Place; Ex-Growth Stars Alluring to Some
description: VALUE is in. Growth is out. So why are some of the people who traditionally invest in value putting growth stocks in their portfolios?

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a televised policy broadcast by Gov. Bill Clinton misidentified the scene shown. It was a news conference in Washington, not the taping of the broadcast in Pittsburgh.

title: F.C.C. ACTS TO LET THE NETWORKS BUY LOCAL CABLE UNITS
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted today to allow broadcast television networks to buy local cable television systems, a move that could hasten a basic realignment of the television industry.

title: Surprise! Escaping From Fenway Is Possible After All
description: How many lives did Melido Perez have tonight against the Red Sox? How many pitches did his right arm have? How many Yankees were finally smiling after another one-run game was completed at Fenway Park?

title: STAPLES TO INCREASE STAKE IN BUSINESS DEPOT OF CANADA
description: Staples Inc. will increase its share in Business Depot Ltd., a Toronto-based operator of office product superstores, to 19.9 percent from 16 percent, Thomas G. Stemberg, the Staples chairman, said. Staples plans to include Business Depot's earnings and revenue with its own, under Securities and Exchange Commission regulations.

title: Farish Is New Churchill Downs Chairman
description: WILLIAM S. FARISH, a Kentucky thoroughbred breeder, yesterday was selected as chairman of Churchill Downs during a meeting of the track's board of directors. He succeeds WARNER L. JONES Jr., who did not seek re-election to the post he had held since 1984. (AP)

title: Expansion Teams Pick Leftovers
description: The Tampa Bay Lightning went for veteran defensemen and toughness. The Ottawa Senators chose balance, featuring a well-known forward and a goalie with possible marquee value.

title: Calipari of UMass Signs 4-Year Deal
description: JOHN CALIPARI, who coached Massachusetts to a 30-5 record last season, yesterday signed a four-year contract with the school.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Chase Manhattan Corp., New York, is offering $200 million, up from $150 million, of 8 percent subordinated notes due in 1999 at par through Salomon Brothers. Noncallable, the notes are rated Baa-3 by Moody Investors Service Inc. and BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Household International Inc., Prospect Heights, Ill., is offering $100 million of 5 3/4 percent notes due in 1994 at 99.649 to yield 5.94 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Noncallable, the notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

title: Books of The Times; Eyesight Returned, Musical Ear Lost
description: The Strange Case of Mademoiselle P. By Brian O'Doherty 228 pages. Pantheon Books. $19.

title: As Bishops Meet, Catholics Voice Differences With Church's Doctrine; Little Hope Seen for Letter on Women
description: The chairman of the committee of Roman Catholic bishops that has worked for nine years to draft a pastoral letter on women said after a divisive debate among the bishops today that it would take a miracle to pass the letter when it came up for a final vote in November.

title: Broker Firm Is Suspended
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, which regulates the Nasdaq and over-the-counter securities markets, today suspended the brokerage firm J. W. Gant & Associates Inc. and its chief executive, Frank Palumbo.

title: Parents Say Boy Shot on Bus Is Improving
description: The 6-year-old boy who was shot in the head last week while riding a school bus here is recovering but is not speaking in complete sentences and has not talked about the shooting, his parents said today.

title: G.O.P. Cuts Florio's Plan in Its Budget
description: The leaders of the Republican legislative majority announced today a $14.6 billion budget for 1993 that cuts Gov. Jim Florio's spending plan by $1.1 billion.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a statement by President Boris N. Yeltsin referred incorrectly to the home state of Bob Smith, the deputy chairman of a Senate committee investigating missing American servicemen. He is a Republican of New Hampshire, not Oregon.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Reports Of Corrupt New York Police
description: Federal law-enforcement officials are investigating allegations of drug-dealing by groups of police officers in one of New York City's most violent, drug-ridden precincts and suspect that there are pockets of corrupt officers in several other precincts, state and Federal investigators say.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Government officials who take classified personal papers with them on leaving office misidentified the organization that prepared a report critical of the practice. It was the Center for Public Integrity, not Investigative Reporters and Editors.

title: Pentagon Takes Over Inquiry on Pilots
description: In the latest development in a scandal that has embarrassed the Navy and its leadership, the Pentagon today took over the investigation into the assault of 26 women at a convention of naval aviators in Las Vegas, Nev., last year.

title: Laettner Has Job Interview in Minnesota
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves have interviewed CHRISTIAN LAETTNER in anticipation of picking him third in the college draft.

title: People
description: * Jamie Rhind has been named senior vice president and associate media director at Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York. Mr. Rhind had been a media supervisor at Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Magazines Report Rise in Advertising
description: The tide in magazine advertising may be turning. A report by the Publishers' Information Bureau shows that total magazine advertising revenue for May was up 9.37 percent over May 1991. A 5.37 percent aggregate gain in revenue was posted for the first five months of the year as well.

title: Confusion Reigns as Athletes Open U.S. Olympic Track Trials
description: It seems like ages ago: FloJo and her body suits, the remarkable reigns of Edwin Moses and Carl Lewis; the ascending stars of Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Randy Barnes and a trio of 400-meter runners. Over nine days four summers ago in the heat and humidity of Indianapolis, the 1988 United States Olympic trials in track and field produced an array of impressions and records.

title: Police Investigative Unit Is Charged With Laxness
description: The Internal Affairs Division of the New York City Police Department, created to fight police corruption amid scandal two decades ago, now finds itself an object of criticism about how well it has done its job.

title: On My Mind; Sixteen Million Slaves
description: Congress had the right to cheer, to share the pleasure and pride with Boris Yeltsin when he said that the idol of Communism would never rise again in his country.

title: In New Orleans, the Gumbo That Leads to the Games
description: For American track and field athletes, the road to Barcelona takes its final turn here. The 10-day United States Olympic trials, a competition often more testing than the Games themselves, will begin Friday, and the survivors will qualify for the Olympics, which start July 25 in Barcelona.

title: Infertility Chain: The Good and Bad in Medicine
description: For couples stranded in the desert of infertility, Dr. Geoffrey Sher's clinic in the green hills 10 miles north of San Francisco is an oasis. People considering in-vitro fertilization and other advanced treatments can leaf through an album filled with photos of babies conceived through Dr. Sher's program, Pacific Fertility Center.

title: Police Overlooked Bloodstain, Jury in Au Pair Trial Is Told
description: The police overlooked a bloodstain at the scene of a fire that killed a 3-month-old baby and prosecution investigators later discarded a sample from that stain, the jury was told today at the arson murder trial of a Swiss au pair.

title: Why the Innocent Might Plead Guilty
description: To the Editor:

title: Utah Utility Bonds
description: To take advantage of the lower interest rates in the debt market, the Intermountain Power Agency of Utah is offering $242.8 million in power-supply refunding revenue bonds to yield a maximum 6.45 percent for an issue due in 2021, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Serial bonds with shorter maturities are priced to yield from 3 percent in 1993 to 5.1 percent in 1997, 5.85 percent in 2002 and 6.25 percent in 2007. For investors interested in other long-term issues, the financing includes a bond issue due in 2012 priced to yield about 6.393 percent. Underwriters said the tax-exempt issue was rated double-A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Jordan Says Bulls Won't Visit Bush
description: MICHAEL JORDAN says he doesn't think there will be any trip to the White House for the Chicago Bulls, who recently won their second consecutive National Basketball Association title.

title: Family Suing F.B.I. in Death Of 'Informer'
description: HOUSTON, June 18 -- The family of a wealthy businessman who was mysteriously murdered here has filed an unusual lawsuit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department. The suit says that he was an informer for the Government and that the Government failed to protect him.

title: Clinton Becomes Yeltsin Fan After Early Morning Chat
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas met President Boris N. Yeltsin today, and to hear the likely Democratic Presidential nominee tell it, the half-hour chat with the Russian leader was a meeting of the minds.

title: Excerpts From the Court's Decision on Rejecting Jurors on the Basis of Race
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Georgia v. McCollum, holding that criminal defendants may not exercise their right to reject potential jurors in a manner that discriminates on the basis of race.

title: Restaurants
description: Let the rakish trattorias around town get all the fashion plates and media mentions. Night after night, Il Mulino is packed more tightly than the box seats at Shea Stadium.

title: Georgia Agreement Promises to Add Black Judges
description: The Governor of Georgia and the primary plaintiffs in lawsuits challenging the method of selecting state judges reached an agreement today that would change the system from elective to appointive and pave the way for an immediate and dramatic increase in the number of black judges.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14 U.S. INTERCEDING FOR RUSSIA

title: U.S. Finds Retaliation Against White Woman Who Charged Bias
description: In an unusual discrimination case, a Federal agency has found that a former manager at a New York City health clinic was retaliated against after she filed a charge that she faced discrimination at work because she is white and Jewish.

title: Child Sex Abuse Cases Can Be Witch Hunts; Grounds for Appeal
description: To the Editor:

title: For Holyfield, Success Is Hardly Hit or Miss
description: Evander Holyfield has always been a fighter who got hit. Michael Dokes, Alex Stewart, George Foreman and Bert Cooper all jarred him with good licks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DIZZY GILLESPIE is unable to attend a concert tonight honoring his 75th birthday, but that does not mean that the tones of his legendary trumpet won't reverberate through Carnegie Hall.

title: Homestead Rebate Cuts Won't Include Elderly
description: The Republican Legislature did the expected and cut Gov. Jim Florio's $685 million homestead rebate program by more than 60 percent, in the process cutting the rebates for most renters and homeowners to the bone and leaving only the elderly untouched.

title: Plan to Aid Olympia Is Reported
description: Looking to repay a favor to an old friend, the Wall Street trader Lewis S. Ranieri is putting together a posse of investors to rescue Paul Reichmann, vice chairman of Olympia & York Developments Ltd., Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Bush Administration to Offer Legislation to Assist Banks
description: Offering an election year gift to the banking industry, the Bush Administration will introduce legislation to repeal provisions of last year's banking law that the banks have complained are too onerous.

title: A TV News Program To Be Offered on Cable
description: Time Warner's all-news channel for New York City cable subscribers will begin a program in September to explore city news and issues in association with The New York Times.

title: For Children
description: Discovery Zone Cross County Square Mall 752 Central Park Avenue Yonkers (914) 969-1666 Recommended ages: 1 to 10

title: Review/Film: Batman Returns; A Sincere Bat, a Sexy Cat and a Bad Bird
description: BATMAN" was an exceptionally hard act to follow, and that's no compliment. It says less about the first film's dark ingenuity than about its sour, cynical spirit and its taste for smirking sadism, qualities that dimmed the urgency for a return visit to Gotham City and its trouble-plagued citizenry. Yet the status of "Batman" as one of Hollywood's biggest commercial triumphs only compounded the sequel problem, creating pressure to re-activate this money machine at any cost. The prospect of a new "Batman" installment -- "Batman Returns" opens today at more than 2,600 theaters nationwide -- has thus been more inevitable than welcome.

title: Morgan's 66 Leads Wave Of Low Scores at Open
description: For Gil Morgan, a 45-year-old doctor of optometry in his 15th United States Open, today's 66 was the lowest round he has ever shot in the Open. It also was the the lowest round ever shot by any golfer at Pebble Beach in the Open. The six-under-par round by Morgan was so low in fact that it gave him a one-stroke lead over Curtis Strange, which was nothing to sneeze at.

title: Bringing Madison Avenue Polish to Bush's Campaign Ads
description: MARTIN PURIS, the president and chief executive of the Ammirati & Puris agency and the man who heads George Bush's media team, is not quite sure how he is going to create a winning advertising strategy for the President's re-election campaign.

title: Parks Threaten to Uproot Cottages by Long Island Sound
description: Since 1974, Dick and Peggy Confoy and their six children have spent every summer at their cottage here on West Meadow Beach, overlooking Long Island Sound. Each spring, Mr. Confoy removes the boards from the windows, cleans the winter's accumulation of sea thatch and sets up the barbecue grill on the deck. This is where the family stays until the fall.

title: CYCLING: Biking in the U.S.A. -- Day 11; Promises to Keep
description: My friend David Karestsky, whose hobby was physical challenge, would have loved this bicycle trip.

title: A Dispute Over Courtroom Attire, and Principles
description: An objection from a judge about a lawyer's choice of attire has become the talk of legal circles in Washington, raising questions about where a lawyer's personal freedom collides with court procedures and whether clothing can influence a jury.

title: A & S in Hempstead Closing After 40 Years
description: When Abraham & Straus opened its doors here 40 years ago, this village was the center of business and politics on Long Island.

title: Supreme Court Rules Defendants Can't Use Race to Exclude Jurors
description: Six years after ruling that the prosecution cannot exclude people from serving on juries on the basis of race, the Supreme Court today extended the same rule to criminal defendants.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Education page on Wednesday about the search for university presidents at Chicago, Columbia, Duke and Yale referred incorrectly to a woman who was listed among possible candidates for all four institutions, and misidentified her employer. She is Adele Simmons, president of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation.

title: Philip Reisman, 87, Artist Who Offered Views of New York
description: Philip Reisman, a Social Realist painter and printmaker known for his views of New York City street life, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 87 years old, and lived in Manhattan.

title: Maxwell's Sons Arrested on Charges of Fraud
description: Kevin and Ian Maxwell, sons of the late Robert Maxwell, and an American investment manager for Mr. Maxwell were arrested today on charges of stealing from employee pension funds and one Maxwell company and of conspiring to defraud banks.

title: Chief Hopeful as Irish Vote on Europe
description: As Ireland voted on the Treaty on European Union, which will significantly affect the future of this country and the rest of Europe, Prime Minister Albert Reynolds said today that he thought a majority of his compatriots were voting yes.

title: California Eccentrics And the Big One
description: Their best friends won't tell them, but Andrew Yates, the director, and Mark Edens, the writer, must be told anyway: their first feature film, a comedy titled "Life on the Edge," is inept and unfunny to the point of being terrible.

title: Critic's Notebook; 'Chimes at Midnight,' Welles's Own Shakespeare
description: As an actor and a director, on stage and in films, Laurence Olivier set piercingly high standards for intelligence and craft and created his own grand classical traditions. Sometimes, though, the standards and traditions blinded the critics, if not the public. Whether Olivier intended to or not, the English-speaking theater's last great actor-manager had a bulldozer's way of demolishing all opposition. Among those left behind in the rubble and dust: Orson Welles.

title: Saberhagen Fails Painful Test of Finger
description: The treatment of Bret Saberhagen goes on. The wait for the right-hander's return goes on. And the concern about it all for the Mets deepens.

title: At the Bar; With judges hired and ready, arbitration services wait to see whether the lawyers will come.
description: Is scrappy, aggressive, argumentative New York, whose lawyers pride themselves on their bare-knuckled obstreperousness, finally ready to forsake traditional litigation for the more rational, orderly and private world of mediation and arbitration?

title: CONOCO VENTURE TO DEVELOP RUSSIAN OILFIELDS
description: Conoco Inc. and its Russian joint-venture partner said yesterday that they would spend up to $3 billion to develop multiple oilfields in Russia. The area to be developed by the venture, called Timan-Pechora Ltd., is in the northern Timan-Pechora Basin, west of the Ural Mountains near the Arctic Circle. The companies estimate the recoverable reserves in the first field to be about 110 million barrels.

title: Corrections
description: The Pulse chart in The Metro Section on Saturday misstated the change in consumer prices for the New York City region in May. The change was a decrease of 0.2 percent, not an increase.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: As Bishops Meet, Catholics Voice Differences With Church's Doctrine; Poll Finds Backing Of Female Priests
description: A Gallup poll released here today finds that two-thirds of Roman Catholics in the United States favor opening the priesthood to women, an increase of 20 percentage points over just seven years ago.

title: Backers of '78 Tax Revolt Hail Ruling
description: Backers of the California property tax revolt that was upheld today by the United States Supreme Court rejoiced in what they said was an affirmation of the citizen's right to keep down taxes.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: 20 Ph.D.'s at Rockefeller U.
description: Rockefeller University awarded 20 Ph.D. degrees yesterday at the school's 34th commencement ceremonies , in the Caspary auditorium on the campus on York Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Art in Review
description: Tim Rollins and K.O.S. Mary Boone Gallery 417 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through June 27

title: On Stage, and Off
description: 'Angels' and 'Atrides'

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; PRESIDENTIAL RACE NOW STABILIZING
description: After months of steady gains in polls by undeclared candidate Ross Perot, the race for President has leveled off and stabilized for the past month, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Look Who's Adding Missiles
description: The world has barely absorbed the stirring summit news that the superpowers have agreed to drastic cuts in their fearsome nuclear arsenals. The West can now truly look to the ex-Evil Empire with hope instead of horror. So what are America's allies France and Britain doing? Increasing their nuclear arsenals. With U.S. help.

title: GENERAL MOTORS' SATURN PLANT TO ADD THIRD WORK SHIFT
description: The Saturn Corporation plans to add a third work shift early next year, which would increase annual output at the company's Spring Hill, Tenn., plant to 300,000 cars a year. Donald W. Hudler, vice president of sales, service and marketing for the company, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said production at the plant was currently 925 to 950 cars a day, or at 85 percent to 90 percent of capacity.

title: 2 New Financings From Fieldcrest
description: To redeem some high-interest debt and thereby reduce its debt service payments, Fieldcrest Cannon Inc., a home-furnishings and textile products company based in Greensboro, N.C., is raising money through two financings.

title: At the Movies
description: In 1946, partly to lure tourists back to the Riviera after World War II, the French Government and the film industry held a film festival at Cannes. The rest is history.

title: Reviews/Film; If a Haircut's Erotic, Marry the Barber
description: Patrice Leconte gives "The Hairdresser's Husband" the same obsessive intensity he brought to "Monsieur Hire," but beyond that these two films have precious little in common. Working with the Georges Simenon thriller that was the basis for his elegant 1989 tale of erotic longing, Mr. Leconte constructed a tragic, symmetrical film graced with superb understatement and an eloquently plain visual style. This time, he takes a similar tack with material so flimsy that it borders on sheer silliness. Relentlessly contemplative, "The Hairdresser's Husband" is simply about one man's lifelong enjoyment of having women cut his hair.

title: Lloyd's Plans To Limit Risk For Members
description: The Lloyd's of London insurance market announced a plan yesterday to limit the potential losses of its members, a fundamental departure from the way the 304-year-old institution has done business.

title: Vasiliki Johnides, 92; Ran L.I. Restaurant
description: Vasiliki Johnides, who founded a Long Island restaurant popular with food critics and celebrities, died on Tuesday at Southampton Hospital in Southampton, L.I.

title: More Arrests in Milwaukee
description: The police today arrested at least 73 anti-abortion protesters, 47 of them children, outside a women's clinic where hundreds of abortion rights supporters locked arms to protect it. Many of those arrested were adults and children who kneeled or lay in the street outside the clinic and refused to move. Today's arrests followed dozens of others on Tuesday outside abortion clinics in Milwaukee, where protesters plan a weeks-long campaign.

title: Review/Ballet; Floating Or Plunging, But Always Glittering
description: Clark Tippet's "Bruch Violin Concerto No. 1" is a glittering showcase for dancers. What makes it rewarding as well as demanding to perform is Mr. Tippet's ability to make his choreography glitter in several different ways. American Ballet Theater displayed all of the work's facets at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday night, when a new cast took over most of the solo roles.

title: Public Broadcasting Lobbied for an Increase
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; CLINTON TO REMAIN VISIBLE DURING CONVENTION
description: Breaking with tradition, the Clinton campaign is planning to let its candidate out of his hotel suite during the early part of the Democratic convention in New York City.

title: The Subways Need Albany, Too
description: Peter Stangl, the chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has proposed an innovative five-year strategy to create a transit system that builds ridership by genuinely serving riders.
