title: Highways vs. Mass Transit Impasse Imperils $1.6 Billion in Annual Federal Aid
description: A city vs. suburbs, highways vs. mass transit standoff between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Long Island and lower Hudson Valley suburbs of New York City has put hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal transportation aid at risk.

title: Turkey Seeks Security Advantage In Region's New Ex-Soviet Nations
description: The gathering of leaders of 11 nations of the Balkan Peninsula and the former Soviet Union was described this week by Turkish and other participants as a Turkish initiative to draw advantage from the collapse of Communism and its founder state.

title: Advantage Health reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 527,000 from extinguishment of debt.

title: U.S. Presses Ousted Haitian Chief To Negotiate a Return From Exile
description: In a push to end a nine-month political standoff, the United States has begun urging Haiti's deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to meet with the country's army-backed Prime Minister to negotiate his return from exile and the lifting of an international embargo.

title: Pacific National Financial reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Warmus Begs for Leniency But Gets Toughest Sentence
description: Carolyn Warmus begged for leniency today, declaring she did not kill her lover's wife but a judge sentenced her to the maximum term for intentional murder.

title: Ex-U.S. Envoy Says Yeltsin Misspoke on M.I.A.'s
description: The American co-chairman of the commission searching for missing Americans in Russia said today that President Boris N. Yeltsin "misspoke" when he said American prisoners of war might still be there.

title: Big U.S. Steelmakers to Seek Billions in Tariffs
description: An angry American steel industry has decided to seek billions of dollars in tariffs on imports from Japan, the European Community, Canada and more than a dozen third world countries.

title: Friends See Secretary as Honorable but Ill-Served
description: Friends and colleagues of Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett 3d say he has always been a meticulous lawyer, an unflappable crisis manager, a loyal public servant and an absolute "straight arrow."

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer transmission error, an article yesterday about effects felt in Serbia from the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina described the drop in the value of the currency incorrectly. While inflation has sometimes climbed at a rate of more than 10 percent a day, in the three weeks since sanctions were imposed the value of a 5,000-dinar note dropped to $2.70 from about $5.50, not $550.

title: Jazz in Review
description: Harold Mabern Pianist Equitable Auditorium Manhattan

title: Johnson Drops Suit Against HBO
description: VANCE JOHNSON, a wide receiver for the Denver Broncos, who sued Home Box Office for showing him naked on television, has settled his lawsuit out of court, his lawyer said yesterday in Denver.

title: Rome Journal; Who Will Save Italy's Ragged Past?
description: First it was the Leaning Tower of Pisa, whose leaning had become so extreme that a corset of steel was strapped around its 819-year-old base to prevent it from tumbling.

title: Capitals Make Offer for Manson
description: The Washington Capitals made a rare foray into the free-agent market yesterday, offering defenseman DAVE MANSON a four-year contract in an effort to lure him away from the Edmonton Oilers. Manson, 25 years old, signed an offer sheet that calls for $1.1 million for the first two years and $1.2 million for the third and option year.

title: Parlux Fragrances Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record; Report Says Police Violated Policies to Aid Perot
description: Despite policies forbidding the use of police officers in civil cases, an officer with a drug-sniffing police dog and officers in marked police cars assisted Ross Perot during a dispute with a tenant in 1990, a private investigator's report on the incident says.

title: Infertile Couples Need the Option of Surrogacy; Regulate the Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz in Review
description: Modern Jazz Quartet Carnegie Hall

title: Usual Pleas, Usual Causes, Usual Airport
description: The summertime crowds of tourists, vacationers and business travelers poured through the main terminal at Kennedy International Airport yesterday afternoon and, as usual, the deft hands and insistent voices of the solicitors were there, aggressively seeking money for political and religious causes.

title: Interspec Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 233,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 411,000, or 7 cents a share, in the 6 months, both from tax benefits; the 6 months also included a gain of $ 158,000 from sale of unit.c-After an extraordinary credit of $ 253,000, or 4 cents a share, from tax benefit, and included a $ 7.4 million gain from sale of unit.Year-ago 6 months' sales included about $ 5.8 million from the sale of its former Vingmed Sound S.A. unit in January 1991.

title: No Way, or Any Day?
description: Two weeks ago, as 6-year-old Cesar Sandoval lay unconscious in a hospital bed, shot in the head when his school bus was caught in a crossfire between armed teen-agers in New Haven, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. issued a call for a special session of the legislature to rethink the state's gun laws.

title: Namic U.S.A. Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 407,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,108,000, or 16 cents a share, in the year.

title: Xytronyx Inc.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
Investment Chief Quits
description: The New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that Christina Seix had resigned as chairman and chief executive of its investment unit, the MacKay-Shields Financial Corporation. Ms. Seix, 41 years old, plans to start an investment-advisory firm, New York Life said. The compamy named Ravi Akhoury, 45, president of MacKay-Shields, to succeed Ms. Seix. Ms. Seix had held her position since August 1987. She joined the company in 1981.

title: Wise Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Nichols Research Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Pension Fund Wins Ruling Against Olympia & York
description: One of the nation's largest pension funds won a court victory yesterday against two affiliates of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. The ruling, which concludes that the troubled Canadian real estate company reneged on a $250 million loan agreement in 1983, could thwart the developer's efforts to avoid a huge bankruptcy filing in the United States.

title: John J. Astor 5th, 79; Son of Builder of Hotel
description: John Jacob Astor 5th, a descendant of one of America's most fabled merchant princes, died yesterday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 79 years old.

title: The Case of the Missing Pharaoh The Case of the Missing Pharaoh
description: The police seldom work on a subtle but critical crime of scholarship. But a New York City detective's forensic art apparently has exposed a case of academic malpractice. His work lends credence to theory that the Sphinx is thousands of years older than Egyptologists and archeologists think. If it is, we must radically revise our ideas about ancient civilization before the rise of the Egyptian culture about 3000 B.C.

title: Biomet Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about trading in tobacco stocks on Wednesday after the Supreme Court's ruling on cigarette product liability misattributed the first news of the decision seen on most traders' computer screens. The headline was from the Dow Jones News Service, not Bloomberg Business News.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHASE LINCOLN FIRST, Rochester, a unit of Chase Manhattan Corp., named David C. Clark executive vice president. COUNTRY AMERICA, New York, a magazine published by Meredith Corp., named Gail C. Healy publisher.

title: Credit Market Awaits New Economic Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities were basically unchanged in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers chose to close their books and wait for a series of important economic reports next week.

title: Proper Daily Accused of Islamic Impropriety
description: One of the more strident anti-Western institutions and champions of Islamic propriety, the Kayhan newspaper chain, has itself come under attack, a state-run newspaper reported.

title: Mark's Work Wearhouse reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: b-Included a tax recovery of $ 1,567,000, or 16 cents a share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: British Succession Offers a Ray of Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Loud Alarms Aren't Just For Cars, Or Are They?
description: The Personal Attack Alarm is a safety alarm for people. When its small pin is pulled, the alarm emits a sharp, piercing screech that may scare an attacker away.

title: Navy Chief Quits Amid Questions Over Role in Sex-Assault Inquiry
description: Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett 3d resigned today amid questions about his involvement in a scandal stemming from the assault of 26 women, including 14 female officers, at a convention of naval aviators last year in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Religion Notes
description: Switching Allegiances

title: UBS Names Official
description: Union Bank of Switzerland's North American unit, UBS Securities Inc., yestrday named Sheldon Epstein as managing director of its over-the-counter derivative options trading operation. At UBS, Mr. Epstein, formerly director of the global swap group at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, will develop additional off-balance-sheet fixed-income financial instruments, including warrants, options and synthetic mortgage-backed and asset-backed securities.

title: Boitano Leaning Toward Lillehammer
description: The International Skating Union has said professionals can compete with amateurs in figure skating at the Olympics. And BRIAN BOITANO seems ready to say yes to Lillehammer, Norway, in 1994.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP., New York, authorized the repurchase of an additional 10 million shares, or 3.1 percent, of its outstanding common stock. BOSTON PACIFIC MEDICAL INC., acquired Boston Medica Ltd., a medical products distributor in Bogota, Colombia.

title: Uncharted Territory Ahead as Trains Roll Again
description: Railroads around the country moved quickly to resume normal service today, ending the two-day chokehold on industries that rely on the rails and the threat of no service for tens of thousands of commuters in the Northeast.

title: AMERICA WEST'S REVAMPING SEEN NEARING COMPLETION
description: America West Airlines Inc. expects to complete its reorganization plan by late summer and emerge from bankruptcy before the end of the year. The company president, Michael J. Conway, said negotiations with creditors were proceeding despite recent fare wars that have hurt airline earnings.

title: Sandpaper II: Leary Pure But Rough Finish for Yanks
description: With umpires, television cameras, an opposing manager and curious Yankee fans playing detective, Tim Leary seemed to be squeaky-clean last night.

title: Infertile Couples Need the Option of Surrogacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Florio Vetoes Budget Plan In New Jersey
description: Just hours after the Republican-controlled Legislature approved a sharply reduced budget of $14.6 billion, Gov. Jim Florio vetoed it tonight, setting the stage for a possible attempt to override.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Hardly Laissez-Faire; Perot Says Strong Government Action Could Restore Industries to Strength
description: In his muscular rhetoric about making America's economy stand tall again, Ross Perot sounds more activist about the economy than many liberal Democrats, promising a far more interventionist role for the Government to make American industry more competitive.

title: Senate Offers Referendum On Sentences
description: After ignoring years of challenges from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to let the people decide whether to reimpose the death penalty in New York State, the Republican-controlled State Senate today reversed course and approved a bill that its members said would do just that.

title: In Surprise, M.T.A. Bans All Tobacco Advertising
description: Despite warnings that such an action might be unconstitutional, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday banned tobacco advertising in its subways, buses and commuter railroads.

title: Bassett Furniture Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: b-Included $ 771,000, or 7 cents a share, of unrealized gain on market securities.c-Included $ 1.4 million, or 12 cents a share, of unrealized gain on marketable securities, in the quarter and 6 months.All per share data has been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed April 6 to shareholders of record March 16.

title: Hearts Heavy, Arms Light, They Are Fighting On for Sarajevo
description: All was deathly quiet on Thursday night on the northern front of Sarajevo's war.

title: Maverick Restaurant reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Hold the Phone! Mets Try to Explain
description: Manager Jeff Torborg apologized for any appearance of an organizational cover-up. Bobby Bonilla didn't apologize for anything. Other Mets had their suspicions about the right fielder and the manager and their roles in Thursday's tragedy of errors at Shea Stadium.

title: Patents; Eyeglasses Augmented By Computer
description: RONALD SIWOFF, an optometrist described the vision of a person whose optic nerve has been damaged: If anything at all can be seen, the colors are likely to be shades of gray; edges and outlines are probably blurry, and details might well be invisible.

title: Excerpts From Justices' Opinions on Mississippi's Public University System
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today in United States v. Fordice that Mississippi must do more to dismantle the legacy of segregation in its eight public colleges and universities.

title: INSIDE
description: Trade Battle Over Steel

title: German Orders Off
description: New orders in the German machinery and engineering sector fell 4 percent in May from a year ago, the German Machinery Manufacturers' and Engineering Association said today. New domestic orders dropped 6 percent in May, while orders from overseas were down 1 percent from May 1991.

title: Unico American Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
British Succession Offers a Ray of Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush's Greatest Glory Fades As Questions on Iraq Persist
description: President Bush may have reached the pinnacle of his political career on March 7, 1991, when he addressed a joint session of Congress and basked in a three-minute standing ovation from lawmakers who waved small American flags and even chanted his name in admiration of his handling of the Persian Gulf war.

title: Morgan's Foods reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
Shorewood Packaging reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
South Bronx Begins to Shed Image of a Land Without Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Festival That Knows No Bounds
description: The American Dance Festival is doubly important. Every summer it offers significant examples of American modern dance. At the same time, it shows American audiences works by contemporary choreographers from around the world. It thereby proclaims the essential internationalism of modern dance. National styles do exist. Yet dance can leap across boundaries.

title: After First Day, Decathlon Results Not as Advertised
description: Two months ago, Dan O'Brien suffered a stress fracture of his right fibula. Two weeks ago, although he and his coaches had never disclosed it, he sprained his left ankle. So instead of training three times a day, he has been training once every other day. He estimates he is at 80 percent efficiency.

title: Men's Team Aims for a Golden Beginning
description: They came. They practiced. They played golf. And then yesterday, on the final day of workouts in La Jolla, Calif., the United States men's basketball team departed for Portland, Ore., their first step toward an anticipated Olympic gold medal later this summer.

title: Lendl Continues Quest to be Lion of the Lawn
description: Cranky, crafty Ivan Lendl did not literally invite 21-year-old Sandon Stolle to sit on his knee and listen to an early bedtime story as the evening shadows gathered on Wimbledon's Court One. But by the time he had forced the youngster into a fifth set today, the self-described old-timer was into a full-scale exposition of tennis' version of "The Turn of the Screw."

title: Diploma Comes First In the Sealy Family
description: The parents, Ann and Sidney Sealy, did not cry as the son, Malik, marched to the stage, graduating from the St. John's Redmen to the National Basketball Association in black Indiana Pacers cap, no gown.

title: Shamir Is Said to Admit Plan To Stall Talks 'for 10 Years'
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir was quoted in a published interview today as saying he wanted to drag out peace talks with the Palestinians for a decade while vastly increasing the number of Jewish settlers in Israeli-occupied territories.

title: VATICAN PREPARES A NEW CATECHISM
description: The Vatican announced today that it had completed a new and long-awaited "universal catechism" designed to guide the world's 980 million Roman Catholics in presenting church teachings.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a decision by the International Trade Commission that tariffs should not be imposed on imported Japanese mini-vans referred incorrectly to a court that hears appeals of decisions by the Court of International Trade. It is the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, not the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: Waterhouse Investor Services reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Waterhouse Investor Services said that per-share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the company's 3-for-2 stock split, which was paid in the form of a 50 percent dividend on Feb. 26.

title: Unifirst Corp.  reports earnings for 13wks to May 30
description: b-Included $ 1.2 million reserve provided in the second quarter to cover a plant closing and $ 1.2 million credit from an accounting change.

title: Revelation in Tyson Case Leaves Mixed Opinions
description: A day after the Rhode Island Supreme Court indicated that the victim in the Mike Tyson trial may have committed perjury, opinions were split yesterday on what effect the finding might have on the future of Tyson, who is serving a six-year sentence for rape.

title: Big Question on Reviewing Police Conduct: What Is True Civilian Control?
description: When New York City was embroiled in its last great battle over establishment of a civilian-controlled board to investigate cases of police brutality the issue seemed a matter of first-grade arithmetic:

title: Another Hope Is Dashed in Sarajevo, as Serbs Shatter Airport Truce
description: The latest effort by United Nations commanders to start relief flights to Sarajevo airport broke down on Friday as Serbian nationalist forces used tanks and artillery to attack civilian buildings in an airport suburb, Dobrinja.

title: Joy Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: There were no year-ago first quarter share earnings after a preferred dividend payment of $ 3,214,000.The company said that its earnings for the latest quarter were positively affected by Joy's financial recapitalization last fall that resulted in $ 6.3 million of lower interest expense and the elimination of the preferred dividend requirements.

title: Relieved Stein Hopes for Robber's Arrest
description: City Council President Andrew J. Stein, speaking publicly for the first time since his two sons and their baby sitter were locked in a bathroom by an armed robber in the family's Upper East Side apartment on Thursday afternoon, said yesterday that he was relieved that no one had been hurt.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page yesterday about defense lawyers' possible response to a Supreme Court prohibition on excluding jurors because of race misidentified an organization of black lawyers. It is the National Conference of Black Lawyers, not the National Black Trial Lawyers Conference.

title: Albany Session Limps to an Unproductive Close
description: A legislative session that once held great promise now appears to be dwindling to an anticlimactic close, with state lawmakers failing so far to agree on many of the most critical issues facing the state, from economic development to Medicaid to environmental protection.

title: Tranzonic Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The shares outstanding included average of class A common, class B common and common equivalent shares outstanding.

title: OrNda Healthcorp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 5,904,000 from retirement of debt in the quarter and 9 months, and both periods included a $ 6.2 million writedown to reflect the anticipated divestiture of Physicians' Community Hospital, a $ 3 million charge to relocate the corporate office to Nashville, and a $ 1.8 million additional provision for doubtful accounts.The latest 9 months' results also included a charge in the second quarter for special executive compensation and the termination of a management contract related to a change in chief executive officer of $ 4,938,000.c-Net income

title: U.S. Sends Mobutu a Message By Welcoming a Cleric-Critic
description: With negotiations to bring democracy to Zaire entering a critical phase in Kinshasa, the Bush Administration has given an unusually high-level welcome to a Roman Catholic archbishop who is leading the movement for change in the Central African country.

title: Lewis Freedman, Producer, 66; A TV Career Spanning 45 Years
description: Lewis Freedman, a television producer and program executive for CBS and PBS, died on Thursday at his home in Chicago. He was 66 years old.

title: Broader Abortion Law Leaves Germans Somber
description: A small crowd gathered at the Cologne Cathedral during the 14-hour debate in the German Parliament to attend a "Mass for the unborn" and await the news from Bonn early this morning of the vote to liberalize the nation's abortion law.

title: Job for D'Amboise
description: To the Editor:

title: At Les Pleiades, Going, Going, Gone!
description: For many people in the art world, Thursday night was truly a last supper. There were tears and eulogies and even a presiding minister. But this was a culinary celebration rather than a religious one, marking the closing of a beloved institution.

title: Cuomo Is Not on List Of Those Addressing Party's Convention
description: In the glittering lineup of speakers for next month's Democratic National Convention in New York, there is one notable omission: Mario M. Cuomo, the Governor of New York, who has been known to give a well-received speech from time to time.

title: Quick & Reilly Group reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
COURT, 8-1, FAULTS MISSISSIPPI ON BIAS IN COLLEGE SYSTEM
description: Thirty years after a court order forced the University of Mississippi to accept its first black student, the Supreme Court ruled today that Mississippi had failed to prove that it had met the constitutional requirement of erasing the legacy of segregation in its state university system.

title: Knapp Commission Reunion Has an Unexpected Currency
description: It was planned as a pleasant evening of reminiscences about an investigation 20 years ago that brought sweeping reform to a New York City police department mired in corruption.

title: Focus: Spring Island, S.C.; Development With an Environmental Bent
description: Here among moss-draped live oaks and unspoiled ponds, a new style of island development based on strict environmental standards is being tested, and developers around the nation are watching to see if it succeeds.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11 MARKET ENERGY IN BEIJING

title: Deborah Platt, Jeffrey Weiss
description: Dr. Deborah Platt, a daughter of Sidney Platt of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Sally Platt, was married last evening to Dr. Jeffrey Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Weiss of Fairfield, Conn. Rabbi Morris Barzilai performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Show Stoppers and a Resort Ambience
description: THE new Sfuzzi restaurant in Southampton looks like one of a kind and can hold its own against many of the East End's best. Yet, there are 13 other Sfuzzis (pronounced FOO-zee). The owners scrupulously avoid the word "chain" and call their enterprise a "collection of Italian restaurants." Indeed there is nothing in Sfuzzi's look, food or prices that says chain.

title: Netac's 'Pat on the Back'
description: To the Editor:

title: President Meets Female Officer In Navy Incident
description: Two days after a female aviator went on national television with the story of how she was molested and manhandled at a naval aviators' convention and how little had been done to investigate the event, the White House apparently decided it was time to act.

title: Microsoft's Unlikely Millionaires
description: Just a few years ago, when the monied class of this city gathered inside a single ballroom for an annual arts benefit, nary an unfamiliar face could be seen. Families named Boeing, Nordstrom and Weyerhaeuser, representing airplane, clothing-store and timber empires, were the financial powers of this corner of the Far West. They were also benevolent civic players, keeping the arts afloat and leading drives to save a sports team or add a wing to a hospital.

title: KNITTING IN CLASS
description: I came in late to the discussion of knitting at boring lectures. But there appears to be an implicit assumption that only women knit.

title: Christine Krais, Steven Schott
description: Frederick V. Krais Jr. of Lighthouse Point, Fla., and Janet C. Krais of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Lovell Krais, to Steven Gorin Schott, a son of Lewis M. Schott of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Marcia W. Schott. A December wedding is planned.

title: BEST SELLERS: June 28, 1992
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 114 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 2 4 6 SAHARA, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) On a mission to Africa, Dirk Pitt uncovers a plot that may extinguish all life in the world's seas. 3 3 16 THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A woman law student seeks to discover the truth about the murder of two Supreme Court justices. 4 2 4 DARK FORCE RISING, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $18.50.) A program for staying healthy and trim by consuming fresh fruit and vegetable juices. 4 4 30 MORE WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An updated and expanded volume of financial advice. 5 5 30 HOW TO SATISFY A WOMAN EVERY TIME, by Naura Hayden. (Bibli O'Phile/Dutton, $14.95.) Sexual counsel for married couples. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large print.

title: G.M. Layoff Raises Employee Fears
description: THE announcement by General Motors that 800 employees on the night shift here will be laid off in August has heightened workers' fears about the scheduled closing of the assembly plant three summers from now. Union officials say that unless retraining programs are implemented soon, the factory's 3,100 hourly workers, who will be hard pressed to transfer their skills elsewhere, may find themselves jobless.

title: Miss Gootenberg, Daniel Alpert
description: Lorraine Gootenberg of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Debra Jean Gootenberg, to Daniel Chase Alpert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Saul Alpert of Providence, R.I. An October 1993 wedding is planned.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 28, 1992
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 22 THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $5.99.) A young lawyer learns that his firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities. 2 11 A TIME TO KILL, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $5.99.) Racial tensions surface during the trial of a man charged with murder in rural Mississippi. 3 32 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Berkley, $5.99.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America. 4 5 THE HOUSE OF THUNDER, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $5.99.) A 1982 novel about a woman who, upon regaining consciousness in a hospital, recalls the horrors that brought her there. 5 6 THE KITCHEN GOD'S WIFE, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.99.) A Chinese-American matriarch tells the harrowing story of her life. 6 5 MAN OF MY DREAMS, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $5.99.) A Victorian beauty inadvertently wins the nobleman she had aspired to marry. 7 1 SLEEPING BEAUTY, by Judith Michael. (Pocket, $5.99.) Attending a family funeral, a woman lawyer finds new understanding and love. 8 4 HEIR TO THE EMPIRE, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $5.99.) The survival of the "Star Wars" galaxy is menaced by new forces. 9 22 FRIED GREEN TOMATOES AT THE WHISTLE STOP CAFE, by Fannie Flagg. (McGraw-Hill, $7.95.) Life in rural Alabama. 10 2 DAISY FAY AND THE MIRACLE MAN, by Fannie Flagg. (Warner, $7.99.) A family moves back to a Florida town, where something evil awaits. 12 5 PARADISE, by Judith McNaught. (Pocket, $5.99.) title: Ione Gatch, Kenneth Miller
description: Ione Waite Gatch, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Milton M. Gatch of New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth Norbert Miller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Miller of Beaver Dam, Wis. The bride's father performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Chapel of St. James the Fisherman in Wellfleet, Mass.

title: Making a Difference; A Year of Shakeups And Quips at the N.R.C.
description: Marking the completion of his first year in office, Ivan Selin, chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said last week that protests by citizen groups have helped move his agency in the right direction. These are the organizations that are politely referred to by the neutral term "watchdogs," but given that most of the groups favor shutting down nuclear power plants, it was an out-of-character comment for a man in Mr. Selin's job.

title: Eugene S. Johnson, Industry Spokesman, 60
description: Eugene S. Johnson, a leading spokesman for the oil industry in New York for 30 years, died at his home in New York on Friday. He was 60 years old.

title: JUNE 21-27: A Pragmatic Path; Russia and Ukraine Ease Risk of Confrontation
description: Almost from the moment he returned to Russia from Washington, Boris N. Yeltsin was dousing the ethnic fires that have plagued the former Communist world: Moldovans against Russians, Georgians against Ossetians, Armenians against Azerbaijanis. None came near the Yugoslav horror yet, but they seemed increasingly resistant to reason or moderation.

title: T.A.C. Acts On Behalf Of Reynolds
description: Senior administrators of the national governing body for track and field, The Athletics Congress, voted today to urge the international federation not to extend Butch Reynolds's two-year suspension because he competed in the United States Olympic trials this week.

title: Bonnie Greenberg and Scott Stern
description: Robert A. and Roberta Greenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bonnie Jill Greenberg to Scott Michael Stern, the son of Emanuel and Lana Stern of Commack, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Finding New Ways to Preserve Farmland
description: A 114-ACRE hilly tract in Morris County's Washington Township has long been used for farming. But last month, through an unusual tax-deferred land swap, the owner guaranteed it would remain forever a farm and then traded it for a smaller farm of equal value, also restricted to agricultural use, and a commercial property, both outside the county.

title:
BACKTALK;
When Protest Made a Clean Sweep
description: For a while it looked as if the Olympics in Barcelona might be spared the political and social concerns that have been a major preoccupation at the Games for more than 60 years. But the carnage in the former republics of Yugoslavia means that nation will probably be barred from the 1992 Games, and the massacre last week in Boipatong township 35 miles south of Johannesburg has led the African National Congress to call for a continuation of the sports isolation of South Africa. In light of these developments, this is a good time to look back on the most dramatic political statement made during an Olympic Games and how it has been misunderstood by most people.

title: Tennis Clothes
description: To the Editor: In "The Score Is Advantage, Foie Gras" (May 24) Michael Mewshaw mentions that "at the U.S. Open great passels of spectators show up in T-shirts and shorts, tennis shoes and headbands."

title: POSTINGS: Hamilton Fish Pool; Reopening a 'Treasure'
description: The best-known Beaux-Arts monument by the architects Carrere & Hastings is the New York Public Library. Less renowned, but also a landmark, is the firm's 94-year-old Hamilton Fish Pool and Recreation Center, at East Houston and Pitt Streets. It is to be reopened Thursday after a $14 million restoration.

title: Development With an Environmental Bent
description: Here among moss-draped live oaks and unspoiled ponds, a new style of island development based on strict environmental standards is being tested, and developers around the nation are watching to see if it succeeds.

title: Separating the False From the True
description: THE Philatelic Foundation has examined hundreds of thousands of "patients," but as in any such examinations, only a few were sick: forgeries, fakes and counterfeits of stamps and other postal material.

title: Caroline Gosse, S. P. Elmendorf
description: Anthony C. Gosse of Lewisburg, Pa., and Dey Erben Gosse of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Ferebee Gosse, to Stephen Philip Elmendorf, a son of Richard A. and Louise Elmendorf of Silver Spring, Md. An August wedding is planned.

title: Japanese Folk Art: Much Elegance With Flashes of Wit
description: Folk art has been around since the beginning of time, but no one called it that until the late 19th century. Today, it's collected internationally, and exhibitions of folk art from Europe, Latin America and Asia are on the increase in the United States. The difference between what was made abroad and what was made in this country, say American experts, has more to do with Asian and European attitudes about social class than with art styles.

title: Public & Private; All of These You Are
description: Let us begin today with the fact that being called a honky is not in the same league as being called a nigger.

title: Laurie J. Burton, Jon David Evans
description: Dr. Laurie J. Burton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Burton of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jon David Evans, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Evans of Windsor, Ontario. Benjamin Lander, a retired justice of the New York State Supreme Court, officiated at the Conservatory Gardens in Central Park

title: Elmsford to Ban Rollerblades and Skateboards
description: SUMMER'S here but the time's not right for skateboarding in the street.

title: Thai Food in the Heart of New Haven
description: IN the late 1980's, Thai restaurants seemed to open with alacrity, but the pace has slowed over the last couple of years. That probably has as much to do with economics as with any possibility that the public is sated with the delicate yet fiery cuisine.

title: Swing Band Strikes Up Arts Series
description: THE singer Jose Feliciano and the Eastern Connecticut Symphony Swing Band will perform at tonight's grand opening celebration of the Levitt Pavilion in Westport. The 8 P.M. concert is a fund-raising benefit (admission is $5), for theperforming arts center, with two more similar evenings to follow: the Silver Streaks on Saturday at 8:30 P.M., and David Clayton-Thomas with Blood, Sweat and Tears on Aug. 7 at 9 P.M.

title: The Lipstick Wars
description: MANY years ago Leonard Lauder, president and chief executive of his family's company, Estee Lauder Inc., watched a friend's daughter brewing lip gloss on the kitchen stove and pouring it into bottle caps for sale at school. Pleased that a young person was interested in the business that consumes him, Mr. Lauder fostered her fledgling venture with a contribution of 24 empty pots from his company's packaging line to lend her product more panache.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: IT was a honey of a day, so sweet with sunshine and June skies that Newark looked scrubbed. Real nice.

title: Camilla Campbell, Oliver Platt
description: John P. and Eleanor S. Campbell of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Camilla Bonsal Campbell, to Oliver Platt, a son of Ambassador and Mrs. Nicholas Platt of Islamabad, Pakistan, and Washington.

title: The Executive Computer; As Price Wars Heat Up, the Victors Seem to Be Customers
description: With personal computer companies lowering prices at a cutthroat pace, some models are selling for half what they cost just several months ago. For any company planning to add new computers or replace older ones, the price wars are good news, at least in the short term.

title:
Commercial Property: 34th Street Partnership;
A Carrot and a Stick to Tone Down the Garishness
description: HAVING made what it considers great strides in cleanliness and security, the 34th Street Partnership has begun trying to make the streetscape less garish.

title: Sarah Griffin, Newell Thompson
description: Sarah Moorehead Griffin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Q. Griffin of Hopewell, N.J., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Newell McLain Thompson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Thompson Jr. of Hopewell. The Rev. Leslie Smith performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church.

title: W. T. Shirley Jr., 60, Real-Estate Developer
description: Walter T. Shirley Jr., who helped his father develop the Long Island community that bears his family name, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

title: A Writer's Best Friend
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: A BRILLIANT MADNESS Living With Manic-Depressive Illness. By Patty Duke and Gloria Hochman. Bantam, $22.50.

title: Talking: Bankruptcy; Can Filing Protect The Home?
description: THE explosion of personal bankruptcies has created confusion about the fate of a debtor's residence. Is bankruptcy a magic wand that can save a home from the onslaught of creditors, including the mortgage holder? Or is it more likely to clean out a homeowner (and even a renter) of everything -- including the home and all its furnishings?

title: INSIDE
description: Courier Loses at Wimbledon To 193d-Ranked Player

title: Streetscapes: Garden Apartments; Waiting in Queens For Historic Status
description: RESIDENTS of the garden apartments of Jackson Heights are hoping that the Landmarks Preservation Commission will soon vote for the designation of the core of the community as a 36-block historic district, protecting their homes from demolition.

title: Dinkins Plan for Homeless Is Criticized
description: The head of a mayoral commission appointed to recommend solutions to the problem of sheltering New York City's homeless is clashing once again with city officials, this time over a plan by the Dinkins administration to move homeless men out of two large shelters.

title: 'Lettice' Without Maggie Smith
description: IT did not seem unthinkable that "Lettice and Lovage" would, one day, go on without Maggie Smith for whose idiosyncratic gifts Peter Shaffer created the role of Lettice Douffet, the tour guide who cannot be bothered with mere facts, in fact, who cannot tolerate anything or anyone "mere."

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FRIENDS' SUMMER SERIES

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE COURAGE OF GIRLS By Jean McGarry. Rutgers University, $22.95.

title: Plucking A Tender Chord
description: To the Editor:

title: The Executive Life; Post-Riot L.A.'s Gun-Toting Liberals
description: For many Hollywood executives weighing the post-riot world of L.A., guns have suddenly become more than the controversial centerpieces of some of their blockbuster films. Strong defenders of big-screen violence are now pondering how to defend themselves against the real kind.

title: Rates Are Just One Piece of the Puzzle
description: President Bush has again urged the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. It was still another reminder that the economic recovery remains sluggish despite short-term rates that have already been cut to their lowest level in 20 years.

title: A Shimmer in the Kitchen
description: Some time in the 1980's, the old stereotype of the brilliant chef as a florid, shouting and temperamental genius gave way to a new stereotype of the brilliant chef as a florid, shouting and temperamental genius who could attain fame on a par with, say, Luciano Pavarotti.

title: Making a Difference; Now Mr. Melamed's Dream Is a Night and Day Reality
description: With the push of a button, Leo Melamed's dream finally came true last week.

title: Wall Street; An OTC Stock's Curious Rally
description: Nothing beats the excitement of getting in on the ground floor. And for a little company called the Ringside International Broadcasting Corporation of Palm Beach, Fla., the "ground floor" was June 12.

title: Scorsese, From the Mean Streets to Charm School
description: In a gilded, gas-lit ballroom, whiskered gentlemen and ladies trailing clouds of tulle and lace waltzed under the fierce scrutiny of Martin Scorsese.

title: Lausanne
description: As top athletes from all continents are warming up to compete for gold medals in Barcelona, scores of international sports officials in the lake city of Lausanne, Switzerland, are already at work planning the 1996 Olympic Games in Atlanta. The preparation, financing and marketing of the Olympics require an organizational effort comparable to mounting a world's fair or a space program -- and it's all done in this pleasant city on the north shore of Lake Geneva.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Lexington Avenue between 34th and 23d streets will be closed from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. today for the Lexington Avenue Festival.

title: After Shoreham Fiasco, Break Up Lilco
description: If the chairman of Lilco [ "New Style Emerges as Lilco Revives," June 18 ] thinks that the company suffered during the 80's with the Shoreham fiasco, what about the innocent ratepayers who have to pay the huge cost of that mess for the next decade?

title: From Country House to Farmhouse
description: TRAVELING in Wales can be a bewildering experience. The Welsh language has a serious grudge against vowels. What should the visitor do when confronted with a sign that reads "Bwlch"? And, compared with its upright Anglo-Saxon cousin across the Severn Bridge, Celtic Wales is an idiosyncratic place -- remote, even wild, in parts.

title: Sixth-Grade Graduation Ceremony: Moment for Pride on Treacherous Path
description: Lakeshea Hill, a graduating sixth grader, gave her teacher the best farewell gift she could afford. It was the message she scribbled across the blackboard of Room 412 last week. It said in part: "I know we gave you a hard time but I'm going to miss you. You taught me to believe in myself."

title: Brazil's President Damaged by Corruption Inquiry
description: Mounting corruption accusations in Brazil's Congress have so damaged President Fernando Collor de Mello that many journalists and politicians have begun to predict one of only two outcomes: that Mr. Collor will resign or, more likely, that he will cling to power as a severely weakened leader until his term runs out almost three years from now.

title: Aurora Journal; Father and Son Reunited at a Shelter
description: The story of a chance reunion after 17 years between a troubled drifter and his troubled son at a homeless mission here is a fairy tale for the 1990's. It involves drugs, domestic abuse, born-again faith, love, loss and maybe even a shot at renewal.

title: Quest for Zoning
description: To the Editor:

title:
OUTDOORS;
The Florida Panther's Fragile Home
description: A cool breeze wafted through the slash pines and made the palmetto fronds rasp and rattle. We came to a mudhole, stopped and knelt. The print was sharp and fresh, three inches wide and three inches from the tip of the leading toe to the back of the pad. It was the track of a Florida panther, one of 30 to 50 surviving in South Florida, the stronghold of the last wild cougars in the East.

title: Minolta Brings Out A New 35-Millimeter
description: WHEN the professional likes and buys a new 35-millimeter camera -- a real seal of approval -- it can become the hot camera in photography. Once amateurs hear the word, they often join the ranks of owners.

title: To Dance, To Dodge
description: Awards night for the Glaucoma Trust, preview night for Ms. Ciccione.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;
Four Historic Residences Up for Auction
description: A SMALL piece of history goes on the block July 14 when the Village of Hastings-on-Hudson auctions off four residences. The auction comes at a time when efforts at historic preservation are lagging because of a lack of financing.

title:
DINING OUT;
Stylish Versions of Regional Italian Fare
description: WHETHER their teams are winning or not, sports fans at the Meadowlands have cause to cheer the arrival of a with-it new trattoria in nearby Wood-Ridge. For those who want to have a good meal before or after the game, Assagia turns out stylish versions of regional Italian dishes at reasonable prices.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: America's Japan Policy: Fractured Vision
description: WHAT IS AMERICAN POLICY toward Japan?

title: President's Wife Can Play a Valuable Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Interview With Clinton on Goals for Presidency
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Gov. Bill Clinton in the Governor's Mansion here on Thursday. The questioners were R. W. Apple Jr., B. Drummond Ayres Jr., Thomas L. Friedman, Steven Greenhouse and Gwen Ifill of The New York Times. Some questions have been edited or paraphrased because of space limitations.

title: Tech Notes; A Bulletin Board Built for Baby
description: Faced with baffling questions about bringing up baby, first-time parents may at last have an alternative to telephone calls to Grandma or the pediatrician. Using a computer and a modem, parents can now log on to an electronic bulletin board that offers an array of child care information.

title: But Is It Art?
description: To the Editor: Your article, "Mirror, Mirror, on the Way" (May 10), regarding shopping abroad, reminded me of two purchases, both supposed to be duty-free, both of which brought trouble.

title: Eberly Pitts, Robert Goldman
description: Eberly Virginia Pitts, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Pitts of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday in Rumson, N.J., to Robert Arthur Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooks C. Goldman of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. George Willis performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Church.

title: Anne Applebaum, Radek Sikorski
description: Anne Elizabeth Applebaum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey M. Applebaum of Washington was married there yesterday to Radek Sikorski, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jan Sikorski of Dwor Chobielin, Poland. Judge Theodore Tannenwald, a senior judge of the United States Tax Court in the District of Columbia, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: The Long, The Mysterious
description: The plunging hemline debate is gaining momentum once more as women experiment with narrower and longer styles for summer. The point of longer skirts is not to make short skirts obsolete. Rather, the length change is part of fashion's perennial search for fresh sensuality and fresh designs.

title: Mary P. Stone, Ross Aiello 3d
description: Mary Patricia Stone, a daughter of Robert L. Stone of Williamstown, Mass., and the late Mary L. Stone, was married yesterday to Ross Robert Aiello 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Aiello Jr. of Pawcatuck, Conn. The Rev. Merle E. Spring, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the United Church of Stonington in Stonington, Conn.

title: Ukrainian National Team Receives a Welcome Celebration at Rutgers
description: To some 25,000 Ukrainian-Americans who were either in attendance or taking part in related activities, this evening's friendly soccer match between the national teams of the United States and Ukraine at Rutgers Stadium was a celebration of independence.

title: A Rockefeller May Take On D'Amato in Primary
description: A new wrinkle may well be added to the race for United States Senator from New York with word from Laurance Rockefeller, the 47-year-old nephew of the late Nelson A. Rockefeller, that he is strongly considering a primary challenge against Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Republican incumbent.

title: Police Officers 'Must Play by the Rules'
description: "MEAN policing leads to mean streets," said the Police Chief of New Haven, Nicholas Pastore. The force responds to the tone set by the leadership, according to Chief Pastore, because "most officers want to get ahead and they will follow the leadership."

title: Spies & Thrillers
description: Suppose Hitler had won World War II. That is the premise of Robert Harris's absorbing, expertly written novel, FATHERLAND (Random House, $21).

title: KNITTING IN CLASS
description: I suppose that it is fashionable for women like Laura Ann Petitto to refer to knitting as a porch activity left over from the days when women did "things like that." There is a tendency, particularly among certain academics, to depict women of past generations as drudges, engaged in mindless activities that symbolized their oppression.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about moves toward the division of Czechoslovakia referred incorrectly to the Slovak Republic election victory of the Movement for Democratic Slovakia this month. The movement won a plurality, not a majority.

title: Low-Skill Immigrants Hurt Job Market for Low-Skill Natives
description: To the Editor:

title: Kim S. Sawyer, Lawrence A. Siff
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Sawyer of Woodbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kim Sherrie Sawyer, to Lawrence Allen Siff, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Siff of Worcester, Mass. A March 1993 wedding is planned.

title: Mutual Funds; A Double Pinch of Rates and Fees
description: Adjustable rate mortgage funds were developed to give investors relatively high and steady yields.

title: Overreach
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria A. Beers, Northrup Knox Jr.
description: Victoria A. Beers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Beers of Fayetteville, N.C., was married yesterday to Northrup R. Knox Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Knox of Buffalo. The Rev. Michael Hartney, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Matthias Church in East Aurora, N.Y.

title: Stress Test; Once Again, Questions of Character
description: WHEN Robert S. McNamara went from running the Ford Motor Company to running the Pentagon, he impressed President Kennedy at first with his bluntness and managerial skills. But Mr. Kennedy soon realized that Mr. McNamara's lack of political seasoning could be dangerous.

title: Sex Without Fear
description: WOMAN OF VALOR Margaret Sanger and the Birth Control Movement in America. By Ellen Chesler. Illustrated. 639 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $27.50.

title:
FORUM;
Focus on Growth, Not Short Rates
description: President Bush may be right about the need for lower interest rates, but jawboning the Federal Reserve as he did last week could actually undermine his goal of more rapid economic growth. The public needs pro-growth fiscal policies from the President much more than another small decline in short-term interest rates. The Fed has already tamed inflation. Giving in to political pressure now could jeopardize this achievement and the recovery as well.

title: THE ISLAMIC WAVE
description: In her superb report on the impact of Islamic fundamentalism on governments and societies in the Arab world, Miller notes that the resurgence of militant Islam is fueled by a longing for the restoration of Arab "pride and dignity."

title:
Making a Difference;
The Bold Autocrat at BMW's Wheel
description: Eberhard von Kuenheim had just finished explaining at a news conference here last week why Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. had decided to build an assembly plant in Spartanburg, S.C., when a local reporter fired off what was intended as a sarcastic question. Having taken this dramatic step away from Germany, he asked, would the company now be building other factories in North America, or even Asia?

title: Whining To the Bank
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
ART REVIEW;
'Flowers' and Modern Masters
description: WITH the gardening season in full swing, the Nassau County Museum of Art exhibition "An Ode to Gardens and Flowers" is an appropriate complement to the beauties of nature that are abundantly in evidence.

title: N.F.L. Refrain: Take It or Leave It
description: A popular theme sounded last week by National Football League lawyers in the Freeman McNeil v. the N.F.L. antitrust suit about free agency in United States District Court in Minneapolis was that owners do not hold all of the chips and all of the leverage in negotiating contracts with players.

title: BIG PALERMO RALLY ASSAILS MAFIA GRIP
description: They came from across the land by train, plane and ferryboat, bearing bright banners and sharp anger, filling this Mafia fief with protest and urging that Sicilians break the compact of silence that sustains and shields the mob.

title: THE ISLAMIC WAVE
description: By emphasizing the sensational and exotic aspects of Islam, Judith Miller's article "The Islamic Wave" (May 31) contributes to the already overwhelmingly negative body of work about one of the world's greatest and most diverse religious communities. As examples, the headline, opening passages and photographs all emphasize the prevalent stereotype of Muslims as uneducated, militant and enigmatic.

title: A Jolt of Cool
description: LIKE THE BELL OF AN ICE-CREAM truck crashing through the still air of a summer afternoon, sorbet or granite can give you a start. Its temperature, simultaneously lip-numbing and a relief to the soul, mimics the double-edged thrill of a Popsicle. And then the freeze fades to flavor, which is another jolt. Made well, fruit ices are hyperbole, more intensely fruit than the fruit they're wrought from. They take your breath away.

title: Making the Most of a Little Bacon Can Capture the Flavor
description: BACON is a frequent treat. It is treasured for its rich, smoky flavor. But on a sensible diet, its high fat content, about 80 percent, and sodium, an average 150 milligrams in a slice, make it something to be consumed sparingly.

title: Gield Schools on Cape Cod
description: A series of weeklong field schools begins July 12 at the Massachusetts Audubon Society's Wellfleet Bay Wildlife Sanctuary in Wellfleet on Cape Cod. Subjects include local archeology, coastal botany, birding, natural history, art and nature photography. Programs emphasize field trips, which might be a whale watch, a seabird cruise from Provincetown or a jaunt to Monomoy National Wildlife Refuge. Other fieldwork sends students to the Cape Cod National Seashore, the Prov incelands dunes and Coast Guard Beach in Eastham.

title: High Life
description: WALKING around in circles but never getting to the top. The myth of Sisyphus? Dante's "Inferno" upside down? No. It was the Guggenheim's black-tie reception on Wednesday night.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GOLF EVENT FOR THE BLIND

title: Nearly Flawless Frost Leads by 3
description: Continuing to playing unspectacular but nearly mistake-free golf, David Frost increased his lead to three strokes in the Buick Classic this afternoon.

title: 'Batman Returns' With a Capeload Of Angst and Ills
description: The story was sad and lurid, and if it had happened in New York City it would have been a natural for late-night television news. "Abandoned baby found alive in sewer! Details at 11!" The anchorwoman would shake her head ever so slightly after reading this heartbreaking report. In a follow-up, politicians would bemoan the lack of family values, and a child psychiatrist would foresee severe identity problems.

title: Shoppingus Mallus Romanus
description: In a city where neon is a sacrament, it takes a lot to get noticed.

title: President's Wife Can Play a Valuable Role; She's Not Elected
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul de Man: The Plot Thickens
description: To the Editor:

title: A Media Pioneer's Quest: Portable Electronic Newspapers
description: In A favorite dream, Roger Fidler envisions a row of commuters reaching into their briefcases on their ride to work. Instead of pulling out the morning paper, each grabs a thin, tablet-sized computer and a pen.

title: Ye Shall Be as Goddesses
description: THE MYTH OF THE GODDESS Evolution of an Image. By Anne Baring and Jules Cashford. Illustrated. 779 pp. New York: Viking Arkana. $40.

title: Jennifer Bradley, J. Carlo Cannell
description: Mr. and Mrs. E. Michael Bradley of New York and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Treat Bradley, to J. Carlo Cannell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Best Cannell of New York and Lattingtown, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: Melissa Micol, Stephen Porter
description: Melissa Denise Micol, the daughter of Roger L. Micol of Chelmsford, Mass., and Barbara Dowker Micol of Dunedin, Fla., was married yesterday in Chelmsford to Stephen Burr Porter, the son of Michael Porter of Chebeaque Island, Me., and Dr. Laurel Porter of New York. The Rev. Hugh Evans performed the ceremony at the Central Congregational Church.

title: 'Stolen Continents'
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. and Microsoft Settle Operating-System Feud
description: The world's largest computer maker, I.B.M., and the most influential software company, Microsoft, have settled a noisy rift by agreeing to pursue divergent paths without legal and financial squabbling.

title: Lindros Officially an Ex-Nordique
description: The Quebec Nordiques no longer own the National Hockey League rights to ERIC LINDROS. That much was clear when LARRY BERTUZZI, the Toronto lawyer hired by the N.H.L. to arbitrate the trade dispute involving the player, announced at 2:20 A.M. yesterday that he had finished his hearings and would render a decision next week.

title:
RECORDINGS VIEW;
A Gripping Opera From a Wagnerian Primitive
description: The composer Mily Balakirev said of Aleksandr Serov's 1863 opera "Judith," "If I ever find it strong, I'll know my brains are going bad." Now, most unexpectedly, we can all measure our brains against Balakirev's, thanks to a recording of "Judith" by Le Chant du Monde (LDC 288 035/6; two CD's).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The decision to break a promise of lifetime health benefits may represent a straightforward business decision for an employer. However, for the retirees who relied on such promises and now face an uncertain financial future, the decision is a betrayal." -- CATHY VENTRELL-MONSEES, a benefits-policy manager with the American Association of Retired Persons. [ 1:3. ]

title: For Home and Homeland
description: A HISTORY OF THE JEWS IN AMERICA

title: Nicole Tempest, Robert Keller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harrison F. Tempest of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nicole Suzanne Tempest, to Robert Andrew Keller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald H. Keller of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Pained Neighbors Recall Slain Owner of South Bronx Bodega
description: They gathered outside the shuttered bodega on Dawson Street in the South Bronx yesterday and remembered its owner, Fulvio Jimenez, as a good man who had tried to soften the edges of a hard neighborhood with his jokes and kindness, who had given candy to the children and had trusted people for a few dollars or a few items from his shelves.

title: Elizabeth S. Kline, Henry Collins 3d
description: Elizabeth Suzanne Kline, the daughter of Dr. Kenneth K. Kline and Elizabeth S. Kline, both of Wheeling, W.Va., was married yesterday to Henry Lafayette Collins 3d, the son of Mrs. C. Edward Pacaud of Berwyn, Pa., and the late Mr. Collins Jr. Judge Elizabeth Shequine, a family court judge in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., performed the civil ceremony at the bride's home in LaGrangeville, N.Y.

title: Serbs Defy Ultimatum From U.N. And Persist in Shelling Sarajevo
description: Serbian forces continued to shell Sarajevo with sporadic artillery fire today, the day after the United Nations Security Council issued an ultimatum to the Serbians to halt fighting and put their heavy guns under United Nations control within 48 hours.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: I AM THE CLAY By Chaim Potok. Knopf, $20.

title: CURRENCY
IN SHORT: FICTION
description: GRACED LAND By Laura Kalpakian. Grove Weidenfeld, $18.95.

title: Salmon Catches In the Northwest
description: Saltwater sports fishermen with visions of landing the Pacific Northwest's prized salmon this summer should be aware that the season has been shortened and fewer fish can be caught in Washington state waters. Efforts to protect endangered species and the need to build up weak stocks are triggering the emergency restrictions, which were announced last month.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: EARLY FILMING

title: Geneticists' Latest Discovery: Public Fear of 'Frankenfood'
description: Exhibits of Pfizer's Chy-max, a genetically engineered coagulant, bloomed alongside displays for the Santa Cruz Valley Pecan Company and Sunsweet Prunes at the annual meeting of the Institute of Food Technologists this week in New Orleans.

title: Carolyn Weiss, C. L. Clayton
description: Ronald W. Weiss and Nancy S. Nelson, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Whitman Weiss to Christopher Laurence Clayton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Clayton of Short Hills, N.J. A November wedding is planned.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Rabbi Gerald L. Zelizer;
The Struggle to Prevent Intermarriage
description: THE spartan second-floor space overlooking the parking lot of Congregation Neve Shalom here was Rabbi Gerald L. Zelizer's personal choice for an office. "Trappings are not important to me," said the synagogue's spiritual leader, a fourth-generation rabbi. He admits to simple preferences: "I have one wife, one son and one God."

title: The MAn From Texarkana
description: "MY MOST VIVID MEMORY of politics," says Ross Perot as he recollects growing up in the little border town of Texarkana, Tex., "is that my dad once bet a friend that he could pick anyone he wanted to, and my dad could get him elected to the Arkansas State Legislature."

title: Fans Like It. Drivers Like It. Stock Cars a Natural for Indy?
description: The Indianapolis Motor Speedway last week took the first step in what could become the biggest breach of sporting tradition since the lights went on at Wrigley Field.

title: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Greenlawn 275,000 27 Old Hills Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, great room, pool, c/a; taxes $5,400. Huntington 162,000 78 Sammis Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 70-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Lynbrook 195,000 22 Leaman Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old colonial; dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,700. St. James 227,000 116 Hobson Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 17-year-old colonial; dining room, family room, basement, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $5,400. Valley Stream 144,000 136 Copiague Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 51-year-old ranch; finished basement, 1-car detached garage; taxes $2,700. Woodbury 645,000 11 Yukon Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, family room, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $15,000. OTHER AREAS South Salem, N.Y. 135,000 88 Fox Run 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old garden condominium; fireplace, dining room, eat-in kitchen, patio; taxes $3,397. Clinton, Conn. 98,000 48 Long Hill Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; deck, needs work, 1 acre; taxes $1,631. Englewood, N.J. 169,000 295 West Hudson Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 65-year-old colonial; French doors, h/w floors; taxes $3,850.

title: No-Frills Insurance Proposed for Cars
description: AFTER years of paying some of the highest automobile insurance premiums in the country, New Jersey motorists may soon be able to purchase bare-bones insurance for as little as $250 a year.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: SCOTTISH GAMES

title: Luminaries At the Met
description: The Candace Awards, at the Metropolitan Museum, honoring black women.

title: IN YOUR FACE
description: The expression "in your face" may appear to have come in vogue only recently because it is used so frequently by white television commentators and sports writers who want to appear hip, but it has been around longer than the slam dunk (On Language: "In Your Face," by William Safire, May 31).

title: Sandy Amoros, World Series Star for Dodgers in 1955, Dies at 62
description: Sandy Amoros, who dashed across the Yankee Stadium outfield in Game 7 of the 1955 World Series and caught a piece of baseball immortality when he turned a deep Yankee drive into a spectacular Series-saving double play for the Brooklyn Dodgers, died yesterday in Miami. He was 62 years old.

title: In East Europe, the Hapsburgs Get Revenge; What's in a Hyphen?
description: To the Editor:

title: KNITTING IN CLASS
description: What a variety of responses there have been to Perri Klass's Hers column "A Stitch in Time" (Letters, May 10 and 17 and June 7). My reaction to her essay was that here at last was a respected professional who shared my discovery that knitting could enhance one's concentration. If I cannot knit, I have to take notes (which I may never look at again) to prevent my mind from wandering. MARILYN SUTTON LOOS Radnor, Pa.

title: Faith Grietzer, D. P. C. Frankel
description: Dr. Faith Ellen Grietzer, a daughter of Clare Grietzer of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late George Grietzer, was married yesterday in Washington to Dr. Douglas Price Charles Frankel, a son of Florence N. Frankel of Hackensack, N.J., and the late Julius Frankel. Cantor Harold Levy performed the ceremony at the Kennedy-Warren, a restaurant.

title: On Coming of Age on a Changing Long Island
description: "THIS is the story of my face" is how Sheila Gray introduces "Nissequott," a novel published this month by the New Directions Press.

title: Libyan Doubts About Qaddafi Are Growing
description: THE United Nations sanctions that went into effect against Libya last April are turning out to be more than a symbolic gesture. While they have not yet accomplished their purpose of compelling Libya to turn over two suspects wanted in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, they have been politically damaging to the mercurial Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Gail E. Leopold, David Jon Pester
description: Miriam L. and James F. Leopold of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Eileen Leopold, to David Jon Pester, a son of Dorothy and Monroe Pester of Roslyn, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: Silencing the Best and Brightest
description: TIME FOR TELLING TRUTH IS RUNNING OUT

title:
MUSIC;
'South of the Border' At Waterloo Festival
description: FOR several years, the Waterloo Music Festival's six-week classical season has presented some unusual repertory and major American works. The festival's directors, Gerard Schwarz, the principal conductor, and Samuel Lipman, the artistic director, have stuck to their convictions despite the criticism that nontraditional programming has produced a decline in audiences.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
At Last, a New Arena to Rise
description: AN agreement by three Boston banks to provide a $120 million loan has set the stage for a start on a $160 million arena for the Celtics and Bruins, the basketball and hockey teams. Delaware North of Buffalo, the owner of the Boston Garden and the Bruins, is providing the remaining $40 million.

title: Ms. D'Amario, Edmund Price
description: Elizabeth Vincent D'Amario, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony V. D'Amario of Westwood, Mass., was married yesterday in Boston to Edmund Hazleton Price, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Price of Lexington, Mass. The Rev. Michael Groden performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Cecilia's Church.

title: Russian Qualifies as a Wimbledon Giant-Killer
description: Jim Courier may have attempted to downplay his third-round loss to a player whose own coach describes him as a virtual nobody, but the Floridian made the wrong sort of Wimbledon history today by becoming the first top-seeded player in the Open era to lose to a qualifier.

title: World Markets; The Rocky Road to a Global Market
description: "Our market will be the market where the action will take place," said Jean-Francois Theodore, the chief executive officer of the Bourse de Paris. It is the kind of comment expected of a man in his job, especially when he is visiting the United States to drum up business for the French stock market.

title: This Week's Numbers
JUNE 21-27: Life Without Parole; Pending Appeal, Gotti Is Dispatched to Prison
description: With defense lawyers already working on his appeal, John Gotti was whisked last week from a Manhattan jail to the Federal prison in Marion, Ill. It came as no surprise that the authorities chose what is considered the toughest prison in the country for the convicted boss of the Gambino crime family. Nor was it any surprise that Judge I. Leo Glasser sentenced him to life in prison.

title: 4 Towns Unite Patrols For Holiday Weekend
description: MOTORISTS driving in Fairfield County this July 4th weekend should be sure that they are not speeding, driving drunk or breaking any motor vehicle laws on the roads in Westport, Norwalk, Weston and Wilton. For the holiday weekend the four communities have formed the Mid-Fairfield County Selective Enforcement Unit, a compact in which police officers from each of the municipalities join together to catch drivers breaking the laws.

title: Ontario's Lode of Black History
description: "FAREWELL, old master/Don't come after me/I'm on my way to Canada/Where colored men are free," they sang, along with "Follow the Drinking Gourd," their code name for the Big Dipper, which, like the North Star and the moss on tree trunks, pointed north toward freedom.

title: A Plan to Conserve New York's Wilderness
description: Conserving Open Space in New York State, a plan released last week, is an effort by state officials to define which unprotected parcels should be preserved for future generations.

title:
BACKTALK;
When Protest Made a Clean Sweep
description: For a while it looked as if the Olympics in Barcelona might be spared the political and social concerns that have been a major preoccupation at the Games for more than 60 years. But the carnage in the former republics of Yugoslavia means that nation will probably be barred from the 1992 Games, and the massacre last week in Boipatong township 35 miles south of Johannesburg has led the African National Congress to call for a continuation of the sports isolation of South Africa. In light of these developments, this is a good time to look back on the most dramatic political statement made during an Olympic Games and how it has been misunderstood by most people.

title: Privileged Witness
description: LEONARD FREED

title: What Writers Earn
description: To the Editor:

title: White Gowns, Plaids and Hoops: Diversity in Wedding Traditions
description: IN time for the annual high season for weddings, the Stamford Historical Society is offering a double exhibition called "Wedding Belles: Bridal Fashions Then and Now" and "A Wedding Album," on view through Aug. 16.

title: Ms. Corry, Mr. Farnsworth
description: John Corry of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter Janet Marie Corry to Ward Farnsworth Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Farnsworth Sr. of Winnetka, Ill. The couple is to be married in September. Ms. Corry is also a daughter of the late Irmtraut Wolff. She is a stepdaughter of Sonia Landau.

title: Beckoned by the Greens, Not the Gang
description: In the dense, sweet heat of the afternoon, gang members loaf along the pale-blue brick walls of the Ramona Gardens housing project. This is Big Hazard turf. Tattoos twitch on jail-built biceps. The gang members snicker and point as Jose Navarro staggers past them. The chunky 15-year-old is bent under a bag filled with golf clubs.

title: G.O.P. Vows Budget Fight With Florio
description: New Jersey's Republican leaders vowed today to override Gov. Jim Florio's veto of their $14.6 million budget and use their subpoena power to insure that their budget is carried out.

title: The Boom in Off-Campus Credits
description: DRESSED in jeans and sneakers, Jane Battista slouched on the sofa in her living room in Long Branch, intently watching the television screen across the room. She scribbled notes on the yellow legal pad on her lap and occasionally consulted the open textbook at her side.

title: How This Corresponds to That
description: FEARFUL SYMMETRY Is God a Geometer? By Ian Stewart and Martin Golubitsky. Illustrated. 287 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Blackwell Publishers. $21.95.

title: SINKING FAST
description: Alvarez notes current poor market conditions. What he omits is the practice by some unscrupulous owners of scuttling ships to collect inflated insurance when profitable sale is impossible. An owner can arrange this by paying the master and officers, while repatriating the third world crew, before any investigation can take place. As any fire marshal in the Bronx knows, arson is difficult to prove. TOM MENARD Bronx

title: Sylvie Otten, Kurt Sollod
description: Dr. and Mrs. Michael Otten of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sylvie Otten, to Kurt Anthony Sollod, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert E. Sollod of Shrewsbury, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: Fitness Freak
description: When a would-be novelist tries to make his way through the thickets of Hollywood, the dangers are many, as Paul Brock, the hero of Avery Corman's new novel, "The Big Hype," discovers. In this excerpt from the book, to be published this week, Brock learns some lessons about the world of TV movie making.

title: Cynthia Smith, Charles Wilson Jr.
description: Cynthia Ann Smith, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David M. Smith of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Charles Ernst Wilson Jr., the son of Mr. Wilson and Marilyn L. Morrison, both of St. Louis. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston Jr. performed the ceremony at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: West Coast Color
description: Truth is, most men in southern California do not dress as if they're on their way to a volleyball tournament on Zuma Beach. In fact, three West Coast designers are spreading a sense of style that happily owes little to a surfboard, and even less to a Seventh Avenue drawing board.

title: Breakfast Customer Kills Diner Owner
description: A man who had just finished breakfast with another man in a Brooklyn diner yesterday morning walked to the cash register and shot the owner to death without saying a word, the police said.

title: The Take on Voice
description: In the soap opera "Santa Barbara," an irate father complains about his teen-age daughter's relationship with a newspaper publisher. The publisher's girlfriend, Angela, quickly straightens the father out: "You think they were sleeping together? You have the wrong take on this situation."

title: POSTINGS: Doing It Right; Renovations on Landmarks
description: Many questions arise when apartment owners contemplate exterior alterations to buildings that are either individually designated landmarks or located in historic districts.

title: Nancy Kalkin, Lincoln Miller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Kalkin of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Beth Kalkin, to Dr. Lincoln Paul Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Miller of Great Neck, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Exploring Interesting Restaurants Near the Expressway
description: THE Long Island Expressway is the Island's spine. It starts at the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and crosses nearly all of Nassau and Suffolk Counties before it ends about 70 miles to the east.

title: Droll Troll, $130
description: He ain't heavy, he's my backpack. These endearing, ridiculous, vaguely folkloric rubber backpacks are cast from a mold, then hand painted, by T. Oliver Kopian Designs of New York and Miami.

title: Kerry Brady, T. P. McDonnell
description: Mr. and Mrs. James C. Brady Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kerry Chace Brady to Terence Peter McDonnell, a son of Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., and the late Mr. McDonnell. A September wedding is planned.

title: JUNE 21-27: Congress; Democrats Outmaneuver A G.O.P. Spending Trap
description: When the House defeated the balanced budget constitutional amendment early this month, Congressional Republicans thought they had a great election issue. Democrats killed the amendment, saying it was no substitute for making hard choices on every spending bill. Swell, thought the Republicans; we'll use every appropriations bill to show that Democrats only give lip service to deficit reduction while they vote for big spending.

title: Mexico Is Now Acting to Protect Border Migrants From Robbery and Abuse
description: Just a few years ago, the desolate canyons that wind down from Tijuana's last cinder-block barrios to the subdivisions of San Ysidro, Calif., became a symbol of the border as a no man's land.

title: Reluctance Over a Farmers Market In Ossining
description: PLANT a seed and watch it grow or will it? Farmers know it's not so simple, and one organizer of a Westchester farmers market has learned that lesson as well.

title: At 45, Levittown's Legacy Is Unclear
description: IT is 45 years since the Levitt Company opened its community of unpretentious Cape Cod-style houses on 1,000 acres of former potato fields and truck farms in Island Trees in Nassau County.

title: He Who Stripped Is Not A Stripper
