description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for this week: MONDAY Ameron Inc Del Unocal Corp TUESDAY Delmarva Power & Light Super Valu Stores WEDNESDAY Corning Inc Natl City Corp (Cleve) Nevada Power Rockwell Intl Corp THURSDAY Amer Water Works Excelsior Income Shs PNC Finl Corp Sun Inc FRIDAY Snyder Oil Corp U S West Inc

title: Prisoners of War -- and Deception
description: The Pentagon knew better. Hanoi knew better. Yet in April 1973, the Nixon Administration insisted it had no indication "that there are any Americans alive in Indochina." Those words concealed a startling fact: The Administration did have the names of 244 Americans who had been captured alive but who failed to return with the other prisoners of war Hanoi released that year.

title: Winnebago Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-After a loss of $ 610,000 from discontinued operations in the quarter and 9 months.c-Net lossd-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 951,000 in the quarter and $ 4.2 million in the 9 months.

title: Univar Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Mitterrand Trip Welcomed Only in Paris and Sarajevo
description: President Francois Mitterrand returned today from a daring six-hour visit to Sarajevo to face the dismay of Germany and his other European partners, the praise of most French people and the prospect of further friction in his country's strained relations with Washington.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising -- Addenda; Miscellany
description: * Veronis, Suhler & Associates Inc., an investment banking firm that specializes in the communications industry, is predicting a 7.4 percent compounded growth rate for United States spending on advertising and promotion in the next five years, compared with the 5.2 percent annual rate of the last five years. Spending is predicted to reach $340.5 billion by 1996, up from $238.1 billion in 1991. * The Association of National Advertisers Inc. and the American Advertising Federation denounced the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority's decision to ban all tobacco advertising on the transit system as "unconsitutional, unfair, outrageous and undemocratic."

title: Sandra Holden, A. N. Rosenberg
description: Sandra Haley Holden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Scott H. Holden of Perth, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew Neil Rosenberg, a son of Robert C. Rosenberg of New York and the late Diane Rosenberg. The Rev. James C. Gulley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., with Rabbi Alvin Roth attending.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN -- Voices: Miami; On the Economy, Well-Being and Confidence
description: Political experts, local officials and ordinary voters in several cities were asked to appraise President Bush's handling of the economy. ESTEBAN FERRER 65, law partner in the international division of the law firm Shutts & Bowen

title: Bridge
description: The modern one no-trump response, forcing for one round, is more heavily loaded than the old-fashioned non-forcing variety. This is workable provided players resist the temptation to use the bid when a clearer alternative is available. On the diagramed deal North should certainly have responded two diamonds to one spade. As it was, he was in difficulty when his partner followed with three clubs, showing a big hand.

title: Price Tag: Summer Games
description: What it might cost, per person, to attend events or participate in selected activities outdoors this summer in the New York City area. Costs may vary in other ares. Transportation, parking and special equipment are not included unless noted. New York Mets game, Flushing, Queens Admisstion: $12 (reserved seats; children under 32 inches tall admitted free) Refreshments: $6.50 Program: $2 Souvenirs: $8 TOTAL: $28.50 Jones Beach State Park, Long Island Admission: Free Lunch from concession stand: $7 Parking: $4 per automobile TOTAL: $11 Bethpage State Park, Long Island Greens fee: $14 (18 holes) Lunch in park restaurant: $8 Electric cart: $23 TOTAL: With cart $45, without cart: $22 Roberto Clemente Park, the Bronx Admisstion: Free Lunch from concessikon stand: $7 Swimming pool entry feee: $1.50 TOTAL: $8.50 A 5-mile race, Central Park, Manhattan Entry fee: $9 (includes T-shirt) Refreshments after the race: $3 TOTAL: $12 (Sources: New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation; New York Mets; New York Road Runners Club)

title: Jennifer Hersch, Daniel Meron
description: Jennifer Rachel Hersch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Hersch of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Daniel Meron, a son of Theodor Meron and Roxandra Meron, both of New York. Rabbi David H. Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: Dance in Review
description: Fay Simpson Dance Theater Manhattan Class Company Theater

title: Forging New Insight on Minimum Wages and Jobs
description: Contrary to one of the most widely accepted orthodoxies of modern economics, raising the Federal minimum wage may not prompt employers to trim jobs, new studies suggest, and therefore may not be such a bad way to help America's working poor.

title: A Little Labor Friction Slows Convention Momentum
description: The Democratic Party, traditionally the party of organized labor, has been caught in an unexpected labor dispute as it prepares for the convention at Madison Square Garden. A four-day standoff kept power cables linking portable generators parked on the sidewalk to the television networks' nearby trailers from being hooked up on schedule last week.

title: Arens Faults Prime Minister's 'Greater Israel' Concept
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens criticized some of his Government's peace and security policies today in a published interview in which he also said Israel had ignored Palestinians in the occupied territories for too long.

title: Bridge
description: The modern one no-trump response, forcing for one round, is more heavily loaded than the old-fashioned non-forcing variety. This is workable provided players resist the temptation to use the bid when a clearer alternative is available. On the diagramed deal North should certainly have responded two diamonds to one spade. As it was, he was in difficulty when his partner followed with three clubs, showing a big hand.

title: 2 Quakes May Have Raised Chances for a Bigger Temblor
description: Seismologists had depressing news for frightened Southern Californians in the wake of today's two powerful earthquakes.

title: Do Double Standards Apply at Fox?
description: The same week that Rupert Murdoch dismissed Stephen Chao for having a male stripper remove all his clothing in front of a crowd that included the Secretary of Defense, Mr. Chao's most recent television creation for Fox Inc. reported its best results ever.

title: Leary, Yankees Are Warned by League
description: Bobby Brown, the American League president, yesterday labeled Tim Leary's camera-caught actions "highly suspicious," but he nevertheless denied the Baltimore Orioles' protest of their game with the Yankees in which they accused the pitcher of scuffing baseballs.

title: Triplecast: An Olympian Blunder or Innovation?
description: When NBC agreed in December 1988 to pay $401 million for the broadcasting rights to the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, the television network believed it had a better idea: a pay-per-view venture with Cablevision Systems of Long Island that would provide 15 days of round-the-clock Olympics coverage, but, more important, would help to recoup the $100 million NBC was certain to lose from its inflated bid.

title: Johnson Products Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 583,000, or 49 cents a share, in nthe quarter and $ 936,000, or 78 cents a share, in the 9 months, from tax loss carryforwards.c-After extraordinary credits of $ 310,000, or 26 cents a share, and $ 668,000, or 56 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Cimarron Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Joanne Moriarty, C. J. Aventuro
description: Joanne Marie Moriarty, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Moriarty of East Atlantic Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Christopher John Aventuro, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Aventuro of Chestnut Ridge, N.Y. Msgr. James P. Kelly performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Ignatius Martyr Church in Long Beach, L.I.

title: Life in the Minor Leagues
description: DAVID LAMB's passion for minor league baseball continues. He was in the stands at Hagerstown, Md., last Wednesday night watching the local team, the Suns, thrash the New Britain Red Sox in an Eastern League tilt. Lamb, who is 51 years old, expects that he will be going to minor league -- not major league -- games for the rest of his life. It's the intimacy and the atmosphere that count.

title: Japan's Top Party Agrees To Give Economy a Push
description: Japan's ruling party agreed over the weekend on a broad plan to stimulate the nation's sagging economy through increased Government spending and other measures worth more than $45 billion for the current fiscal year.

title: Challenging a Myth in Los Angeles
description: The young people of South-Central Los Angeles who try to make life work are almost invisible. News about their riot-torn community leaves the impression that black and Hispanic teen-agers are mostly gang members and welfare spongers. To learn how misleading that is, ask the Walt Disney Company.

title:
BASEBALL:AROUND THE MAJORS;
Dempsey, at 42, Is Ageless Oriole
description: No longer a baseball anomaly, Rick Dempsey is wearing his Baltimore Orioles uniform with a lot more pride.

title: Erica Prager, Jeffrey Hessel
description: Erica Lynn Prager, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Prager of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Hessel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Hessel of Huntington, L.I. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Judith Karpen, Steven Schoenhaus
description: Judith Karpen, a daughter of Lynn Karpen and the late Sanford Karpen of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Steven Schoenhaus, the son of Edythe Jussim of Tamarac, Fla., and the late Robert Schoenhaus. Rabbi Marjorie Slome performed the ceremony in the gardens at Snug Harbor Cultural Center in Livingston, S.I.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Frost Turns Buick Into Pushover
description: Playing that most elusive of games, natural golf, David Frost catapulted out of the worst slump of his career by cruising to an astonishing eight-shot victory today in the Buick Classic.

title: Some Old Track Heroes Fade Away
description: When the United States Olympic track and field trials ended tonight, there was joy for such heroes as Jim Spivey, Michael Johnson, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Gwen Torrence and Gail Devers. There was no joy for many others such as Mary Decker Slaney, Joe Falcon, Steve Scott, Greg Foster, Roger Kingdom and even Carl Lewis.

title: Question Box
description: Most Walks on Purpose

title: Allan Jones, 84, Hollywood Singing Star, Is Dead
description: Allan Jones, a Hollywood singing star in the 1930's and 40's whose romantic tenor rang out in 35 films, including "Show Boat," with Irene Dunne, died on Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Observer; Bush League Bogart
description: The White House professes shock and sorrow at evidence that Ross Perot likes to snoop around in people's lives -- likes to have people -- believe it or not -- investigated.

title: Agreement Reached on Restoring $900 Million for School Rebuilding, Officials Say
description: The Dinkins administration and the Board of Education have agreed to a plan that would restore $900 million to the long-term effort to rebuild New York City's schools, officials involved in the talks said yesterday.

title: Critic's Notebook; For a Date (Wink) Or a Tease (Smirk), Try Late-Night TV
description: Looking for a date? Problem with nail fungus? How about plugging into a personal psychic? Hang around after the late-night news and commercial television will do its best to satisfy you, preferably with a strategically placed tickle.

title: Furiously, Indeed
description: Shug McGaughey stood outside Barn 20 at Belmont Park and reflected on the highs and lows of life with a prodigy. Inside the stall stood the prodigy: the sensationally named colt Furiously, who has won his first three races in a blaze by a combined total of 31 lengths. That is, furiously.

title: Mongolia Ex-Communists Said to Win Vote
description: Opposition political parties said today that they had lost overwhelmingly in the election on Sunday and that the former Communist Party had won 72 of the 76 seats in the new Parliament.

title: Resort Wear for Sea, Shore or Wherever
description: Fashion in its inexorable way is going into its next phase. Fall clothes are moving out of the workrooms into the stores. By the middle of October, when they begin to look familiar and tired on the racks, the fall styles will be supplemented by new styles from collections called -- not totally appropriately -- resort and cruise. The first wave of these collections by both European and American designers began breaking in showrooms in New York last week.

title: Colony Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Long Battles Over Abortion Are Seen
description: Both sides in the abortion debate said that yesterday's decision in Planned Parenthood v. Casey guaranteed many more years of legislation and litigation over how far states may go to restrict abortion.

title: Tapie Considers Adidas Sale
description: Bernard Tapie Finance will be a holding company with assets of only cash if it decides in the next few weeks to sell majority stakes in Adidas A.G. and other industrial companies, its finance director and acting chief executive said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the transplanting of a baboon's liver into a human patient referred incorrectly to previous uses of animal organs in humans. At least 33 other operations have involved animal organs, but not all have been from baboons. Further reporting on the latest operation appears today on page C3.

title: In Russia, Makarova Stars on the Stage, But Not as a Dancer
description: When Natalia Makarova was 12 years old, she gave a reading at a Young Communist Pioneers' Club here and brought her audience to tears. The next year, she entered the Vaganova ballet school and put her acting ambitions aside.

title: Algerian President Fatally Shot at Rally
description: The President of Algeria's ruling Supreme State Council, which was installed after a military coup in January, was assassinated today.

title: Jay Jacobs reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: b-After a net charge of $ 440,000 for losses expected to be incurred in connection with the closure of four stores in Southern California.

title: McEnroe Moves Up but Lendl Bows Out
description: John McEnroe, a trifle grass-stained but otherwise chomping at the bit like a colt instead of the war horse that he is, stayed on course at Wimbledon today. But Ivan Lendl, never a front-runner on turf, foundered altogether.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASKETBALL Sabonis Dominates Arvidas Sabonis scored 33 points and had 16 rebounds as Lithuania rallied for a 99-89 victory over Croatia in the European Olympic qualifying tournament yesterday in Zaragoza, Spain. Sabonis, the starting center on the Soviet Union's 1988 gold-medal Olympic team and a two-time draftee of the Portland Trail Blazers, added three assists and two blocked shots as Lithuania improved to 2-0. Only the top four teams in this eight-team round-robin will advance to the Olympics in Barcelona. Germany beat Israel to also become 2-0. (AP) GOLF Stamberger Leads in Ike Mike Stamberger of Plainfield, N.J., shot a two-under-par 69 and took the first-round lead in the Metropolitan Golf Association Ike Tournament at the Shorehaven Golf Club in East Norwalk, Conn. Stamberger holds a one-stroke lead over Mike Muehr of Roxiticus and R.J. Nakashian of Glen Cove, who had rounds of 70 at the 6,520-yard course. The field of 124 was trimmed to 44 for today's final. Nakashian and Mike Meehan, who had 71, hold the team lead with 141.

title: Europeans Lift Bar to Insurers
description: Insurance companies registered in one European Community country will be able to sell life insurance policies throughout the 12-nation group under a directive approved by ministers meeting here, community officials said today.

title: Third World Women Aren't the Big Polluters; There's Plenty of Room
description: To the Editor:

title: Avis Raising Rental Rates In New York
description: Six months after Hertz imposed surcharges of as much as $56 a day on car rentals in the metropolitan region by New York City residents, Avis said yesterday that it would raise its rates in the area by 25 percent now and perhaps 25 percent more in the coming months. Avis also said it would cut back on the number of cars it rents in the area.

title: Thailand Sets General Election for Sept. 13
description: Thailand, recovering from weeks of political turmoil, will dissolve its Parliament on Tuesday and hold general elections on Sept. 13, the interim Prime Minister announced today.

title: Mikhail Tal, a Chess Grandmaster Known for His Daring, Dies at 55
description: Mikhail Tal, a Latvian grandmaster who held the world chess championship in 1960-61 and was one of the game's most popular and exciting players, died in Moscow on Sunday after a long illness, the Russian news agency Itar-Tass reported. He was 55 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: More travails for SALLY JESSY RAPHAEL: Her 19-year-old son JASON SODERLUND, who was severely injured in an automobile accident in January, was involved in another car accident on Sunday. He was not seriously hurt, according to The Associated Press.

title: Carolina Freight Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 13
description: b-Included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,797,000.c-Net income

title: Markets Surge as the Fed Prepares to Discuss Rates
description: Financial markets surged today on the eve of a Federal Reserve Board meeting as investors bet that the Fed would soon reduce interest rates -- just as President Bush called for last week.

title: Universal Seismic Associates reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington at Work; Administration's Regulation Slayer Has Achieved a Perilous Prominence
description: In an airy office down the hall from the Vice President's, an Indiana lawyer with dark eyes and dawn-to-dusk work habits basks nervously in the limelight of power.

title: USAir Is Said to Show Interest in T.W.A.
description: USAir Group's stock rose sharply yesterday after a report that the company was negotiating to buy the assets of Trans World Airlines. But Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of T.W.A., called the report premature.

title: Zip! Zap! Johnson Never Saw It Coming
description: The first inning was a blur for Jeff Johnson at Yankee Stadium last night. A blur of hits whizzing off Kansas City bats, a blur of baserunners streaking for home and a blur of runs on the scoreboard before a Yankee had even lifted a bat.

title: Bridge
description: Many collections of deals have been published in the past decade, and most of them have been flawed in one or more respects. Some have hands of insufficient quality. Some are poorly analyzed. Some are badly presented. And nearly all are unstructured, with no logical connection between the deals.

title: Still Another Place To Install a Trackball
description: ALTHOUGH falling prices were the big news at the PC Expo computer trade show held in New York City last week, there were many new products of interest on display.

title: Shift in School Fund Plan Gains in Trenton
description: The education committees of the New Jersey Legislature today took the first step toward amending the State Constitution to remove the legal underpinning for the system that transfers money from more affluent school districts to poorer ones.

title: The Summer Forecast: Widespread Wanderlust
description: More Americans will be traveling this summer than at any time in recent years, barring prolonged bad weather, a steep rise in gasoline prices or some other unexpected calamity.

title: Business Scene; New Russian Car: Pretty Good Deal
description: OUTSIDE the Zhiguli Trade Center, the nation's largest new-car dealership, throngs of men loiter. They represent a growing phenomenon in Russia today: the car merchant. Their specialty is to collar people who have just bought new cars and to try to persuade them to sell their shiny vehicles on the spot. Sometimes new-car owners are offered double the amount they paid minutes before to the dealer.

title: This Honorable Court
description: The Supreme Court yesterday preserved liberty for American women and, because of three moderates, honor for itself.

title: Note Offering By BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation offered $500 million in 7 3/4 percent subordinated notes yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are due in 2002 at a price of 99.60, to yield 7.955 percent.

title: Resignation Clears Path at Pepsico
description: One of Pepsico Inc.'s top executives resigned yesterday, leaving Roger A. Enrico as the heir apparent at the $20 billion food and beverage company. The resignation also prompted a reshuffling of top management at several important Pepsico divisions.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB CO., New York, said its joint venture in China announced a $13 million capital expansion program to increase manufacturing capacity at its Shanghai pharmaceutical plant. ENCORE COMPUTER CORP., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., received a $4.4 million contract from Lockheed Corp., Calabasas, Calif., for 11 computer systems for the Air Force.

title: Having Fled City Ills, People Stay Despite Quakes
description: Like her neighbors on the high desert of California, where a vast mesa studded with ungainly Joshua trees fills the basin between the San Bernardino and Pinto mountains, Carmen Mendoza came here to escape big-city ills.

title: 3 Newark Officers Charged in Shooting Cover-Up
description: Three Newark police officers were charged today with conspiring to cover up their actions in connection with the shooting of Howard Caesar, a 17-year-old who the police say was driving a stolen car.

title: Life at the Extremes: Ants Defy Desert Heat
description: BY midday the temperature at the desert's surface has climbed to 140 degrees. As far as the eye can see to the shimmering horizon at the desert's edges, there is not even the tiniest patch of shade. A few animals that have strayed too far from their underground shelters collapse from exhaustion under the Saharan sun.

title: Samaranch, Under the Gun Shoots Back
description: As president of the International Olympic Committee, Juan Antonio Samaranch has every reason to be happy. This year's Winter Olympics, in Albertville, France, went off well. The 1992 Summer Olympics are to open July 25 in his hometown, Barcelona, Spain. And King Juan Carlos recently made him the Marquis of Samaranch in recognition of his work.

title: Review/Television; Parents Running Fast to Keep From Falling Back
description: "Family Matters" begins with plugs for family life from George Bush, Dan Quayle, Ross Perot and Bill Clinton. The rest of the hour is devoted to documenting how remote such campaign fodder is from the daily problems of families with children and not much money.

title: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS U.N. Votes to Send Troops To Reopen Sarajevo Airport; Talks on U.S. Role
description: The Bush Administration stepped up talks with United Nations officials today over the use of United States planes and aviation experts to airlift food and medical supplies to Sarajevo.

title: On July 4, Chemistry Will Paint The Night With Fire
description: WITH the coming of summer and a heady whiff of powder smoke in the air, America's pyrotechnicians, working like Santa's elves on Christmas eve, predict that their newest fireworks will dazzle the senses as never before.

title: Short-Term Rates Fall Sharply
description: Fresh signs of economic weakness sent short-term interest rates to their lowest level in more than two decades yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve Board would soon ease its monetary policy.

title: Clone Maker AST Research Shakes Up Its Management
description: In a management shake-up, AST Research Inc. said today that Thomas C. K. Yuen, its co-founder, co-chairman and chief operating officer, had left the company.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Clinton Is Quiet as Running-Mate Game Roars On
description: It may be a little difficult to detect this year, with all the fuss involving Ross Perot and President Bush, but the customary parlor games that surround the selection of a candidate for Vice President have begun.

title: KLH COMPUTERS ASKS AMEX TO HALT TRADING OF STOCK
description: KLH Computers Inc., operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, asked the American Stock Exchange to stop trading in its common stock and 8.5 percent debentures, effective last Friday. KLH said it could not comply with financial reporting requirements. It said it was unsure it would be allowed to resume trading because it did not meet Amex financial guidelines for listing. KLH closed Friday at 15.625 cents a share. Houston-based KLH, which supplies low-cost computers to discount stores, filed for Chapter 11 in April after it was unable to renegotiate $5.75 million in bonds held by companies controlled by the investor Carl C. Icahn.

title: Review/Jazz Festival; From Gerry Mulligan, 'Rebirth of the Cool'
description: Each jazz era finds its own ancestors. Now that many musicians and audiences are turning toward music that prizes structure as well as solos, it's appropriate that Gerry Mulligan has decided to revive the arrangements he wrote and played with the Miles Davis Nonet more than 40 years ago. The music was collected in 1957 on an album titled "Birth of the Cool," and on Friday night Mr. Mulligan and a "tentet" (the nonet's lineup plus an extra trumpeter and saxophonist) performed at Carnegie Hall for a JVC Jazz Festival concert called "Rebirth of the Cool."

title: Candidates On Television
description: The Presidential campaigners have scheduled these television appearances in coming days: President Bush

title: Davis Distributing reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Protein May Hold Clues to Anti-AIDS Drug
description: THE virus that causes AIDS appropriates members of a newly discovered collection of cellular proteins in order to replicate, scientists have found.

title: A Shelter From Addiction's Storm; In Bronx Apartments, Fresh From Treatment, the Poor Find the Will to Stay Clean
description: Fresh from a 10-month stay at a residential drug treatment program in upstate New York, Frank B. stands on the sidewalk outside his South Bronx apartment building, the shouts of drug dealers and their lookouts echoing faintly from a block away.

title: Helen Olheim Is Dead; A Mezzo-Soprano, 87
description: Helen Olheim, a mezzo-soprano who sang with the Metropolitan Opera, died on Friday at the Beneva Nursing Pavilion in Sarasota, Fla. She was 87 years old.

title: Lindros Decision Today
description: The National Hockey League said yesterday that a ruling on the Eric Lindros controversy by arbitrator Larry Bertuzzi is due today.

title: Peoples Jewellers reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a one-time restructuring provision of $ 5,500,000 to cover the cost of implementing a strategy designed to rationalize store locations, head-office workforce and overhead expenses.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Justice Blackmun On His Longevity
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun, who joined the majority in part in its ruling on the Pennsylvania abortion case, used his own opinion as an opportunity to ponder his mortality and its potentially pivotal effect on the abortion issue.

title: He'll Definitely Return, But Will Steinbrenner Bring Chill With Him?
description: Buck Showalter, the youngest manager in the major leagues, looks as if he has aged about 10 years since he took over the Yankees this season.

title: Barrister Information Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 900,000 for write down of service parts used to main computer hardware and $ 454,000 restructuring charge for both the quarter and year.c-Included $ 4,668,000 for restructuring charge for both the quarter and year.The company said all per-share figures are restated to reflect a reverse, 1-for-6 stock split effective Dec. 20, 1991.

title: U.N. Takes Control of Airport At Sarajevo as Serbs Pull Back
description: United Nations troops took control of Sarajevo airport today in a move described by United Nations officials as a major step toward ending a 12-week siege that has left the city's 400,000 people close to desperation.

title: Aetna to Cut 10% of Work Force, or 4,800 Jobs, by End of '93
description: Aetna Life and Casualty announced yesterday that it would lay off 4,800 workers, more than 10 percent of its work force, by the end of next year as part of its effort to trim costs and narrow the business of the nation's largest publicly traded insurance company.

title: High Court, 5-4, Affirms Right to Abortion But Allows Most of Pennsylvania's Limits
description: WASHINGTON, June 29

title: Taking Manhattan, by Way of Jersey City
description: Appealing to people who want to see every inch of a city they would not dream of setting foot in if they did not have to, the Circle Line will open a berth in Jersey City today for its three-hour cruises around Manhattan.

title: First Human to Get Baboon Liver Is Said to Be Alert and Doing Well
description: A 35-year-old man who became the first human to receive a baboon liver in a transplant operation was reported today to be doing as well as as any recipient of a human liver a day after surgery.

title: 37 South Africa Victims Evoke Angry Eulogies
description: In the dusty amateur soccer stadium of this previously uncelebrated black township, the leadership of black South Africa and a crowd of 25,000 today eulogized victims of the reform era's worst massacre and roared their bitterness at the white Government.

title: Corrections
description: A contents listing on page 1 of the main news section on Sunday, citing a review in The Times Book Review, misidentified the author of "Woman of Valor: Margaret Sanger and the Birth Control Movement in America." She is Ellen Chesler. (Phyllis Chesler is the author of "Women and Madness.")

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; BUSH TO APPEAR ON MORNING INTERVIEW SHOW
description: President Bush, who recently suggested that he was not cool enough to appear with the talk-show host Arsenio Hall, apparently finds the hosts of the CBS News program "CBS This Morning," Paula Zahn and Harry Smith, more his speed. On Wednesday morning the President will appear on a special segment of "CBS This Morning" to be broadcast from the White House from 7 to 8 A.M.

title: Stars Are Missing? This U.S. Cast Could Still Reign in Spain
description: So how do you gauge this track and field team the United States will send to the Barcelona Olympics?

title: New York City's Loft Law Is Extended
description: The New York State Legislature passed a bill today to extend and modify the law governing New York City's loft residences, allowing thousands of artists to continue living in lofts without fear of eviction.

title: In Trenton, Battle Over Budget Goes Down to the Wire
description: Under pressure from a maverick Republican Senator who is trying to win more benefits for his district, Republican legislative leaders today delayed their attempt to override Gov. Jim Florio's veto of their $14.6 billion budget.

title: HIGH COURT, 5-4, AFFIRMS RIGHT TO ABORTION BUT ALLOWS MOST OF PENNSYLVANIA'S LIMITS
description: By the narrowest of margins, and in words reflecting anger and anguish alike at its continuing role in the center of the storm over abortion, the Supreme Court today reaffirmed what it called the "essence" of the constitutional right to abortion while at the same time permitting some new state restrictions.

title: Dalfen's Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income of $ 57,361, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $ 1,177,845 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations and both reflects the company's retail operations.The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ruling Inspires Groups to Fight Harder
description: It was clear today outside the Planned Parenthood clinic that challenged this state's abortion law that both sides in the debate remained a universe apart.

title: Kicking Off the Slick: The Other Talley Beatty
description: Talley Beatty has made his name as a leading modern-dance choreographer with flowing, high-energy jazz dances. But another side of Mr. Beatty will be on view this week at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., when Philadanco, a Philadelphia-based modern-dance company, performs a revival of Mr. Beatty's "Southern Landscape," a 1947 work that has not been performed as a whole since 1949. Philadanco will share the program with the Jose Limon Dance Company in an engagement to open tonight and run through Saturday night in the Ted Shawn Theater.

title: A G.O.P. Rift in Albany May Hinder Health Bill
description: New York State lawmakers said today that they had finally agreed to overhaul the state's health insurance system, but the agreement remains uncertain because of a highly unusual internal dispute among Senate Republicans.

title: Dream Team Routs Might Mean Lowly Ratings
description: No doubt about it, the men's Olympic basketball team proved it was the Dream Team on Sunday night. So soothing, so numbing was its 136-57 embarrassment of Team Cuba that I confess I slept, perchance to dream of competitive basketball -- and Fidel Castro posting up big-time in the paint.

title: Outside Court, Rival Rallies and Heavy Politicking
description: At the precise moment the Supreme Court was issuing its much-awaited opinion, advocates of abortion rights and their opponents sallied forth to interpret it. They had not had a chance to read it, but never mind: with few exceptions they already knew they did not like it.

title: DOW CORNING WILL SELL ITS ARTIFICIAL-JOINT BUSINESS
description: Dow Corning Inc. said it would sell its global medical-devices business, which makes artificial joints for hands, hips, knees and feet. Dow Corning, Midland, Mich., a 50-50 joint venture of Corning Inc. and the Dow Chemical Company, declined to disclose a sales price. It said the unit was expected to post annual sales of about $100 million this year.

title: A Victory for Roe
description: When Roe v. Wade came down in 1973, holding that women had a fundamental right of access to abortion, its opponents launched two offensives that persist to this day.

title: Scandal Brings Police Added Stress and Scrutiny
description: When Dennis Pagan became a New York City police officer, he followed his two older brothers into a job from which he thought professional satisfaction would flow as steadily as the paychecks. On fleeting occasions he still feels that way: Two weeks ago, a crowd applauded when he helped arrest three burglary suspects.

title: Long Fight for Local Support Hampers Bush on Education
description: Four years after George Bush took office proclaiming himself to be the "education President," he can point to few tangible accomplishments that have improved the nation's schools.

title: Excerpts From the Justices' Decision in the Pennsylvania Case
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today in the Pennsylvania abortion case, Planned Parenthood v. Casey. Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, and David H. Souter jointly wrote an opinion for the Court upholding a portion of the regulations -- an "informed consent" provision and a 24-hour waiting period -- and reaffirming the 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling that legalized abortion, but declaring unconstitutional a requirement that women seeking abortions notify their husbands. Justices John Paul Stevens and Harry A. Blackmun each wrote an opinion arguing that all the restrictions should have been found unconstitutional.

title: For Head Start, Two Steps Back
description: Head Start is, in a sense, the motherhood and apple pie of Government programs. Everybody, rightly, is crazy about it -- the President and parents, Congress and local politicians of every persuasion. But what all this love adds up to, Prof. Edward Zigler of Yale wrote on The Times's Op-Ed page last week, is "public whispers of sweet nothings. When political push came to budgetary shove, Head Start lost."

title: Topics of The Times; Whose Higher Education?
description: Higher education in New York has suffered in recent years. Tuition at public colleges and universities has increased while public support has decreased. So has the state's program of support for private universities.

title: Richard Fontana Dies; French Stage Actor, 40
description: Richard Fontana, a star of the Comedie Francaise and a leading stage actor in France, died here on Friday. He was 40 years old and lived in Paris.

title: Ridden With Debt, U.S. Companies Cut Funds for Research
description: SCIENTIFIC research by private industry, the traditional powerhouse of innovation and technological leadership in the United States, is suffering deeper financial woes than previously disclosed, suggesting that America is slipping in the international race for discoveries that form the basis of new goods and services.

title: U.N. Peace Mission in Moldova Is Thwarted by Separatist Fighting
description: Gun and artillery fire prevented a three-member United Nations fact-finding delegation from entering a separatist region of Moldova today.

title: Leader Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Apirl 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.The company attributed its increased revenues to the consolidation of sales of CPF Dualam, Concept and Incendex, which were acquired in 1991. It added that sales at its Leader Sports and Leader Tekno divisions were up 48 percent in the quarter.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Gay-Rights Bill in Peril
description: Gay-rights advocates have apparently failed in their bid to win Assembly passage this year of a bill that would specifically include gay men and lesbians among the groups protected under the state's civil rights law. Assembly officials said today that they could not be assured of mustering the necessary 76 supporters in the 150-member chamber and that they would not schedule the bill for a vote.

title: Melvin C. Steen, 85, a Founder Of the Cleary, Gottlieb Law Firm
description: Melvin C. Steen, a corporate and securities lawyer in New York, died at his home in Bronxville, N.Y., on Sunday. He was 85 years old.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: The Festival of Cultural Diversity Grand Central Terminal

title: New Government Plan For National Forests Generates a Debate
description: IN the weeks since the Forest Service adopted what it calls "a more ecologically sound approach" to managing the National Forests, debate has flourished over whether the policy amounts to a major philosophical shift, a barely modified form of business as usual, or something in between.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of the Times column on Sunday, about a dispute in the selection process for the United States Olympic boxing team, referred incorrectly in some editions to the light heavyweight who lost an elimination bout. He is Terry McGroom.

title: Ruling Eases a Worry for Bush, But Just Wait, His Critics Warn
description: From the standpoint of President Bush's re-election strategy, today's Supreme Court ruling on abortion took the edge off a recurring Republican nightmare. But if his opponents are right about the potency of the abortion issue, it will continue to challenge him.

title: Suit Names Cable Unit
description: The successor to the bankrupt Financial News Network Inc. announced yesterday that it was suing Telecommunications Inc., the nation's largest operator of cable television systems, saying it had interfered with FNN's 1990 attempt to sell a major asset, the Learning Channel.

title: A Busy '92 for Wall St. Underwriters
description: Wall Street's money-raising bonanza extended through this year's second quarter, as the value of stocks and bonds taken to market again topped $200 billion and set a record.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Gay Pride parade in Manhattan misidentified a motorcycle group and referred incorrectly to the appearance of its contingent. It is the Empire City Motorcycle Club. While some members wore leather caps, vests and G-strings, most were fully clothed.

title: No New Report From Vincent
description: Commissioner Fay Vincent and George Steinbrenner met for an hour and a half at a midtown hotel yesterday in a session the commissioner said produced "nothing significant."

title: Square Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included gain from tax-loss carryforward of $ 230,000, or 19 cents a share.The company said the increased operating results were mainly the result of a small increase in parking capacity; increased patronage in several locations due, in part, to several promotional and sales programs and improved traffic flow in the downtown Philadelphia area.

title: Lothar Kalinowsky, A Psychiatrist, 92; Used Electroshocks
description: Dr. Lothar B. Kalinowsky, a psychiatrist who was a teacher and author in the field of electroshock therapy, died on Sunday in his apartment in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: Pettibone Corp. reports earnings for 12 mos March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,868,000.

title: Third World Women Aren't the Big Polluters; Vatican's Blind Spot
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of U.N. Resolution Allowing the Dispatch of Troops
description: Following is the text of Security Council Resolution 761, approved unanimously today, which authorizes peacekeeping forces to reopen the airport in Sarajevo for delivery of aid to Bosnia and Herzegovina: THE SECURITY COUNCIL,

title: McElligott Wright Is Losing McElligott
description: McElligott Wright Morrison White in Minneapolis said yesterday that Tom McElligott, chairman, chief executive and creative director, would soon leave the two-year-old shop.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Neo Classic String Quartet Daming Zhu Taipei Theater Manhattan

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Sunday about events surrounding the Columbus anniversary gave an incorrect date for the end of public viewing of reproductions of Columbus's ships at the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum in Manhattan. They will be on view through July 14, not July 7. The article also misstated the location for a fireworks display on July 4. It will take place at Battery Park, not the South Street Seaport.

title: When Sports Pitchmen Fall It's Time to Control the Spin
description: NEVER mind the running, jumping and swimming scheduled for the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain. All eyes are now on the furious scrambling, ambushing and maneuvering by the Olympic advertisers.

title: Welcome to Japan; Leave All Stereotypes on the Plane, Please
description: A MONTH ago, Amy Weibel, Kirsten Malone and Adam Lobel thought they knew about Japan. Today, they know what they thought they knew is only partly true. And they've begun to wonder if what they thought they knew about each other might also be a little off.

title: NEXT GETS $65 MILLION OF ADDITIONAL FINANCING
description: Next Inc. said it had secured additional private financing in the form of a $55 million credit line from Canon Inc. of Japan and a $10 million line of credit from Steven P. Jobs, the computer company's founder, chairman and chief executive. The financing, which the company said was the last it would need, indicated that Next would not make a public offering of stock this year. Many analysts had expected such an offering.

title: Books of The Times; Snapshots From a Family Album
description: Marine Life By Linda Svendsen 165 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; CLINTON CAMP SEEKS TO UNDERSTAND NEW YORK COMMUTE
description: The Democratic National Convention in New York is less than two weeks away, and the Clinton campaign is sweating the details.

title: Giants Stadium Rolls Seven as World Cup Site
description: The designation of Soldier Field in Chicago as the site of the opening game of ther 1994 World Cup tournament, and the choice of Giants Stadium for seven games, highlighted today's announcement of the nine American stadiums that will be hosts to all 52 games of the soccer extavaganza.

title: Times Completes Deliverers' Purchase
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it had completed its long-planned purchase of two newspaper wholesale distribution companies, the Metropolitan News Company and Newark Newsdealers Supply Company, which deliver The Times and many other newspapers to retail outlets and home delivery depots in New York City and central and northern New Jersey.

title: O'Brien Sets His Sights on French Event
description: There may be no Olympics this year for DAN O'BRIEN, but there may still be a world record. The world decathlon champion said his failure Saturday in the United States Olympic track and field trials in New Orleans had led him to accept an invitation to a major competition in early September in Talence, France.

title: Patterns
description: Ripped-Up at Retail

title: Manor Care reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 4,166,000 which reflects early debt redemption for both the quarter and year, and both the quarter and year included a gain of $ 18.8 million from the sale of stock by the company's institutional pharmacy subsidiary, Vitalink Pharmacy Services.The company said shares outstanding and earnings per share have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 27.

title: Murder Charges Expected This Week in Reso Case
description: The authorities said today that they would wait at least a day to file murder charges in the kidnapping of Sidney J. Reso, the Exxon executive whose body was found Saturday night in a shallow grave in the vast Pine Barrens with a bullet wound in one arm.

title: A Protest Is Thinned in Belgrade
description: An anti-Government protest faltered today when most of those who came out on Sunday to call for the resignation of Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, ignored pleas from the organizers that they remain in the plaza outside Parliament.

title: Rebecca C. Simonson; Schoolteacher, 95
description: Rebecca C. Simonson, a New York City schoolteacher active in school affairs in the 1940's and 1950's, died on Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. She was 95 years old and lived in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Dirty Business on Clean Air
description: President Bush has celebrated the 1990 Clean Air Act as a triumph for the environment and for bipartisanship. Now he has undermined the act with weak new regulations that risk fouling both the air and whatever good will he has left with Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill.

title: Big Guys Look Little Again as Mets Lose to Cubs
description: The autopsy reports on the Mets turn up nearly identical game after game. The organization isn't fooled, even if it is limited in what it can do. The manager has been reduced to acts of curious, even comic desperation. The players make sense but no progress in their evaluation of it all.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Marijuana vs. Alcohol for Teen-Agers
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerrold S. Maxmen; Psychiatrist, 50
description: Jerrold S. Maxmen, a psychiatrist, author and associate professor of clinical psychiatry at Columbia University, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 50 years old.

title: Lawrence Pomeroy, A Retired Lawyer, 79
description: Lawrence Pomeroy, a former New York City lawyer who devoted his retirement to conservation activities on Block Island, R.I., died on Friday at Newport Hospital in Rhode Island. He was 79 years old and had lived in New Rochelle, N.Y., for many years before moving to Newport.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Disunity Is a Tradition That Hurts Democrats
description: Paul E. Tsongas was chatting with Ross Perot last week. Jesse Jackson did his flirting the week before. Both men are Democrats, but both seem in a persistent state of pique with their party, and neither seems to pay much of a price for it.

title: Of Gaps and How to Bridge Them
description: THE personal computer industry is diverging and converging at the same time. An example of divergence is the split between International Business Machines and Microsoft on operating systems. An example of convergence is the alliance forged between I.B.M. and Apple Computer Inc.

title: Justices Ease Way to Challenge Land-Use Rules That Prevent Development
description: Ruling in a closely watched case on property rights, the Supreme Court today made it easier for some property owners to challenge land-use regulations and demand compensation from the government if "confiscatory regulations" prevent them from developing their land.

title: INSIDE
description: Avis Raising New York Rates

title: Lilly Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Scripps Winner's Dances Are for the Soul
description: The choreographer Donald McKayle received the 1992 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award on Sunday night at the Page Auditorium of Duke University.

title: Global Income Plus Fund reports earnings for As of April 30
description: Net income represented net investment income.As of April 30, total net assets for the latest period was $ 246,987,894, or $ 9.62 a share, compared with $ 9.74 a share, for the year-earlier period. Total net assets figure for the year-earlier period was not immediately available.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; Bush Denounces Rap Recording and Gives D'Amato a Hand
description: Casting about for new themes for his re-election campaign, President Bush yesterday copied a page from Vice President Dan Quayle's playbook -- almost.

title: Reconstructing Jelly Through His Music
description: Luther Henderson, the pianist, composer and orchestrator, has been the arranger and conductor of more than 50 Broadway musicals. But when people try to describe what he did for the hit musical "Jelly's Last Jam," he says, they can't figure out what to call him.

title: Concord Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Basic Earth Science reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a fourth-quarter $ 113,000 charge against capitalized oil and gas property cost absorbed by the company.c-Net income

title: ISRAEL DETAINS 17 WHO MET ARAFAT
description: Seventeen members of the Palestinian delegation to the Middle East peace talks were held by the Israeli police today and questioned about their recent public embrace of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Lieut. Gen. Daniel Strickler, 95, Veteran of Three Wars, Is Dead
description: Lieut. Gen. Daniel B. Strickler, retired, who served in three wars and was a former Lieutenant Governor of Pennsylvania, died on Monday in a retirement home in Lancaster, Pa. He was 95 years old.

title: Franklin Quest Co. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Pro forma; upon the company's initial public offering in June, it changed from S to C Corporation status.

title: Reconstructing Quakes: New California Equation
description: At 7 o'clock this morning, Kerry Sieh, a seismologist, climbed into a helicopter, unfolded geologic maps of the Mojave Desert and set off on what he described as "the happiest day of my life."

title: U.N. Votes to Send Troops To Reopen Sarajevo Airport
description: As Serbian forces besieging Sarajevo backed down, the Security Council voted unanimously today to send troops to secure the airport for delivery of food and medicine to the hungry, war-battered residents.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They bade farewell to Wilbur D. Mills, the former chairman of the Ways and Means Committee in the House of Representatives, at a service in the Longworth House Office Building in Washington yesterday. For three hours, an audience of more than 200 listened to such eulogists as Senators DALE L. BUMPERS and DAVID H. PRYOR SR., both Democrats of Arkansas; former Senator RUSSELL B. LONG, Democrat of Louisiana; former Governor HUGH L. CAREY of New York and Representative DAN ROSTENKOWSKI, Democrat of Illinois. Mr. Mills died on May 2 at the age of 82.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "I'll take tornadoes any day. At least you can see them coming." --CHRISTINE CURRAN, a native of Indiana, who suffered through the earthquake in California yesterday. [ A14:3 ]

title: NORWAY IS PLANNING TO RESUME WHALING DESPITE WORLD BAN
description: The six-year-old international moratorium on commercial whaling began to crumble today, with both Norway and Iceland declaring that some species had been so well protected that they could be hunted again without danger of extinction.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Fiber-Optic Feat; Lots of Conversations Over One Skinny Cable
description: Progress in modern telecommunications is often invisible, but enormous. Scientists at A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories reported last week that they had succeeded in doubling the previous record for information that can be conveyed using blindingly fast pulses of light -- some 6.8 billion bits of information, or pulses of light, a second.

title: Arrow International reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included $ 4.4 million, or 20 cents a share, in non-recurring income from patent litigation settlement.

title: Lexus Ranks Highest
description: Toyota's Lexus line of luxury automobiles has been ranked No. 1 in the United States in J. D. Power & Associates survey of cars that are regarded as most satisfying after 12 months of ownership. Nissan's Infiniti brand was second, and the General Motors Corporation's Saturn cars were third, according to the survey released today.

title: Market Place; A Slower Flow Into Stock Funds
description: THE stock market has gone nowhere fast this year, but only now are investors finally beginning to slow their headlong rush into stock mutual funds.

title: Argentine Chief Suffers Setback as His Senate Candidate Loses
description: President Carlos Saul Menem suffered a political setback on Sunday when voters in the Argentine capital, apparently upset over continued scandal involving Government officials, gave his Peronist party's candidate for the Senate just 32 percent of the vote, while the opposition Radical Party candidate won with 50 percent.

title: Q&A
description: Big Eyes

title: Hubble Observations Find Universe Is Older Than Some Thought
description: SCIENTISTS using the Hubble Space Telescope say new observations of a distant galaxy suggest that the universe is older and larger than many scientists had thought.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN -- Voices: Houston; Worries That the Nation's Schools Fall Short
description: Political experts, local officials and ordinary voters in several cities were asked to appraise President Bush's handling of issues involving education. Gladys House 36, sandwich shop manager, active in working for education reform

title: Empire Co. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: What the French Pay For Their Electricity
description: To the Editor:

title: Investment in a TV Station Raises Questions
description: Has Mario Gabelli, who became a mutual-fund superstar in the 80's by dealing heavily in media stocks, exceeded the number of broadcast properties that a money manager can legally own in his portfolios?

title: 15-Year-Old Dies From Shot to Chest
description: A 15-year-old Manhattan boy died yesterday after he was found with a bullet wound to his chest outside a known drug location in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: Third World Women Aren't the Big Polluters
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote Near on Regulation Of Fannie and Freddie
description: The Senate is finally nearing a vote, expected as early as Wednesday, on a measure that for the first time would subject to independent regulation two Government-sponsored institutions that have guaranteed nearly $1 trillion worth of home mortgages.

title: Three Who Spoke as One
description: From the joint opinion by Associate Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy and David H. Souter.

title: Chess
description: Sometimes there is cunning in being blunt. When you make your intentions overt, they may look so gross and undisguised that no one believes you really mean to carry them out. This works best when your plan takes a dozen moves or more. Your opponent may think that vicissitudes will surely intervene to punish such elaborate machinations.

title: Sports of The Times; Odd Sound: 'Come On, Jeremy!'
description: WHO sneezed? Who clicked the camera? Who made the noise that froze Jeremy Bates in mid-serve at match point, and ultimately plunged this island nation back into its normal state of sporting defeatism?

title: By Design; Shopper's Delight
description: This is utopia time for those who take their fashion seriously. New fall styles are filling store racks. American designers, toting their fall collections, are crisscrossing the country to promote them. But best of all, top designer merchandise from spring is on sale.

title: Biocircuits Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.Biocircuits said it completed its initial public offering of 2,000,000 common shares at $ 5.00 a share on May 14, and on June 17, underwriters exercised their over-allotment option by purchasing 143,270 shares and the company received net proceeds of $ 9,966,206 from the offering.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Columbia Hospital Corp., Fort Worth, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of $135 million in senior subordinated notes due in 2002 through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The offering is conditioned on the completion of Columbia's proposed merger with Basic American Medical Inc.

title: Macy Had $38.9 Million 4-Week Loss
description: R. H. Macy & Company reported yesterday that it had lost $38.9 million in the four weeks that ended May 30, sending yet another signal that the bankrupt retailer was still unable to stop its continuing losses.

title: Executive Changes
description: HOGAN SYSTEMS INC., Dallas, which produces software for financial institutions, appointed Michael H. Anderson president, chief executive and a director. MASSACHUSETTS MUTUAL LIFE INSURANCE CO., Springfield, Mass., named Gary E. Wendlandt executive vice president.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-A10 RELIEF SUPPLIES IN SARAJEVO

title: U.S. to Ease Push for Policy Shifts by Germany and Japan
description: After long pressuring Germany and Japan to do more to stimulate world growth, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that the United States would not prod them so hard at the economic summit meeting in Munich because they seem ready to adopt policies that Washington has favored.

title: Toronto Journal; Canada the Magnet: Enter Stage-Struck Russians
description: Sergei Pavlov is a concert pianist trained at the Moscow Conservatory. In Canada he has been tuning pianos and manning an ice-cream cart.

title: Magic in Midst of Act As U.S. Beats Canada
description: There are superstars of all sizes on the United States Olympic Team, including the best player in the game, Michael Jordan, but this would be no Dream Team without Magic Johnson and Larry Bird. On Coach Chuck Daly's team, Jordan is the brightest star of a spectacular lot. But Johnson and Bird, who reinvented the game for men their size, still carry the aura of masters of the universe.

title: Principal's Tough Tack Roils Brooklyn School
description: Songs sounded, cameras clicked and colorful balloons and flowers adorned the packed auditorium at Public School 212 in Brooklyn last week as 200 fifth- and sixth-graders graduated in front of proud relatives.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY OPINION DIVIDED ON BROOKLYN PRINCIPAL

title: A Tax on Parking Attacks the Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: In Au Pair Trial, Judge Gets a Chance to Show His Verbal Sparring Skills
description: Lawyers, like all performers, play roles.

title: Top Lawmakers Vow to Push Abortion-Rights Bill
description: House and Senate leaders vowed today that Congress would pass legislation to protect abortion rights, although they ac knowledged that they lacked the votes to override an expected veto by President Bush.

title: Fiscal Footwork Is Fancy In Plan for Police Recruits
description: In an audacious move to outwit the State Legislature and save the city $20 million next year, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced today that he would require 2,104 New York City police recruits to begin their training at 11:59:59 P.M. on Tuesday, the last second of the fiscal year.

title: Adelphia Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance; A Roster of Guest Artists Ends City Ballet's Season
description: Personnel changes are in the works at the New York City Ballet, at least on the visitor's level. Mikhail Baryshnikov completed the last of his guest appearances on Saturday night with a repeat of Mark Morris's "Three Preludes." In a rare show of emotion, he clasped his hands to his heart during a curtain call and then opened his arms to the audience.

title: Pavichevich Brewing reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Topics of The Times; A Doctor's Life
description: Dr. Jan Jakob Smulewicz died of heart failure in New York last week at the age of 69. He was not famous. He never made the gossip magazines or TV talk shows. Before yesterday's obituary, he'd been mentioned in The Times only once. Judging from that obituary, he was a man worth knowing.

title: On My Mind; The Israeli Gamble
description: Consider:

title: Ernest Acker, 96, Who Worked For Utility Company for 45 Years
description: Ernest R. Acker, a utility executive who retired as head of the Central Hudson Gas & Electric Corporation in 1964 after 45 years with the company, died on Friday in the Caleb Hitchcock nursing home in Bloomfield, Conn. A former resident of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., he was 96 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Allison Dunham, a professor who helped to make states' laws uniform, misstated the day of his death in Pomona, Calif. It was Friday.

description: To the Editor:
